story:
SustainableJoes ~ 

SustainableJoes is about making sustainability easy for "Everyday Joes." After living off the electrical grid and producing less than one bag of garbage in year one, SustainableJoes’ founder Stephen Szucs (Such) just completed Leg One of the SustainableJoes’ #RETHINK Tour. Cycling almost 5,000 miles, in just over 6 months from Ontario, Canada to Key West, Florida on a solar and pedal powered tricycle (The ELF), SustainableJoes has engaged tens of thousands of people already. Today more people are #RETHINKing sustainability because of SustainableJoes, and we want to continue that momentum.

However, we need your help to tell the story of Joes on a larger scale. Your support of this campaign will fund the production of a short documentary serving as an educational tool for schools, families, corporations, and communities. 

We believe our world needs to move in a sustainable direction, and we are certain we can get there faster together.

“Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed people can change the world. Indeed, it’s the only thing that ever has!” ~Margaret Mead 

How will we accomplish our mission to make sustainability easy?

Passion, will power, and your help! SustainableJoes is working to identify, evaluate, and provide implementable sustainable solutions. Our delivery method follows the 5 E’s of Joes. To Engage, Entertain, Educate, Empower, and to make sustainability Easy. Today, more people are talking about stewardship and sustainability because of SustainableJoes. Upon completion, this documentary will serve as an entertaining educational tool for students, families, corporations and communities. 

What's The Plan?

This Campaign

  • Will get more people to #RETHINK sustainability. The documentary produced with your donations will serve as an entertaining and educational tool for schools, corporations, and communities. 

Future Development

  • Website - The “Hub for Hope” demonstrating simple sustainable solutions anyone can implement, and displaying quantifiable results.
  • #RETHINK Tour Leg Two - Fuelling sustainable dialogue and action. Stephen and a team of Joes will journey around the world highlighting sustainable difference makers, uniting all, making sustainability easier, and sharing the story every step of the way.

Ask & Allocation

Campaign Goal - $6,000

  • Expenses related to Documentary Campaign - $2,000
  • Production Costs - $2,500
  • Website Modifications - $1,000
  • Miscellaneous - $500
  • Note - Any donations received in excess of the ask will be used first for web development and then to build Leg Two of the RETHINK tour. 

Timeline

Documentary Release - June/July 2015

How you can get involved 

Step 1 - Share this campaign and get the word out there! Together we will get everyone #RETHINKing sustainability.

Step 2 - Join the SustainableJoes community and get involved today at SustainableJoes.com. 

Step 3 - Donate. if you want sustainable change and can financially support Joes.

Your Impact

Your support makes this documentary happen, and in a very real way keeps SustainableJoes going. This is a fixed funding campaign, meaning the documentary will only be produced if the campaign goal is reached. 

“Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed people can change the world. Indeed, it’s the only thing that ever has!” ~Margaret Mead  

Thank You, SustainableJoes

*Shipping is included for items in the lower 48 states and Canada.

story:
3000KM THROUGH INDIA IN AN AUTORICKSHAW

Hey guys!

We're a couple of friends gearing up to embark on an epic journey 3000km across India in an auto rickshaw.

We're not crazy, it's all for charity!

Pay it forward by donating to Cool Earth, a charity that works alongside indigenous villages to prevent deforestation and protect our rainforest.

Why Donate to Cool Earth to Save Rainforest in Congo?

Cool Earth's Lubutu project is in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. After years of civil war, DRC is on the brink of development with mounting pressure on its forest. Cool Earth is working alongside five villages in the Maniema Province to protect the highly at-risk forest between two National Parks.

Sponsoring Lubutu rainforest funds the villages’ rainforest protection and community investments to ensure our partner communities are best placed to keep their forest standing.

The Impact

Your donations will help to:
Protect the Rainforest and its Inhabitants from Mining Threats
Prevent Deforestation
Losing Endangered Species and Fauna
You are able to track the progress of how many acres have been saved, trees protected, people supported, and tonnes of C02 stored by following this link: 

http://www.coolearth.org/429/save-the-rainforest-in-lubutu-congo

How the Jenggols in India are Helping

We will be embarking on this trip to India with at least 100 other teams, all of them with the same goals in mind. 

We will document our trip and adventure through our personal social media and blogs to raise awareness of our cause. 

During our trip we will also be talking to the locals to collect donations from them along the way.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate to our cause, do not worry... Just help us to get the word out! Share this link with your networks to help us make some noise and excitement!

story:
Our journey started with a trip to Cambodia, a region with heart-wrenching levels of poverty and plastic pollution. The municipalities in these regions were struggling to budget basic necessities, so spending money on waste management was a low priority. We realized that we had to engage the brands who supply the plastic in these communities to contribute towards a solution.

It took over three years of perseverance and research to develop our process and mobile technology for providing fair trade market access to the waste picker recyclers in developing regions. 


Our system and process can now ensure that waste-picker recyclers receive a fair trade rate. Similar to how fair trade agriculture helps to increase the value farmers receive for their produce.

We have tested our mobile technology and fair trade transaction platform working with recyclers in India. But we need your backing to grow the platform and provide access to fair trade recycling to more developing communities.

What We Need & What You Get

We have developed and tested the mobile technology. We now need $10,000 to fund the implementation phase. We will use this funding to work with multiple communities in India and provide access to fair trade recycling. Overtime we will continuously improve the platform and develop partnerships with NGOs to help grow the model throughout Asia, Africa and Latin America.

We estimate that it will cost $10 for each additional waste picker we add onto the platform once the system is operational in the community. *This is our best estimate we will update you if it changes.

With your contribution you can help liberate some of the most marginalized members of society, while increasing recycling rates and reducing plastic pollution. You can also receive some amazing eco-friendly perks for your contribution. 

Our Impact

In most developing countries recycling rates are a dismal 2-8%. Governments in these regions don’t have the budget to develop recycling infrastructure, instead it is often the poorest members of the community that collect and exchange the discarded plastics for a living. Increasing the monetary benefit for collecting discarded plastics is a proven strategy for increasing recycling rates.

1) Providing a fair trade minimum rate.

The fall of oil prices has made it cheaper for companies to use virgin plastic (new plastic from oil) rather than recycled plastic. The decreased demand for recycled plastic has caused a massive drop in the value of plastic which waste pickers collect. The millions of waste picker recyclers who rely on collecting discarded plastics have been affected the most. In some regions their income has decreased 40% since oil prices fell in 2013.  



2) Fighting climate change through recycling.

Waste Management estimates that recycling one ton of plastics saves 16.3 barrels (685 gallons) of oil and 98 million Btu's of energy. Creating new plastic from oil accelerates climate change and kills jobs in the recycling industry. Over 8 trillion pounds of plastic exists on our planet. With your help we can transition brands away from using virgin plastic by using ethically sourced recycled plastic instead. 


 3) Decreasing plastic pollution in our ocean 

Over 8 million tons of plastic enters the ocean each year.That’s the equivalent of placing five garbage bags of trash on every foot of the 217,000 miles of coastline on our planet! 80% of this plastic pollution starts on land. 

Even more alarming is the fact that the amount of plastic entering our ocean is expected to double within 15 years. At this rate by 2025 there will be 1 tonne of plastic for every 3 tonnes of fish in our oceans.

By increasing the monetary value of discarded plastics for those who collect it, we prevent the human behavior that contributes to plastic pollution while building a more resilient waste-management system.


4) Creating respectable employment.  

In India alone, over 1.5 million people make their primary household income from waste picking. Imagine how many families we could impact by expanding our platform to high poverty regions in Asia, Africa and South America. 

Globally over two billion people live on less than two dollars / day and in these same regions approximately three billion people lack access to formal waste management.

Through our ethical sourcing platform we can use plastic pollution as a resource to create a sustainable source of employment for millions.


Risks & Challenges

The waste management industry in developing regions can be plagued with corruption. In some regions mobs will use corrupt means to gain a monopoly over the plastic exporters in the regions. This allows them to dictate the price that waste pickers receive. In the beginning we will target regions that aren’t controlled by the mob and over time we will work to elevate corruption by providing an alternative inclusive recycling system.

                                            Other Ways You Can Help

1. Add your voice for a better future. Share our message online and stay up to date with a follow. 

2. Reach out to your favorite brands and educate them about this opportunity. Together we can increase recycling rates, reduce plastic pollution and create dignified jobs by engaging brands in the solution.

3. Join our Global Change Agents community and receive exclusive invitations and bi-monthly updates . 


                       Click to share on twitter                         

                Spread this campaign on Facebook

              Email this to people in your network

                                                                      

Our team has a combined 70+ years of experience working in sustainability, ethical sourcing and increasing recycling rates. Learn more at www.plasticsforchange.org

story:
Marañon River is the hydrological source of the Amazon, and is under threat from 20 large scale hydroelectric projects.

My goal is to raise funds to help the locals of the Rio Maranon who will become future raft guides on the river. All funds raised go towards covering their costs on an 18 day training expedition. I am volunteering my own time and covering my own expenses to be a safety boater and whitewater instructor.

This paddling with purpose aims to open up pathways for locals to become more involved in growing ecotourism and develop new relationships between riverside communities, which will play a part in stopping the construction of these dams. We will also share an incredible experience with a group of people who would not otherwise have the chance to see the river in this way- this can be life changing.


As a marine scientist and kayaking enthusiast, I am volunteering with Paddling with Purpose and taking three weeks off of work in order to go on this expedition to help preserve the river conditions and encourage the use of the natural resources in a sustainable way. This is one small step, but it is part of a much bigger campaign being developed by Paddling with Purpose, Peruvian NGO Conservamos por Naturaleza. It is one small way I can use my skills as a kayaker to help in the fight against these dam projects.


History of the River

The Rio Maranon, the Grand Canyon of South America, is one of the most important water sources in Peru and an key tributary of the Amazon. The river supports thousands of people locally by providing food and employment opportunities. The river contains a fragile ecosystem, home to many life forms. 

There are 20 dams proposed for the Rio Maranon, and it is possible that 8 of these will be built. Dams are now known to be costly and provide environmental harm and as a result, the removal of dams is taking place in the United States at this very moment as they have not met their output requirements. Sadly the same cannot be said for developing countries. Twenty dams are proposed for the stretch of the Rio Maranon which would disrupt the major hydrological source to the Amazon, alter normal silt deposition into the lower river, destroy habitat and migration patterns for fish and other aquatic life and displace thousands of residents along the river. 

Welcome to Paddling with Purpose!

So what are we doing to prevent this? Paddling with Purpose has developed plans for this expedition which will take place towards the end of may and will be a training expedition for a number of proactive, passionate young people from dam affected villages of Mendan and Tupen. This will provide these people with the opportunity to fully experience the Marañón River while it still runs in its natural state. This expedition will take us from the foothills of the Andes, through to the beginnings of the Amazon Jungle. We will train the locals in whitewater safety.We will spread awareness about why it is essential for the wellbeing of the ecosystems and locals dependent on this river to maintain its natural freeflowing state.

The beauty of this is that by engaging local people to become guides, we have a way to connect with the entire community; from providing cooked meals as raft groups pass by to having pre-arranged fresh fruit and vegetable drops. This can help make contacts within the community and gain support from locals who also wish to preserve the river.If the dams destroy the river & dislodge these communities, then at least the locals whom we are training will be able to keep their connection with the river, and find work in this industry elsewhere in Peru.

Risks and challenges

·  Taking inexperienced people on a long river trip (rapids are mainly Class II and Class III, but there are a few Class IV rapids to navigate. My main role on this trip will be as a safety kayaker for participants as they take their first strokes on the river.

·  There will be communication and teamwork challenges to work through.

·  Other normal challenges associated with a long expedition. 

·  By focusing on teaching whitewater safety techniques from the beginning we will mitigate these risks as much as possible.

The section we are training people on is an extremely relaxed class III section, with one IV. We will be taking many breaks and stopping to practice skills. We are simply introducing people, teaching the basics and opening up a pathway into this career if they want to pursue it in the future.

Costs
These are the costs for the entire expedition:
Broad Cost Breakdown:
Equipment Hire $4,000
Transport $3,000
Food $2,000    
I am part of a small group of volunteers who are working hard to make this journey happen. Together, we need to raise a minimum target of $9,000. This amount will allow us to invite six Peruvian participants. if we can raise more money, then we will have more flexibility in the program and the ability to invite more participants.

story:
Short Summary

 Everyone needs a calendar, so why not also support the farmers who grow our food?? Proceeds will go towards establishing a community farm to engage youth in growing food, and support new farmers. 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what's going on:

  • Your donation covers printing, design, and photography costs for a 2019 On the Farm calendar. 
  • The calendar features Squamish farmers and food producers. Photos were taken by our amazing friend and photographer Nina LaFlamme. 
  • Proceeds from calendar sales will fund the creation of a community farm in Squamish, BC. 
  • If you want this calendar for cheaper, this is the time to get it as a perk. Once our Indiegogo campaign is over, calendar prices will go up!

The Impact

The community farm will: 

  • Engage Squamish youth in growing and selling local food
  • Provide youth with no-cost activities, employment, and employable skills
  • Provide nutritious, sustainable food for the community
  • Protect farmland from development
  • Provide low-barrier access to new farmers wishing to start a business
  • Educate the community about climate-friendly agriculture
  • Provide a space for the community to learn about and eat food, and connect with each other

What are we fundraising for?

Through a few years of working with farmers and community stakeholders in the food system, we learned that in Squamish, like many areas in Southwest BC, farmers experience barriers to producing food. Some of these barriers include: access to land, land affordability, knowledge gaps, etc. Food policy council staff and volunteers spent some time visiting and learning how community organizations are creatively addressing these complex barriers in the lower mainland. Community Farms are a great way to affect systemic change in the food system. 

We’ve learned first hand the positive impacts that gardening can have people through our Mamquam Edible Schoolyard and community gardens. Through the community farm, we plan to involve youth aged 13-18 in Squamish. The community farm will offer no-cost activity options, employment, and create opportunities for different generations to spend time together.


The community farm will have two main components. The CAN Farm aspect will be a market garden, where we will involve youth in the learning, growing, and selling produce to the community. In addition to the CAN Farm that we operate, we will lease several “incubator plots” that new farmers can lease for 1-4 years. This will help new farmers access land, without the significant financial investment and risk of buying their own property. There will be opportunities for these new farmers to share resources with the CAN Farm for tools, processing, storage, and sales. We will also facilitate a mentorship program to connect the new farmers to older farmers to address the gap in farming knowledge many new farmers have. The community farm will be open to the public to learn about sustainable agriculture practices, food preservation, celebrations, etc. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

Help us get the word out by posting about our campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc! Every post helps. 

*Thank you Nina Nichols for making our amazing campaign video! Music credit: "Farmer's Almanac" by Johnny Cash. 

*A huge thank you to Nina LaFlamme for the beautiful photos, vision, and dedication! We couldn't have done it without you! 

*Thank you to the farmers who enthusiastically agreed to be a part of our zany campaign idea! 

 

Thank you for your support!!!

A little more about Squamish Climate Action Network (CAN)

We are a community action group that operates many environmental projects in Squamish, British Columbia, Canada. We strive to educate, support, and empower the community of Squamish by developing, promoting, and implementing sustainable strategies to mitigate and adapt to climate change.

We run projects in the areas of Food, Energy, Transportation, and Waste. 

Food —Goal: Create a resilient food system

Projects:

  • Mamquam Edible Schoolyard
  • Three community gardens
  • Free food education workshops
  • Gardening workshops
  • Food Policy Council
  • Seed Library and Seedy Sunday
  • Farm to Table Fundraiser Dinner

Energy & Transportation —Goal: Reduce community energy consumption and dependency on fossil fuels.
Projects:

  • Eco Home Hop
  • Promoting green energy
  • Promoting active transportation

Waste —Goal: Achieve zero waste
Projects:

  • Zero Waste Action Team
  • Initiated curbside compost pickup
  • Curbside recycling audits
  • Annual Reuse it Fair-to date we have saved over 100 tonnes from the landfill

story:
My 20th birthday wish is to raise funds to do good.

Hello! I am Valerie.

August 14th is my birthday, and I'm going to become twenty this year. Twenty years old is a milestone for me, and it means I am no longer a teenager. I've always been passionate about social good, and I've decided that it's time I start to do good for the world.

This year, for my 20th birthday, I want to raise funds for four non-profit organizations which I really care about and believe in: Crossroads Foundation, Compassion in World Farming, Kiva and WaterisLife. 

So let me explain the four organizations I want to donate to.

The first is Crossroads Foundation, which does a lot of great work such as distributing donations of goods to people in need, and offering simulation experiences where participants can step briefly into the shoes of people facing global challenges.

The second is Compassion in World Farming, which works on farm animal welfare and campaigns peacefully on a global level to end all cruel factory farming practices of animals.

The third is Kiva, which connects people through lending to alleviate poverty, and uses the the internet and a worldwide network of microfinance institutions to allow people to lend as little as $25 to help create opportunity for others around the world. 

The fourth is WaterisLife, which provides clean drinking water, sanitation and hygiene education programs to those in desperate need. I really support two of their projects, which is the WaterisLife straw, and the Drinkable manual.

Below you can read the detailed description of what these organizations do and why I decided to raise funds for these four organizations. 

The Greatest Birthday Gift

This is the very first time I am using my birthday to do good and further causes that I am really passionate about.  I am excited, and nervous!

I really hope that as a birthday gift, you will help to donate to my campaign. I will be donating as well! Of all the donations I receive, I will personally donate 10% extra from my own pocket. My goal is to raise $1000 USD of donations, and I will donate $100 USD as well. All these will go towards helping the four non-profit organizations that I have mentioned above. 

I really hope you can help me achieve my birthday wish of raising funds to do good in the world. Thank you so much! 


Crossroads Foundation

https://www.crossroads.org.hk/

"Crossroads Foundation is a Hong Kong based non-profit organisation. Our goal is to connect people in a broken world. As our name suggests, we try to be a crossroads: bringing together those in need and those who can help. We do so in four ways.

Global Distribution: Where need meets resource

We are donated excellent quality goods by business and private donors. We distribute these to people in need, in Hong Kong and around the world. 

Global Hand: Partnering for a better world 

Global Hand is a match-making service which links for-profit and non-profit organisations who want to partner to help meet global need. 

Global X-perience: Stepping into another's shoes

We offer simulation x-periences in which participants step, briefly, ‘into the shoes’ of people facing global challenges: war, poverty, HIV vulnerability, blindness, environmental challenges, hunger, etc. 

Global Handicrafts: Fair trade for a fairer world 

Aid helps people today. An income helps them tomorrow. Global Handicrafts Marketplace sells goods from people in need within Hong Kong, and around the world, on a fair trade basis"

Why I want to donate to this organization 

When I was in Hong Kong, I first met the head of Crossroads Foundation, David Begbie, at a conference where he gave a very inspiring speech. Subsequently, I went to visit his organization and participate in their Global X-periences, namely the HIV/AIDS experience, the Blind Experience and Struggle for Survival. These were very impactful and I gained much more empathy for people who had HIV/AIDS, who suffered from river blindness, and who were in poverty. It motivated me to want to do more for these groups of people. I really feel that more people should go for these simulations that Crossroads conducts so that they will be able to increase in awareness and empathy for people in need. 

I also talked to David Begbie personally where he was very sincere and generous in giving advice. He is really great and so is his team at Crossroads Foundation who are all full-time volunteers. As such, I really want to support their efforts and enable them to do more.


Compassion in World Farming (CIWF)

http://www.ciwf.com/ 
"Today at Compassion in World Farming, we campaign peacefully on a global level, to end all cruel factory farming practices. We believe that the biggest cause of cruelty on the planet deserves a focused, specialized approach – so we only work on farm animal welfare.

Compassion USA is dedicated to reforming a broken food and farming system and introducing a more humane sustainable one.  Compassion believes ending factory farming must be a priority not just because of the impact on farm animals, but because of the negative impact on farmers and workers, our health, food security and the environment.

Compassion in World Farming’s Food Business Team is working with some of the world’s biggest food companies - retailers, producers and manufacturers. The companies we work with are a key part of the drive towards a more ethical and sustainable food supply. Our Good Farm Animal Welfare awards are already benefitting over 311 million animals throughout Europe. We are set to launch a US specific Good Farm Animal Welfare Awards in the near future."

Why I want to donate to this organization 

I am always shocked and appalled at the immense cruelty that many farm animals have to face. They live in squalid and cramped conditions with no freedom to move about, which is tragic because they are sentient beings capable of feeling pain and suffering, and they are not meant to be cooped up. I feel it's so horrible that they have to live a life full of so much misery and suffering, probably worse than anything humans have to face. I've done my best not to eat meat since I was five years old, but I really want to do much more about animal cruelty. I know it is hard for most people to give up meat, so I support what CIWF is doing by getting business to adopt ethical farming methods, and educating consumers about buying free-range meat. 


Kiva 

http://www.kiva.org/home

"We are a non-profit organization with a mission to connect people through lending to alleviate poverty. Leveraging the internet and a worldwide network of microfinance institutions, Kiva lets individuals lend as little as $25 to help create opportunity around the world.

We envision a world where all people - even in the most remote areas of the globe - hold the power to create opportunity for themselves and others.

We believe providing safe, affordable access to capital to those in need helps people create better lives for themselves and their families.

How to use Kiva

Make a loan

You make a loan on Kiva. All Kiva loans are made possible by our Field Partners, who vet, administer, and disburse each loan.

Get updates

Throughout the life of the loan, you will see progress updates from Kiva through your email, and if you come back to the site.

Get paid back

As the borrower repays the loan, the money becomes available in your account. This is called your Kiva Credit.

Repeat

You can now use it to fund another loan, donate it to Kiva, or withdraw it to spend on something else."

Why I want to donate to this organization 

I really like Kiva's model of microfinance, and feel that it's really good because I get to provide people with the capital required to make a living for themselves. It's also more personal because I get to read about the stories of individuals of other parts of the world and know what their situation is.  I think this helps increase my empathy and understanding of them, which will prompt me to do even more. A unique point about donating to Kiva is that I can get my loan back after the borrower repays the loan, which I can then use to loan to another person, so with many cycles of this, the money donated can actually go a long way to helping many people. 


WaterisLife

http://www.waterislife.com/ 

"WATERisLIFE is about impact. Showing donors and supporters how lives are being changed. WiL provides clean drinking water, sanitation and hygiene education programs to schools and villages to those in desperate need.  We provide opportunities for others to be involved through fundraising and field project implementation. The global water crisis can be daunting – at WATERisLIFE we focus on making impact – community by community. 

Through community driven and community engaged integrated water, sanitation and hygiene programs, WATERisLIFE works closely with non profit partners, local governments and community organizations to focus on an integrated approach to ensure that households, schools, orphanages, and medical facilities have access to safe water, proper sanitation and hygiene programs. The results of our work change everything. Hours are restored each day – women can use their time to learn a trade, start a business and receive an income. Children can receive an education. Clean water will reduce sickness by almost a third. Clean water saves and transforms lives, and communities."

Why I want to donate to this organization 

It is really a tragedy to me that clean water, which is so available and accessible for me, is something that close to a billion people do not have access to. The drinking of dirty or polluted water causes so many water-borne diseases such as river blindness, and diarrhea, which results in many deaths as well. All these illnesses could have been prevented if people had access to clean water or filtration devices. I really want to help WaterisLife to be able to provide clean water, sanitation and hygiene programs to those who lack them. WaterisLife provides a special Straw to people, which is a small, portable filtration device that filters out waterborne diseases and provides pure, clean drinking water whenever it is immersed into a water source. I think this is really great and innovative! I also think it's really cool that they are working on another product, the Drinkable Book, which is a life saving tool that filters water and teaches proper sanitation and hygiene to those in the developing world. You can find out more here: https://www.behance.net/gallery/16619527/The-Drinkable-Book?scid=social24105884


Why so many NGOs? Why not just choose one? 

That's because I am passionate about doing different kinds of good! There's not just one cause that I'm super passionate about, it's quite a few. I did do research and shortlisted from quite a number of NGOs to just these four which I feel promote values I think are important, are innovative, and represent causes which are most important to me. 
While I know it's much more effective for marketing and everything to just support one NGO, I feel like having these four NGOs to support is more reflective of who I am and what I am passionate about, which consists of more than one thing! 
To not support one of these NGOs would feel like I'm leaving out a part of who I am and what I believe in, for the sake of simplicity and a more unified story.
As you read more about these NGOs and why I chose to support them, I hope you will understand the value of these organisations and support them as well. (:

August 14th is my birthday, and I'm going
to become twenty this year. Twenty years old is a milestone for me, and it

world.

story:
Hi, we’re the Mono Lake Committee. You probably know us—we’re the group that saved the big salty lake with the strange rock towers in the Eastern Sierra from excessive water diversions to Los Angeles.

We’re at it again—this time the problem is that five years of drought have lowered Mono Lake seven feet, shrinking a protective moat of water around the lake’s islands, and putting one of the world’s largest nesting colonies of California Gulls in danger.

After all of the shoveling we've done this winter, we know it's hard to believe that we still need a fence. But we've run the numbers. Even if storms continue to cross the Sierra Nevada and drop much-needed snow in the Mono Basin watershed, the major lake rise from that meltwater will arrive in summer, long after the gulls need protection for the nesting season. 

Last summer biologists found signs that coyotes crossed the remaining 500 or so feet of shallow water to prey on eggs and chicks. Now that the coyotes know how to get out there, we have to do something to protect the gulls when they arrive to lay their eggs this year—in April.

Even with this winter turning unexpectedly wet, Mono Lake's wintertime rise will put the lake back around the same elevation as last year when coyotes crossed the moat. The problem is that now they know that there's easily-accessible food out there, and that it's worth crossing the moat.

To keep the gulls safe we’re putting up a temporary solar electric mesh-netting fence across the landbridge. We’ve consulted with coyote behavior experts and ranchers in the Mono Basin who agree that a fence is the best way to deter clever coyotes.

So, we’ve got the fence route, design, and permits lined up, and a gull biologist to put up the fence. The Mono Lake Committee stepped up and offered to pay for the fence materials in order to keep the project moving.

The fence materials cost $15,000. If we all chip in what we can, we can keep the gulls safe. If you can't help with cash, don't worry, you can still help. We need to get the word out about this fundraiser, so tell your family and friends, and share on the social media outlet of your choice, and together we can get the fence up in time!

Perks!

(now this is getting fun)

Your message on a fence post

  • We'll put your short message on an aluminum tag on a fence T-post—out there on the landbridge cautioning coyotes from approaching and wishing a safe and successful nesting season for the gulls (don't worry--it won't interfere with the fence or detach in the wind). We’ll email you to get your message, and once it’s up on the fence we’ll take a photo for you and send it to you via email and in the mail.

​Long Live the Gulls sticker

  • We made this limited-edition Mono Lake sticker just for the #LongLivetheGulls campaign. It’s the clear vinyl sticker in the shape of the outline of Mono Lake you’ve been waiting for ... complete with the fence route! The sticker measures approximately 4 x 4 inches and is printed on clear durable bumper-sticker vinyl. If we make these stickers again in the future, the landbridge will be gone ... so you've gotta get one now.

Gull band earrings

  • Earrings made with actual scientific bird bands used for gull research here at Mono Lake! A hot item in the Mono Lake Committee Bookstore, these earrings have stainless steel plated ear wires, and hang approximately 1.25 inches. They're the bird-nerdy-yet-elegant way to show your love of Mono Lake's California Gulls. Handmade by birding intern Erv Nichols.

 

Long Live the Gulls campaign mug

  • Wrap your hands around this satisfyingly beautiful Long Live the Gulls mug, and you'll feel good knowing you've helped to keep the gulls at Mono Lake safe. We're having a special run of these 16-oz handmade-in-the-USA café mugs made just for this campaign because they are so irresistible.

 

 

Gull-chasing-flies wine glasses

  • Have you seen a gull running through clouds of alkali flies snapping its bill? It's pretty excellent -- check out the footage at the end of our campaign video if you haven't. Second to seeing it yourself, is ... having it captured on a wineglass, of course. Scientific illustrator and former Committee staffer Logan Parsons, made this illustration just for us, and we don't sell these wine glasses in the store, so you can't really get these anywhere else. This 12.5 ounce wine glass is both sturdy and elegant, and makes a great conversation piece too. 

 

Other ways you can help

  • Tell a friend! You'd be surprised at how many people know about and love Mono Lake, and want to help protect it, let your people know what we're up to.
  • Want to help monitor the fence? Give us a call at 760-647-6595 and ask for Jessica.
  • There are tools to share the campaign right here from the Indiegogo site, or share this link: www.monolake.org/gullfence
  • Use #longlivethegulls in social media to help keep the momentum going.

Thank you!

(We're pretty sure the gulls thank you too.)

 

____________________________________________________________________________

For those who want to know more
about the gulls, the lake level,
and why we're putting up a fence

(we love you guys)

Three years ago we looked out at the growing landbridge and thought, "It's not good enough to just hope that the lake doesn't fall low enough for the coyotes to get back out to the gull colony." So, as California's drought continued, we began to plan for all scenarios. We started meeting with California State Parks and US Forest Service staff as well as Point Blue Conservation Science biologist Kristie Nelson in order to figure out the best protection options.

The solution we came up with is:

  • A fence that will be temporary and fully removable when the lake rises above the threshold of concern. It will also be removed for the fall and winter to avoid obstructing wildlife outside the nesting season.
  • It's a solar electrified mesh net fence that delivers a charge in pulses, not a continuous charge, of up to 14,000 volts (this looks like a big number but static electricity can be up to 25,000 volts). Each pulse lasts only 3/10,000 of a second.
  • The strands of the fence are black and white, making the fence highly visible to wildlife.
  • When an animal receives the unexpected shock, they establish a pain memory with the fence that makes them avoid the fence when they encounter it, and thus, the netting fence is both a physical and psychological barrier.
  • This same fence design (with a smaller electrical unit) has been used successfully to keep a bear from raiding beehives on a farm here in the Mono Basin.
  • Animals need to be in contact with the ground in order to get zapped, so birds can perch on the fence without getting a shock.
  • The California Department of Fish & Wildlife has determined that the fence won't harm other wildlife.

  • The fence will be installed on exposed lakebed so no vegetation or tufa formations will be disturbed.
  • The fence will run along the 6381-foot contour line on the eastern margin of Gaines Island (the island that becomes the landbridge when the lake is low, and disappears when the lake rises.)
  • There will be wildlife cameras on and around the fence to monitor activity.
  • The fence will be routinely monitored by local volunteers.
  • The islands are closed to the public between April 1 and August 1 to protect the nesting gulls, so the fence will not impact public access, and signs will be posted along the fence to warn the public that the fence is electrified.

____________________________________________________________________________

From the 2017 Winter/Spring Mono Lake Newsletter:

Epic winter lifts spirits but won’t raise Mono Lake in time for nesting season

by Geoffrey McQuilkin, Mono Lake Committee Executive Director

Five years of drought lowered Mono Lake seven feet, shrinking the protective moat of water between the lake’s north shore and Negit Island and adjacent islets that are home to one of the world’s largest nesting colonies of California Gulls. Last summer signs were found on several of these islets of coyotes crossing the remaining 500 or so feet of shallow water to prey on eggs and chicks.

Ultimately Mono Lake will rise, covering the landbridge and restoring the natural watery protection that the gulls have relied on for safety for centuries. But in the meantime, the Mono Lake Committee has been working with California State Parks, in consultation with the Department of Fish & Wildlife and US Forest Service, on a plan for a solar-powered electric mesh netting fence, similar to those used with livestock on ranches. The fence will be temporary and fully removable when the lake rises above the threshold of concern, and it will be removed for the fall and winter to avoid obstructing wildlife outside the nesting season.

Not enough water in the moat

Currently there is not enough water in the moat separating the gull colony from the landbridge to provide safety. When researchers found clear signs that coyotes had crossed to some of the islets last summer, Mono Lake stood at 6378.3 feet above sea level—only a few inches higher than the current lake level. Although the impact of the breach was limited, the concern is that knowledgeable coyotes are likely to return and use their experience to explore deeper into the colony.

Analysis to determine when a fence is needed requires a lot of careful examination of lake levels. As the lake has fallen during the drought, 6378 feet has been the “trigger” level for starting the project, representing a level at which island access is clearly possible and the cost and effort of mounting a fence project in response is worthwhile. The lake fell below 6378 feet in September 2016 and plans for fence construction moved to implementation as a result.

The construction trigger, however, is not the same as determining when the gull colony is naturally protected by the lake. With the winter turning unexpectedly wet, the Committee has begun to focus less on “when a fence is needed” and more on “when it is not needed.” At 6380 feet the moat grows wide enough and deep enough to serve as a natural deterrent to coyote access.

Thus the question we’ve been spending a lot of time analyzing (while the office has been buried under snow): How high will Mono Lake rise—and how fast?

Timing is everything

California Gulls arrive at Mono Lake during the waning days of winter and start building their nests and laying eggs in April. Gulls are consistent about this schedule pretty much regardless of weather conditions because they have an important deadline to beat: chicks need to hatch, grow, learn to fly, and be strong enough to head to the coast before the subsequent winter arrives.

In contrast, winter snows don’t usually melt enough to significantly raise Mono Lake’s level until around June. So even if storms continue to cross the Sierra Nevada and drop much-needed snow in the Mono Basin watershed, the major lake rise from that meltwater will arrive in summer, long after the gulls need protection for the nesting season.

Committee staff and experts have been forecasting lake level rise using four different scenarios that are updated monthly as winter precipitation stacks up. At press time the takeaway is this: Mono Lake is likely to rise to 6380 feet, but not until the first half of July. This matches the regular pattern and confirms that the fence is still needed this year.

Variations on the theme

Depending on how wet the remainder of the winter is, some variations on the main fence plan may be in order. For example, the planned route is designed to accommodate the lake level falling across the four months of the nesting season. Now that the reverse situation has arrived, with the lake expected to rise monthly through the spring and summer, the fence route could be adapted and possibly shortened.

Could upcoming storms make a difference?

Even with the above points in mind, it is reasonable to ask whether it is possible that the winter will end up so wet that a fence will not be necessary. After all, the snowpack was 200% of average on February 1 .

The answer is: it is highly unlikely. The drought has impacted Mono Lake and all of California heavily, and recovering from those impacts, particularly lake level decline, will take more than a single wet year. In the Committee’s lake level projections, the chance of an extraordinary end to the winter causing the lake to rise fast and high enough to eliminate the need for the fence is essentially zero.

We will continue to watch closely to see how the lake level forecast develops. Should an unprecedented rise become a reality we will gladly cheer the snow gods, celebrate Mono Lake’s rise, and put the fence plans on the shelf in case of a future drought. But analysis tells us the lake won’t rise in time to protect the gulls, and so the fence is needed. As a result the Committee and partners continue to advance the fence effort with implementation expected in March.

Why are gulls so important?

Since 1983 scientists have monitored Mono Lake’s California Gull (Larus californicus) breeding colony annually in order to measure the year-to-year variation in population size and reproductive success. The objectives of the study are to measure these parameters as they relate to changing lake and other environmental conditions. Three standardized procedures are conducted each year: in late May every nest is counted within the breeding colony to ascertain the population size; in early July all chicks within 10 study plots are banded, and in fall a mortality assessment of banded chicks is made. The California Gull population is an effective measurement of Mono Lake’s health. It has been found to be very strongly tied to certain lake conditions, and monitoring the gulls each year is an effective way to keep a vigilant eye on the lake environment. After 34 years of study, the information gained is not only valuable for the gulls and Mono Lake, but also because 34 years of data makes for uniquely long data set for any avian population.
story_txt:
Hi, we’re the Mono Lake Committee. You probably know us—we’re the group that saved the big salty lake with the strange rock towers in the Eastern Sierra from excessive water diversions to Los Angeles.

We’re at it again—this time the problem is that five years of drought have lowered Mono Lake seven feet, shrinking a protective moat of water around the lake’s islands, and putting one of the world’s largest nesting colonies of California Gulls in danger.

After all of the shoveling we've done this winter, we know it's hard to believe that we still need a fence. But we've run the numbers. Even if storms continue to cross the Sierra Nevada and drop much-needed snow in the Mono Basin watershed, the major lake rise from that meltwater will arrive in summer, long after the gulls need protection for the nesting season. 

Last summer biologists found signs that coyotes crossed the remaining 500 or so feet of shallow water to prey on eggs and chicks. Now that the coyotes know how to get out there, we have to do something to protect the gulls when they arrive to lay their eggs this year—in April.

Even with this winter turning unexpectedly wet, Mono Lake's wintertime rise will put the lake back around the same elevation as last year when coyotes crossed the moat. The problem is that now they know that there's easily-accessible food out there, and that it's worth crossing the moat.

To keep the gulls safe we’re putting up a temporary solar electric mesh-netting fence across the landbridge. We’ve consulted with coyote behavior experts and ranchers in the Mono Basin who agree that a fence is the best way to deter clever coyotes.

So, we’ve got the fence route, design, and permits lined up, and a gull biologist to put up the fence. The Mono Lake Committee stepped up and offered to pay for the fence materials in order to keep the project moving.

The fence materials cost $15,000. If we all chip in what we can, we can keep the gulls safe. If you can't help with cash, don't worry, you can still help. We need to get the word out about this fundraiser, so tell your family and friends, and share on the social media outlet of your choice, and together we can get the fence up in time!
Perks!
(now this is getting fun)

Your message on a fence post
We'll put your short message on an aluminum tag on a fence T-post—out there on the landbridge cautioning coyotes from approaching and wishing a safe and successful nesting season for the gulls (don't worry--it won't interfere with the fence or detach in the wind). We’ll email you to get your message, and once it’s up on the fence we’ll take a photo for you and send it to you via email and in the mail.

​Long Live the Gulls sticker
We made this limited-edition Mono Lake sticker just for the #LongLivetheGulls campaign. It’s the clear vinyl sticker in the shape of the outline of Mono Lake you’ve been waiting for ... complete with the fence route! The sticker measures approximately 4 x 4 inches and is printed on clear durable bumper-sticker vinyl. If we make these stickers again in the future, the landbridge will be gone ... so you've gotta get one now.
Gull band earrings
Earrings made with actual scientific bird bands used for gull research here at Mono Lake! A hot item in the Mono Lake Committee Bookstore, these earrings have stainless steel plated ear wires, and hang approximately 1.25 inches. They're the bird-nerdy-yet-elegant way to show your love of Mono Lake's California Gulls. Handmade by birding intern Erv Nichols.
 
Long Live the Gulls campaign mug
Wrap your hands around this satisfyingly beautiful Long Live the Gulls mug, and you'll feel good knowing you've helped to keep the gulls at Mono Lake safe. We're having a special run of these 16-oz handmade-in-the-USA café mugs made just for this campaign because they are so irresistible.
 
 
Gull-chasing-flies wine glasses
Have you seen a gull running through clouds of alkali flies snapping its bill? It's pretty excellent -- check out the footage at the end of our campaign video if you haven't. Second to seeing it yourself, is ... having it captured on a wineglass, of course. Scientific illustrator and former Committee staffer Logan Parsons, made this illustration just for us, and we don't sell these wine glasses in the store, so you can't really get these anywhere else. This 12.5 ounce wine glass is both sturdy and elegant, and makes a great conversation piece too. 
 
Other ways you can help

Tell a friend! You'd be surprised at how many people know about and love Mono Lake, and want to help protect it, let your people know what we're up to.
Want to help monitor the fence? Give us a call at 760-647-6595 and ask for Jessica.
There are tools to share the campaign right here from the Indiegogo site, or share this link: www.monolake.org/gullfence

Use #longlivethegulls in social media to help keep the momentum going.

Thank you!
(We're pretty sure the gulls thank you too.)
 
____________________________________________________________________________
For those who want to know moreabout the gulls, the lake level,and why we're putting up a fence
(we love you guys)


Three years ago we looked out at the growing landbridge and thought, "It's not good enough to just hope that the lake doesn't fall low enough for the coyotes to get back out to the gull colony." So, as California's drought continued, we began to plan for all scenarios. We started meeting with California State Parks and US Forest Service staff as well as Point Blue Conservation Science biologist Kristie Nelson in order to figure out the best protection options.
The solution we came up with is:

A fence that will be temporary and fully removable when the lake rises above the threshold of concern. It will also be removed for the fall and winter to avoid obstructing wildlife outside the nesting season.
It's a solar electrified mesh net fence that delivers a charge in pulses, not a continuous charge, of up to 14,000 volts (this looks like a big number but static electricity can be up to 25,000 volts). Each pulse lasts only 3/10,000 of a second.
The strands of the fence are black and white, making the fence highly visible to wildlife.
When an animal receives the unexpected shock, they establish a pain memory with the fence that makes them avoid the fence when they encounter it, and thus, the netting fence is both a physical and psychological barrier.
This same fence design (with a smaller electrical unit) has been used successfully to keep a bear from raiding beehives on a farm here in the Mono Basin.
Animals need to be in contact with the ground in order to get zapped, so birds can perch on the fence without getting a shock.
The California Department of Fish & Wildlife has determined that the fence won't harm other wildlife.



The fence will be installed on exposed lakebed so no vegetation or tufa formations will be disturbed.
The fence will run along the 6381-foot contour line on the eastern margin of Gaines Island (the island that becomes the landbridge when the lake is low, and disappears when the lake rises.)
There will be wildlife cameras on and around the fence to monitor activity.
The fence will be routinely monitored by local volunteers.
The islands are closed to the public between April 1 and August 1 to protect the nesting gulls, so the fence will not impact public access, and signs will be posted along the fence to warn the public that the fence is electrified.

____________________________________________________________________________
From the 2017 Winter/Spring Mono Lake Newsletter:
Epic winter lifts spirits but won’t raise Mono Lake in time for nesting season
by Geoffrey McQuilkin, Mono Lake Committee Executive Director

Five years of drought lowered Mono Lake seven feet, shrinking the protective moat of water between the lake’s north shore and Negit Island and adjacent islets that are home to one of the world’s largest nesting colonies of California Gulls. Last summer signs were found on several of these islets of coyotes crossing the remaining 500 or so feet of shallow water to prey on eggs and chicks.
Ultimately Mono Lake will rise, covering the landbridge and restoring the natural watery protection that the gulls have relied on for safety for centuries. But in the meantime, the Mono Lake Committee has been working with California State Parks, in consultation with the Department of Fish & Wildlife and US Forest Service, on a plan for a solar-powered electric mesh netting fence, similar to those used with livestock on ranches. The fence will be temporary and fully removable when the lake rises above the threshold of concern, and it will be removed for the fall and winter to avoid obstructing wildlife outside the nesting season.
Not enough water in the moat
Currently there is not enough water in the moat separating the gull colony from the landbridge to provide safety. When researchers found clear signs that coyotes had crossed to some of the islets last summer, Mono Lake stood at 6378.3 feet above sea level—only a few inches higher than the current lake level. Although the impact of the breach was limited, the concern is that knowledgeable coyotes are likely to return and use their experience to explore deeper into the colony.
Analysis to determine when a fence is needed requires a lot of careful examination of lake levels. As the lake has fallen during the drought, 6378 feet has been the “trigger” level for starting the project, representing a level at which island access is clearly possible and the cost and effort of mounting a fence project in response is worthwhile. The lake fell below 6378 feet in September 2016 and plans for fence construction moved to implementation as a result.
The construction trigger, however, is not the same as determining when the gull colony is naturally protected by the lake. With the winter turning unexpectedly wet, the Committee has begun to focus less on “when a fence is needed” and more on “when it is not needed.” At 6380 feet the moat grows wide enough and deep enough to serve as a natural deterrent to coyote access.
Thus the question we’ve been spending a lot of time analyzing (while the office has been buried under snow): How high will Mono Lake rise—and how fast?
Timing is everything
California Gulls arrive at Mono Lake during the waning days of winter and start building their nests and laying eggs in April. Gulls are consistent about this schedule pretty much regardless of weather conditions because they have an important deadline to beat: chicks need to hatch, grow, learn to fly, and be strong enough to head to the coast before the subsequent winter arrives.
In contrast, winter snows don’t usually melt enough to significantly raise Mono Lake’s level until around June. So even if storms continue to cross the Sierra Nevada and drop much-needed snow in the Mono Basin watershed, the major lake rise from that meltwater will arrive in summer, long after the gulls need protection for the nesting season.
Committee staff and experts have been forecasting lake level rise using four different scenarios that are updated monthly as winter precipitation stacks up. At press time the takeaway is this: Mono Lake is likely to rise to 6380 feet, but not until the first half of July. This matches the regular pattern and confirms that the fence is still needed this year.
Variations on the theme
Depending on how wet the remainder of the winter is, some variations on the main fence plan may be in order. For example, the planned route is designed to accommodate the lake level falling across the four months of the nesting season. Now that the reverse situation has arrived, with the lake expected to rise monthly through the spring and summer, the fence route could be adapted and possibly shortened.
Could upcoming storms make a difference?
Even with the above points in mind, it is reasonable to ask whether it is possible that the winter will end up so wet that a fence will not be necessary. After all, the snowpack was 200% of average on February 1 .
The answer is: it is highly unlikely. The drought has impacted Mono Lake and all of California heavily, and recovering from those impacts, particularly lake level decline, will take more than a single wet year. In the Committee’s lake level projections, the chance of an extraordinary end to the winter causing the lake to rise fast and high enough to eliminate the need for the fence is essentially zero.
We will continue to watch closely to see how the lake level forecast develops. Should an unprecedented rise become a reality we will gladly cheer the snow gods, celebrate Mono Lake’s rise, and put the fence plans on the shelf in case of a future drought. But analysis tells us the lake won’t rise in time to protect the gulls, and so the fence is needed. As a result the Committee and partners continue to advance the fence effort with implementation expected in March.

Why are gulls so important?
Since 1983 scientists have monitored Mono Lake’s California Gull (Larus californicus) breeding colony annually in order to measure the year-to-year variation in population size and reproductive success. The objectives of the study are to measure these parameters as they relate to changing lake and other environmental conditions. Three standardized procedures are conducted each year: in late May every nest is counted within the breeding colony to ascertain the population size; in early July all chicks within 10 study plots are banded, and in fall a mortality assessment of banded chicks is made. The California Gull population is an effective measurement of Mono Lake’s health. It has been found to be very strongly tied to certain lake conditions, and monitoring the gulls each year is an effective way to keep a vigilant eye on the lake environment. After 34 years of study, the information gained is not only valuable for the gulls and Mono Lake, but also because 34 years of data makes for uniquely long data set for any avian population.

story:
Follow the story and our continued progress HERE! 


Video by: Lindsay Daniels 


A video series profiling rural mountain communities that are fighting poverty through ecotourism: 

The Pamir's traditional obstacle to prosperity has been its extreme mountain landscape. Now, these same mountains are being used to create sustainable opportunities for the people that live here.

Why are you making this video series?

These videos will serve as powerful tools that

  1. Teach international travelers about how their decisions impact the environments and the people living in the destinations they visit.  
  2. Help development organizations like PECTA, the AKDN, and others to promote the Pamir as the unparalleled adventure destination that it is. 

Photo Credit: Veronica Bastian


What can I expect from the videos?

Besides showcasing the Pamir's stunning and untouched landscapes, each video will help the world to see how extremely warm and friendly the people of Tajikistan are. 

These inspiring videos will explain how the Pamiri people aren't confronting poverty just by using tourism to turn a quick profit, but that they are thinking long-term, and taking bold steps to introduce tourism in a way that includes the local population and protects the fragile alpine ecosystems they depend upon. 

 

Infographic by: Allie Rae Saraiva

Why Adventure Tourism?

Many people have asked, “Why adventure tourism? Wouldn’t agriculture or manufacturing be more feasible and sustainable?” In any other part of the world, perhaps yes. But 93% of Tajikistan is covered in ginormous mountains. This presents two problems:

  1. There is limited land for agriculture uses.
  2. Exporting manufactured or agricultural goods is incredibly expensive because of, you guessed it, the mountains. 


Video and illustrations by: Ryan Bastian

Adventure tourism takes what has been an economic barrier for these people and turns it into an advantage. With the third highest mountain range in the world, no shortage of beautiful landscapes and scenery, and kind-hearted locals, the Pamir is an unparalleled destination for foreigners looking for unforgettable experiences. 


Will adventure tourism in the Pamir be sustainable? 

This is exactly why telling this story is so important. The more travelers visiting the Pamir understand about ecotourism and the importance of choosing environmentally responsible guides and lodging, the better the region's natural resources and long-term economic value can be protected. 

We are planning several profiles in these videos to feature staff members and guides associated with the Pamir Eco-Cultural Tourism Association (PECTA) and the Mountain Society Development Support Programme (MSDSP).  


Thanks to the hard work of organizations like PECTA and MSDSP, Tajikistan's High Pamir - Bartang and Wakhan Valleys were recognized in the top 100 most sustainable global destinations:  http://greendestinations.info/top100/


How are local Pamiris getting involved? 

A journalistic piece by Adam Valen Levinson.


Can I get some more details about what I can expect from this video series?

The underlying storyline will be centered on sustainability efforts made by the ecotourism sector within the local adventure industry. 

Because we want to give the Pamiri people a voice with these videos, the story will be told by profiling local individuals in the tourism sector that are pursuing better livelihoods for their families while, at the same time, helping establish environmental standards for the long-term good of their homeland.  


Photo Credit: Ryan Bastian

This series will feature the immense beauty of the Pamir's landscape, while exploring its capacity for world-class climbing and off-the-beaten-trail adventure.

We will focus on how these people will be affected for good/bad depending on the environmental sustainability measures that do/don’t become standard operating procedure in the Tajik tourism industry. 

Photo Credit: Oleg Gregoriev

The character of the Pamiri people and their culture will also be depicted: their warmth, friendliness, and hospitality; as well as other unique characteristics (e.g. value and emphasis on education, progressive views regarding gender equality, etc.).

What is your distribution plan? 

Besides making them available for use by organizations like AKDN, PECTA, MSDSP, and local Pamiri tour operators, we will promote these pieces on our website, Facebook, YouTube; aim for staff-pick features on Vimeo; etc. 

Photo Credit: Veronica Bastian

What are the risks and challenges?

Since Magic 8 balls are only so effective at accurately predicting the future, we can only assume there will be hiccups on the way to finishing these videos. These could include, but aren’t limited to:

  • Getting permits and government approval for filming in-country.
  • Entrance into the country with drone and other video equipment. 
  • Political unrest while in country that could cancel filming.
  • Unpredictable dust storms blowing north from Afghanistan damaging equipment. 


Photo Credit: Veronica Bastian


How can I help?

Just because you can’t give financially doesn’t mean you can’t be a part of this; sharing is priceless! Post the campaign on social media or reach out to friends and family who would be interested in social impact or outdoor adventure travel. We know with your help we can do this and change the lives of the Pamiri people!

If you can contribute, every little bit helps to raise the $5,000 to produce this video series. That, in combination with money from Ryan's own pocket, will help cover travel, boarding, and food, as well as some minor needed equipment. 

This campaign is “fixed,” which means we either meet our goal or we get nothing. This strategy is risky, but it allows us to keep more of the money we raise—and every cent will be needed to pull this off. In exchange for your help, we've done our best to put together some fantastic perks. Check them out!



I still have some unanswered questions...

Feel free to post a question to our Facebook page! We will answer it as promptly as we can.

Big thanks to our sponsors! 

And thanks to everyone for your support!

Video/Photo Credits: 

Oleg Grigoriev (http://grigoryev.net/)
Veronica Bastian (http://veronicabastian.com/)
Lindsay Daniels (http://www.lindsaydanielsphotography.com/)

Adam Valen Levinson (http://www.brosettastone.tv/)

Stef Hoffer


Our stretch goal of $7,200 & Kyrgyzstan! 

We are expanding our project's coverage to Tajikistan's neighbor to the north, Kyrgyzstan! 

This coverage will shed light on how ecotourism can be used by remote mountain communities to build economic opportunities and protect their environments.


Why Kyrgyzstan?

The Kyrgyz adventure tourism industry is much older and larger than that of Tajikistan, yet it still shares many of the same challenges and opportunities. 

Photo Credit: Andy Isaacson

A tremendous amount of insight can be gained by examining both the positive and negative consequences of adventure tourism in Kyrgyzstan, as well as by exploring the cause of these varying outcomes. 

We need you! Please keep sharing the campaign!

When looking to the future of Tajikistan's tourism industry in the Pamir, it's extremely important to consider tourism's successes and failures in Kyrgyzstan, as well as the lessons learned therefrom.
