story:
First promotional video complete!

Thanks to you all, and to additional support from a Taking Root partner, we've been able finish the first Taking Root video. It took us many long hours, but we're very happy with the result. Please take a look:


We're in the closing hours! Help us make that final push!

Here are a few photos that I took during our visit to Nicaragua. Visit www.chrishenschel.com to see more! Tell your friends, tell your family! These are the final hours, help us get as much finding as possible so we can start to tell the amazing story that is Taking Root!

-Chris

 

 

Campaign Update: The Gorda Draw!


While strolling through the town of San Juan de Limay, we came across some women baking pastries in their outdoor wood oven. We asked if we could film them working and they graciously invited us into their home. Inside, we discovered an incredible collection of stone carvings that they sell as another form of income.

One such carving is the ‘Gorda’. She’s a cultural icon here in Limay, where the voluptuous is admired and celebrated. There are many of these ladies overlooking the road from Esteli to Limay as well as throughout the town here. Each statue represents and promotes an activity or cultural aspect of Limay. Some are holding a child, or flowers, and there’s even one making some tortillas. The statues around town are quite large whereas the one we bought is only about 5 inches tall.

For our campaign we would like to do a draw for this little statuette that we purchased from the ladies. For every $25 donated, you’ll be entered to win this little beauty. Furthermore, for every referral that generates a donation, you’ll be entered again! Be sure to leave us a comment if anyone you've referred makes or has made a donation. Best of luck to everyone!

Pour le texte en français, voire en dessus.

What's this campaign about?

Hi there! We're a Montreal-based non-profit called Taking Root that develops social reforestation projects in Nicaragua. This means we collaborate with small-scale farmers to help them reforest unused parts of their land. Our aim is to use reforestation as a tool to restore ecosystems, improve livelihoods, and tackle climate change. Pretty great stuff, right?

In the last five years, our project has worked with hundreds of subsistence farmers to plant over 500,000 trees. This coming summer, we'll be working with these farmers to plant yet another 400,000 trees! But in order for this project to succeed and keep growing, we need to show the world the value of what we do through images.

That's why, for this campaign, we're raising funds to create a series of educational videos about our project. We'd like to capture footage during our upcoming planting season to bring awareness to the benefits of social reforestation and generate support for the project in the future.

What do we need your support for?

This summer will be the project's biggest planting season ever, so we need to document this incredible milestone and demonstrate the passion that the entire community puts into the reforestation efforts.

However, creating a successful, comprehensive and informative video is no easy feat.  Your contributions will help cover the cost of a trip (flight, lodging, transportation) to Nicaragua for our very talented photographer and documentarian. They will also cover the editing and production costs of putting together high-quality videos with all of this great footage after the trip.

 

With this, we'll create a series of great, educational videos to capture the essence of this beautiful project, and promote the equitable approach that our organization has to reforestation. We'll also highlight some of the new innovative aspects of the project that are going on right now, like building fuel-efficient cookstoves and using biochar in agriculture, so that we can get much needed support for these initiatives in the future.

What are we offering in return?

In exchange for your invaluabe support, we're offering the great perks that you see to the right. These include sending you postcards and haikus from the trip, fantastic photos that were taken on the trip, and actually planting trees in your honour while we're there.

 

We're also offering producer and executive producer status, which will give you and/or your company visibility with every video we create and share. There's even an option to have personalized versions of the videos created for you that emphasize your valuable role in supporting these projects. Please contact us for more details.

 

We'll make this initiative work one way or another even if we don't reach our funding goal. However, the more funds we receive, the more energy we can invest in doing a really great job and producing an excellent series of videos.

Why support this cause?

Poverty, deforestation and climat change

Deforestation accounts for around 17% of global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, which is more than the entire global transportation sector. CO2 is the primary gas leading to human-caused climate change, and we're already feeling the impacts of this global issue. Yet it is the world's poorest countries, lacking the resources to adapt and fight the impacts of climate change, which are feeling the impacts the worst. We have now reached a tipping point and we need, more than ever, to take action!

 

Taking Root's community-based initiative provides a key solution to this global problem, while also addressing issues of local poverty in Nicaragua. We're asking for your support because together we have the power to create a better world that we are proud to hand down to the next generation. As ambassadors, we can spread the word!

Why Nicaragua?

Nicaragua is the second poorest country in the Americas, and has a long history of political turmoil and poor environmental management. As a result, there is a great need for social reforestation – where community members are directly involved in the decision making process and are paid for the work that they do.

 

Also, because of the year-round tropical climate, trees grow at least 10 times faster closer to the equator than they do in Canada. This means that they are ten times more effective at sequestering carbon, releasing oxygen, restoring nutrients to the soil, helping retain humidity and much more!

 

You can find out more about our organization and our social reforestation project on our website: www.takingroot.org

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone has the funds to contribute. So if you want to help out in other ways, please help us spread the word, using the Indiegogo share tools on this page. The more we raise, the more trees we plant, and the better equipped we'll be to tell the story of this great project.

 

Thanks so much!

 

Above drawings by Chris Henschel, 2012.

À propos de cette campagne

Bonjour! Nous sommes les membres de l’équipe d’EnRacince, un organisme à but non lucratif basé à Montréal (Canada) qui développe des projets de reforestation sociale au Nicaragua. Ceci veut dire que nous collaborons avec de petits agriculteurs afin de reboiser les portions sous-utilisées de leurs terres. Nous nous sommes donné pour mission de recourir à la reforestation pour restaurer les écosystèmes, améliorer la qualité de vie et freiner les changements climatiques. Un travail fantastique, n’est-ce pas?

Le travail d’EnRacine

Au cours des cinq dernières années, des centaines de petits agriculteurs ont travaillé au sein de notre projet et ont planté plus de 500 000 arbres. Cet été, nous travaillerons avec ces agriculteurs pour planter 400 000 arbres de plus! Pour que ce projet fonctionne et prenne de l’expansion, nous devons toutefois montrer au monde à l’aide d’images la nécessité de ce que nous faisons.

Nous amassons des fonds pour réaliser une série de vidéos de grande qualité. Au cours de notre saison de reboisement à venir, nous aimerions capturer des images qui montreront les retombées à la fois locales et mondiales de la reforestation sociale, et qui assureront un soutien futur pour le projet.

Pourquoi avons-nous besoin de votre soutien?

Réaliser une vidéo informative, complète et réussie n’est pas chose facile. Vos dons nous aideront à couvrir les frais de voyage au Nicaragua (vols, hébergement et transport sur place) de notre très talentueux photographe-documentariste. De retour de voyage, ces dons couvriront également les frais de montage et de production, ce qui nous permettra de transformer les merveilleuses séquences de tournage en vidéos de haute qualité.

Avec ce matériel, nous produirons une série de vidéos éducatives et dynamiques, qui nous permettront de capter l’essence même de ce beau projet et de promouvoir l’approche de reboisement équitable déployée par notre organisation. Nous mettrons également l’accent sur certains des aspects novateurs du projet qui sont en cours de réalisation, comme la construction de fours écoénergétiques et l’utilisation du biocharbon en agriculture. De cette manière, nous pourrons obtenir le futur soutien essentiel à ces initiatives.

Que proposons-nous en retour?

En retour, vous pouvez choisir parmi la sélection de récompenses amusantes que vous voyez à droite. Celles-ci comprennent l’envoi de cartes postales et de haïkus vous étant destinés durant le voyage, de fantastiques photos prises lors de celui-ci et la plantation d’arbres en votre honneur.

Nous vous offrons également la possibilité de jouer le rôle de producteur ou de producteur délégué, ce qui confère à votre nom ou à celui de votre entreprise une certaine visibilité puisqu’il apparaîtra sur chaque exemplaire de la vidéo que nous réalisons et distribuons. Il est même possible d’obtenir des versions personnalisées de la vidéo réalisées à votre attention, qui mettent l’accent sur le rôle essentiel que vous jouez en soutenant ces projets. Veuillez communiquer avec nous pour plus de détails.

D’une manière ou d’une autre, nous ferons en sorte que cette initiative porte ses fruits, même si nous n’atteignons pas l’objectif de financement que nous nous sommes fixé. Toutefois, plus nous recevrons de dons, plus nous pourrons investir d’énergie pour faire un très bon travail et ainsi réaliser une excellente série de vidéos.

Pourquoi soutenir cette cause?

Pauvreté, déforestation et changements climatiques

La destruction des forêts, qui a surtout lieu en régions tropicales, est responsable de 12 à 17 % des émissions mondiales de CO2, soit le gaz à effet de serre contribuant le plus aux changements climatiques. Cela représente une quantité presque semblable aux émissions générées pendant un an par l’ensemble des voitures, camions, bateaux et avions de la planète. Nous ressentons déjà tous les impacts de cette problématique mondiale. Ce sont toutefois les pays les plus pauvres de la planète, ceux qui n’ont pas les ressources nécessaires pour combattre les changements climatiques et s’adapter à leurs conséquences, qui subissent les pires impacts. Nous avons maintenant atteint un point de basculement et il est plus que jamais nécessaire de passer à l’action!

L’initiative communautaire d’EnRacine offre une solution à ce problème mondial, tout en s’attaquant aux problèmes découlant de la pauvreté locale au Nicaragua. Nous sollicitons votre appui parce qu’ensemble, nous avons la capacité de créer un monde meilleur que nous serons fiers de léguer aux prochaines générations. À titre d’ambassadeurs, nous pouvons faire passer le mot!

Pourquoi le Nicaragua?

Le Nicaragua est le pays le plus pauvre d’Amérique centrale et le second plus pauvre pays des Amériques après Haïti. Il possède en outre une longue histoire d’agitations politiques et de piètre gestion environnementale. En conséquence, il y a un besoin criant pour la reforestation sociale – où les membres de la communauté prennent directement part au processus décisionnel et sont rémunérés pour le travail qu’ils effectuent.

De plus, en raison du climat tropical, les arbres situés dans la zone équatoriale peuvent croître jusqu’à dix fois plus rapidement que ceux retrouvés sous les climats nordiques. Cela signifie que les retombées de notre projet en matière de séquestration du carbone, de production d’oxygène, de restauration des nutriments des sols, de rétention d’humidité et plus encore sont optimisées!

Vous trouverez plus de détails concernant notre organisation et notre projet de reforestation sociale sur notre site web : www.enracine.org

D’autres moyens de nous aider

Nous savons que tous n’ont pas les moyens financiers de nous aider. Ainsi, si vous désirez nous soutenir d’autres manières, aidez-nous à faire connaître notre travail en vous servant des outils de partage offerts par Indiegogo sur cette page. Plus nous amassons de fonds, plus nous planterons d’arbres et plus nous serons outillés pour raconter l’histoire de ce merveilleux projet.

Merci mille fois !

Illustrations ci-dessus par Chris Hanschel, 2012.

First promotional video complete!Thanks to you all, and to additional support from a Taking Root partner, we've been able finish the first Taking Root video. It took us many long hours, but we're very happy with the result. Please take a look:We're in the closing hours! Help us make that final push!
Here are a few photos that I took during our visit to Nicaragua. Visit www.chrishenschel.com to see more! Tell your friends, tell your family! These are the final hours, help us get as much finding as possible so we can start to tell the amazing story that is Taking Root!
-Chris





 
 
Campaign Update: The Gorda Draw!
While strolling through the town of San Juan de Limay, we came across some women baking pastries in their outdoor wood oven. We asked if we could film them working and they graciously invited us into their home. Inside, we discovered an incredible collection of stone carvings that they sell as another form of income.
One such carving is the ‘Gorda’. She’s a cultural icon here in Limay, where the voluptuous is admired and celebrated. There are many of these ladies overlooking the road from Esteli to Limay as well as throughout the town here. Each statue represents and promotes an activity or cultural aspect of Limay. Some are holding a child, or flowers, and there’s even one making some tortillas. The statues around town are quite large whereas the one we bought is only about 5 inches tall.

For our campaign we would like to do a draw for this little statuette that we purchased from the ladies. For every $25 donated, you’ll be entered to win this little beauty. Furthermore, for every referral that generates a donation, you’ll be entered again! Be sure to leave us a comment if anyone you've referred makes or has made a donation. Best of luck to everyone!
Pour le texte en français, voire en dessus.
What's this campaign about?
Hi there! We're a Montreal-based non-profit called Taking Root that develops social reforestation projects in Nicaragua. This means we collaborate with small-scale farmers to help them reforest unused parts of their land. Our aim is to use reforestation as a tool to restore ecosystems, improve livelihoods, and tackle climate change. Pretty great stuff, right? In the last five years, our project has worked with hundreds of subsistence farmers to plant over 500,000 trees. This coming summer, we'll be working with these farmers to plant yet another 400,000 trees! But in order for this project to succeed and keep growing, we need to show the world the value of what we do through images.That's why, for this campaign, we're raising funds to create a series of educational videos about our project. We'd like to capture footage during our upcoming planting season to bring awareness to the benefits of social reforestation and generate support for the project in the future.

What do we need your support for?

This summer will be the project's biggest planting season ever, so we need to document this incredible milestone and demonstrate the passion that the entire community puts into the reforestation efforts.However, creating a successful, comprehensive and informative video is no easy feat.  Your contributions will help cover the cost of a trip (flight, lodging, transportation) to Nicaragua for our very talented photographer and documentarian. They will also cover the editing and production costs of putting together high-quality videos with all of this great footage after the trip.
 
With this, we'll create a series of great, educational videos to capture the essence of this beautiful project, and promote the equitable approach that our organization has to reforestation. We'll also highlight some of the new innovative aspects of the project that are going on right now, like building fuel-efficient cookstoves and using biochar in agriculture, so that we can get much needed support for these initiatives in the future.


What are we offering in return?

In exchange for your invaluabe support, we're offering the great perks that you see to the right. These include sending you postcards and haikus from the trip, fantastic photos that were taken on the trip, and actually planting trees in your honour while we're there.
 
We're also offering producer and executive producer status, which will give you and/or your company visibility with every video we create and share. There's even an option to have personalized versions of the videos created for you that emphasize your valuable role in supporting these projects. Please contact us for more details.
 
We'll make this initiative work one way or another even if we don't reach our funding goal. However, the more funds we receive, the more energy we can invest in doing a really great job and producing an excellent series of videos.
Why support this cause?
Poverty, deforestation and climat change
Deforestation accounts for around 17% of global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, which is more than the entire global transportation sector. CO2 is the primary gas leading to human-caused climate change, and we're already feeling the impacts of this global issue. Yet it is the world's poorest countries, lacking the resources to adapt and fight the impacts of climate change, which are feeling the impacts the worst. We have now reached a tipping point and we need, more than ever, to take action!
 
Taking Root's community-based initiative provides a key solution to this global problem, while also addressing issues of local poverty in Nicaragua. We're asking for your support because together we have the power to create a better world that we are proud to hand down to the next generation. As ambassadors, we can spread the word!
Why Nicaragua?
Nicaragua is the second poorest country in the Americas, and has a long history of political turmoil and poor environmental management. As a result, there is a great need for social reforestation – where community members are directly involved in the decision making process and are paid for the work that they do.
 
Also, because of the year-round tropical climate, trees grow at least 10 times faster closer to the equator than they do in Canada. This means that they are ten times more effective at sequestering carbon, releasing oxygen, restoring nutrients to the soil, helping retain humidity and much more!
 
You can find out more about our organization and our social reforestation project on our website: www.takingroot.org

Other Ways You Can Help
We know that not everyone has the funds to contribute. So if you want to help out in other ways, please help us spread the word, using the Indiegogo share tools on this page. The more we raise, the more trees we plant, and the better equipped we'll be to tell the story of this great project.
 
Thanks so much!

 
Above drawings by Chris Henschel, 2012.

story:
The  new  Front-­‐line  –  Jamaica  is  one  of  40  countries  facing  the  greatest  impact  from   Climate  Change  -­‐United  Nations  (UNU-­‐EHS)  

Walking  to  celebrate  and  discover  the  abundant  ecology,  meet  and  hear  the  stories  from  a  people  that   created  a  nation  with  a  philosophy  of  ‘Out  of  Many  One  People’  and  ‘One  Love’.  To  also  explore  the   creativity  of  this  extraordinary  Island.  Jamaica’s  journey  from  slavery  and  economic  exploitation  has   created  a  resilient  and  resourceful  people,  many  of  whom  are  notable  on  the  world  stage  but  now  the   Jamaican  people  face  one  of  their  biggest  challenges  yet  -­‐  Climate  Change

 Legacy:- To raise awareness and create connections along the central agricultural spine of Jamaica. Linking village to town andperson to person. The route to the Tourist Enhancement Fund, environmental agencies and investment opportunities - Laying a trail for the One Love walk - a legacy for earth rights walking a global impact movement.


There  is  a  special  quality  to  the  nature  of  Jamaica,  which  is  unique  within  the  Caribbean,  a  small   Island  with  enormous  biodiversity.  Many  endemic  creatures  live  on  the  Island  and  anything  grows  in   the  rich  and  diverse  soils.  This  needs  recognition,  consideration  and  then  action  to  protect  it  from   exploitation.  Jamaica  was  once  built  on  a  foundation  of  ONE  LOVE  -­‐  BUT  has  this  now  become   nothing  more  than  a  brand?  We  want  to  explore  this  through  walk,  talk  and  stories,  capturing  the   true  currency  of  Jamaica to map the future.


I  believe  that  the  future  success  of  this  BIG  little  Island  is  rooted  in  the

 

that  is  Jamaica’s   heritage.  Many  specialized  herbs  with  healing  and  medicinal  properties  grow  easily  and  abundantly   here;  including  Ganja,  Ginger,  Noni,  Okra , Moringa, Cocoa, Coffee and Sorrel to name but a few .  

 

We  will  raise  awareness of  the  issues  of  climate  change,  habitat  degradation  and  human  interaction   with  the  environment,  with  the  hope  to  reinforce  the  need  for  a  law  to  end  ecocide  and  mitigate   against  these  critical  issues;  the   effect  of  which  are  felt  by  so  many  emerging  economies  and  small   island  

States and whose delicate  ecosystems  often  lie  in  the  balance. We will  be  discussing  and   demonstrating  new  opportunities  and  solutions  that  are  presented  in  the  face  of  such  adversity.

       

 

We  will  walk  to  communities and  share  our  skills,  gather  stories,  spend  the  night  and  feel  the  pulse  of   this  nation.  We  will  film  this  journey  and  we  will  share  this  film  and  gathered  knowledge  with  all  who   we  meet.

We  want  schools,  university  students,  community  organizations,  churches  and  all  members  of  society   to  join  us.  We  invite  people  from  other  parts  of  the  world  to  support  us  and  walk  with  us,  here  or   there.  Walk  for  a  few  days  or  the  whole  three  weeks!  We  plan  to  stay  amongst  communities  in   community  centers,  churches  and  schools.    Sharing  our  skills,  gathering  tales  and  understanding  this   beautiful  Island.

Support  is  requested  to kit out local people

 

• Food,  water

• Walking  boots

• Ruck  sacks,  first  aid

• Bedding.  Sleep  places

• Maps

• A  Sherpa  to  take  bags  and  injuries  by  car  or  truck  to  next  place  on  route

• General  walking  kit

• Security

     

                                                                                

 Earthrightswalker (s)  walk  so  far…   The  walk  so  far  has  taken  me and many great people who have joined me,  through  Spain on  the  Camino  to  Santiago  de  Compostela,  a  sacred  and   ancient  pilgrimage,  then  to  Portugal,  Sweden,  Finland,  Germany,  The  Netherlands  and  Cuba  see…  www.earthrightswalker.org      and  www.endecocide.com a  journey  walking  3500km  plus  trains , planes   and  automobiles….

WHY…people  all  over  the  world  are  working  for  change   Mother  Earth  suffers  from  the  modern  globalised  industrialised  society,  resulting  mass  extinction  of   species  and  climate  change  endangering  the  survival  of  future  generations.  To  maintain  biodiversity   and  future  generations’  health,  we  need  a  new  definition  of  wellbeing  and  prosperity  for  all  life  under   the  limits  and  in  recognition  of  the  Rights  of  Nature.  And  it  requires  an  international  legal   framework  to  protect  those  rights  from  greed  and  natural  exploitation.  To  that  end  we  must  protect   ecosystems  by  creating  a  legal  and  moral  framework  to  prevent  and  outlaw  ecocide,  the  extensive   destruction  or  damage  of  ecosystems.

• Promote  the  establishment  of  a  legal  system  of  environmental  justice  at  national  and  international   level.

• Empower  citizens  to  take  responsibility  in  the  democratic  process,  to  protect  the  Earth,  our  Home.

• Reconnect  society  with  all  cycles  of  life  through  developing  a  culture  of  sustainability.


Follow on twitter and instagram #OLOSW
story_txt:
The  new  Front-­‐line  –  Jamaica  is  one  of  40  countries  facing  the  greatest  impact  from   Climate  Change  -­‐United  Nations  (UNU-­‐EHS)  Walking  to  celebrate  and  discover  the  abundant  ecology,  meet  and  hear  the  stories  from  a  people  that   created  a  nation  with  a  philosophy  of  ‘Out  of  Many  One  People’  and  ‘One  Love’.  To  also  explore  the   creativity  of  this  extraordinary  Island.  Jamaica’s  journey  from  slavery  and  economic  exploitation  has   created  a  resilient  and  resourceful  people,  many  of  whom  are  notable  on  the  world  stage  but  now  the   Jamaican  people  face  one  of  their  biggest  challenges  yet  -­‐  Climate  Change Legacy:- To raise awareness and create connections along the central agricultural spine of Jamaica. Linking village to town andperson to person. The route to the Tourist Enhancement Fund, environmental agencies and investment opportunities - Laying a trail for the One Love walk - a legacy for earth rights walking a global impact movement.There  is  a  special  quality  to  the  nature  of  Jamaica,  which  is  unique  within  the  Caribbean,  a  small   Island  with  enormous  biodiversity.  Many  endemic  creatures  live  on  the  Island  and  anything  grows  in   the  rich  and  diverse  soils.  This  needs  recognition,  consideration  and  then  action  to  protect  it  from   exploitation.  Jamaica  was  once  built  on  a  foundation  of  ONE  LOVE  -­‐  BUT  has  this  now  become   nothing  more  than  a  brand?  We  want  to  explore  this  through  walk,  talk  and  stories,  capturing  the   true  currency  of  Jamaica to map the future.I  believe  that  the  future  success  of  this  BIG  little  Island  is  rooted  in  the that  is  Jamaica’s   heritage.  Many  specialized  herbs  with  healing  and  medicinal  properties  grow  easily  and  abundantly   here;  including  Ganja,  Ginger,  Noni,  Okra , Moringa, Cocoa, Coffee and Sorrel to name but a few .  
 
We  will  raise
 awareness of  the  issues  of  climate
 change,  habitat  degradation  and  human
 interaction   with  the  environment,  with  the
 hope  to  reinforce  the  need  for  a
 law  to  end  ecocide  and  mitigate  
against  these  critical  issues;  the   effect
 of  which  are  felt  by  so  many
 emerging  economies  and  small   island  
States and whose delicate  ecosystems
 often  lie  in  the  balance. We will  be
 discussing  and   demonstrating  new  opportunities
 and  solutions  that  are  presented  in
 the  face  of  such  adversity.        We  will  walk  to  communities and  share  our  skills,  gather  stories,  spend  the  night  and  feel  the  pulse  of   this  nation.  We  will  film  this  journey  and  we  will  share  this  film  and  gathered  knowledge  with  all  who   we  meet.
We  want  schools,  university  students,  community  organizations,  churches  and  all  members  of  society   to  join  us.  We  invite  people  from  other  parts  of  the  world  to  support  us  and  walk  with  us,  here  or   there.  Walk  for  a  few  days  or  the  whole  three  weeks!  We  plan  to  stay  amongst  communities  in   community  centers,  churches  and  schools.    Sharing  our  skills,  gathering  tales  and  understanding  this   beautiful  Island.

Support  is  requested  to kit out local people

 

• Food,  water
• Walking  boots
• Ruck  sacks,  first  aid
• Bedding.  Sleep  places
• Maps
• A  Sherpa  to  take  bags  and  injuries  by  car  or  truck  to  next  place  on  route
• General  walking  kit
• Security
     

                                                                                 
 Earthrightswalker (s)  walk  so  far…   The  walk  so  far  has  taken  me and many great people who have joined me,  through  Spain on  the  Camino  to  Santiago  de  Compostela,  a  sacred  and   ancient  pilgrimage,  then  to  Portugal,  Sweden,  Finland,  Germany,  The  Netherlands  and  Cuba  see…  www.earthrightswalker.org      and  www.endecocide.com a  journey  walking  3500km  plus  trains , planes   and  automobiles….
WHY…people  all  over  the  world  are  working  for  change   Mother  Earth  suffers  from  the  modern  globalised  industrialised  society,  resulting  mass  extinction  of   species  and  climate  change  endangering  the  survival  of  future  generations.  To  maintain  biodiversity   and  future  generations’  health,  we  need  a  new  definition  of  wellbeing  and  prosperity  for  all  life  under   the  limits  and  in  recognition  of  the  Rights  of  Nature.  And  it  requires  an  international  legal   framework  to  protect  those  rights  from  greed  and  natural  exploitation.  To  that  end  we  must  protect   ecosystems  by  creating  a  legal  and  moral  framework  to  prevent  and  outlaw  ecocide,  the  extensive   destruction  or  damage  of  ecosystems.
• Promote  the  establishment  of  a  legal  system  of  environmental  justice  at  national  and  international   level.
• Empower  citizens  to  take  responsibility  in  the  democratic  process,  to  protect  the  Earth,  our  Home.
• Reconnect  society  with  all  cycles  of  life  through  developing  a  culture  of  sustainability.



Follow on twitter and instagram #OLOSW

story:
Short Summary

Our Mission

To advance renewable energy implementation through practical installations, education, leadership, and scientific & fiscal scrutiny.

Our Vision

To be a key catalyst in the real-world installation and utilization of renewable energy and in expanding Minnesota’s energy landscape with a focus on efficiency and sustainability.

Our Values

Above all else, we believe in: Contributing towards the long term sustainability of the planet by supporting and implementing renewable energy technologies.  Effecting real change through the support of education and the practical application of science and engineering.  Embodying excellence and positivity.  Honesty, integrity, teamwork and communication.

Our Campaign

To obtain a state and federal non-profit status so that we can apply for and accept various types of funding. Obtaining non-profit status will help in the success of pursue our mission. Your donation will allow us to be a catalyst in the development of a sustainable future.

_______________

$2600 is needed to obtain state and federal non-profit status. This amount will pay for the application and legal fees that are associated with becoming a non-profit. 
If our goal is not met, the funds will be put towards obtaining the state and federal non-profit status. 

The Impact

Why our project is valuable to the community.

Implementation of renewable and sustainable energy sources is important in ensuring a safe and healthy environment for generations to come. Pursuing these types of energy sources is not only beneficial to humans, but to the diverse population of flora and fauna as well. We are stewards of the natural world and are wholly dependent on it. It is because of this that is our duty to promote environmental education, inspire innovation and create the leaders of tomorrow.
Real and Renewable has successfully implemented a hybrid street lamp within the Minnesota State Fair Grounds. These  street lamps are powered by vertical-axis wind turbines and solar panels that charge the battery banks. The street lamps have been operating maintenance free for nearly a year and a half. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Making a donation is not the only way you can help! Make some noise about our campaign and our organization by sharing us on Facebook or by making a tweet!

story: My nephew has asked that he receives no presents for his birthday in June and instead we send money to the children in Nepal that have lost everything. He has also asked his mum and dad to ask his friends parents coming his party not to give him gifts but give him money to send to Nepal as he is so upset by what they have lost and that they have nothing. So please help a 9 year old raise money for this good cause.

story:
We are a family of traditional coffee growers in the mountains of Veracruz, Mexico. We have been growing some of the best coffees for generations.


Enjoying lunch at the farm

We implement careful management of the land, including a wide diversity of shade trees that create the perfect microclimate and provide shelter to a wide variety of native animals. We ensure the selection of the best seeds and plant these with organic compost for the best possible start. We carefully handpick only perfectly ripe coffee cherries.


All our coffee is wet processed in an artisanal way to get a cleaner, brighter and fruitier taste. This also develops a nice degree of acidity without compromising the body and mouth feel of the coffee. The coffee is then gently sun dried so the heat won’t damage the delicate and complex flavors and aromas that the coffee plant has been storing in the developing coffee bean throughout the whole year. When the coffee is dry it is allowed to rest a little before being roasted to perfection.


Sun drying the coffee

All the coffee is freshly roasted just before shipping so you get the best possible product, and you can enjoy it at its peak. We really hope you enjoy all the hard work and attention to detail that goes into this artisanal coffee.

We wouldn’t be able to do all this without the blessing of an ideal climate for growing high quality coffee. As farmers we are facing the daunting challenge of climate change making the rains more unpredictable and the temperatures more extreme. We believe that if we want to keep growing the best coffee possible we have to stop climate change. We are already helping to get carbon out of the atmosphere by incorporating organic matter back in the soil but we want to do even more. The biggest source of carbon dioxide on the farm is the truck we use to haul things back and forth to the farm. We would like to replace the truck with an electric cargo bicycle that would be emissions free and would drastically reduce the carbon emitted to the atmosphere during the production of the coffee.

What We Need

We would like to start with a Surly Big Dummy cargo bicycle that is able to carry up to 400 pounds. The bike is also nimble and fast and it can be geared down low enough to tackle the steep grades that we encounter in the mountains where coffee likes to grow. We would also like to add an electric motor to help tackle the steeps hills when the bike is fully loaded especially after a hard day’s work at the farm. The bike costs $2000 dollars and the electric bike conversion kit is $1000. That is why our goal is to reach $3000 dollars. We feel that it is not a lot of money for the big impact it will have on our world.


Surly Big Dummy Cargo Bicycle (Stock Photo)

What You Get

If you contribute to our campaign you will get the opportunity to try our great tasting and sustainably produced coffee that you won't be able to get anywhere else. The coffee was harvested this year and is ready to be roasted and shipped. We are just waiting for your contribution. Don’t miss this opportunity to enjoy this unique coffee. All our coffee is handpicked at the perfect ripeness, slowly sun dried so it doesn’t lose any of its delicate flavors and then roasted to perfection. And by supporting our crowd funding campaign you will help to conserve this planet so we can keep producing the great coffee that we all enjoy every morning.


Enjoying a cup of our coffee in the morning

You can also live the experience of a lifetime by visiting us and living as a coffee farmer for a week where you will get to learn the whole process coffee goes through from picking the cherries to roasting and cupping the final product.

The Impact

If you are like us and can’t start your day without a cup of coffee in the morning you will understand the impact of this campaign. With your contribution you are helping to stop climate change and ensuring that we can keep growing the best coffee.


Coffee farm devastated by rust, the disease is reaching epidemic proportions due to climate change

Risks and Challenges

It will be a challenge to stop using the truck but I ride my bike almost daily and have been doing it for most of my life so I believe that I’m physically capable. With an electric cargo cycle I will be able to haul coffee plants, compost, coffee beans, and other cargo to and from the coffee farm and replace the truck for most of the trips.

You also don’t have anything to lose because the coffee was harvested this year and it is now ready to ship. Even if we don’t reach our goal you will get to taste our great coffee.


Green coffee ready for roasting and shipment

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a donation now help us to spread the word by sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter and E-mail using the Indiegogo tools at the top left of this page. The more we can spread the word about this great tasting sustainable coffee, the better we'll all be.

story:
A true American Goddess is coming to play in Dubai. Will you join me?
 Have you ever wondered what it would be like to be at my feet in real time? To be able to have the opportunity to sleep at the foot of my bed? To know what I smell like? To know what it will be like to be at my beck and call? To know what it's like to serve a naturally dominant, demanding, and beautiful Goddess? Did you think you'd never have the chance to serve me because of the distance? Well now is your chance to make your fantasy into a reality. Not only will you be completely satisfied to be at my feet serving me when I come, but you will also be happy knowing that you are at my feet, serving me, because you contributed to this campaign to prove to me, how badly you need me.  I will come to you as soon as you meet my funding goals here to ensure my safe arrival to you. The sooner you fulfill my funding needs, the sooner you will be able to make all of your fantasies come true. Your tribute will be used as a deposit or down payment as we like to call it, to ensure your servitude to me, the second my flight lands. 

I will ONLY be doing sessions when I arrive, with slaves who have tributed to me in this campaign. In my eyes, those are truly the most deserving. If you don't tribute to this campaign, you will not be welcome in my presence, period!



I will session with slaves in the order of donations received. If you are the first to donate, then you will be the first one to see me when I arrive. 

I'm into playing games. My favorites are CBT, Foot, Leg and Ass Worship, Chastity devices and of course, holding the key ;), Whipping and Cropping, Forced Intoxication, Humiliation (public, private, physical, and verbal), Forced Feminization and Sissification, Face sitting, Trampling, Domestic Servitude (chores), Corner time, Shopping Sprees, Water Sports, and more. 

The trip costs $3900 USD. I will be visiting Abu Dhabi/Dubai for 2 weeks on this visit. If you make my stay worthwhile, I will consider staying for up to 4 weeks. 



The only way I will be coming to do sessions in Dubai, is if you contribute your money to this and use this campaign as your down payment for a session with me. Stop wasting time and let's play! 

*If you ask me to session with me in Dubai and don't donate, you will be blocked from contacting me and removed from my online social networking sites.
*If you want to cam verify with me before donating, I'm ok with that. My Skype is girlx101. Introduce yourself to me when you add me so I know who you are and what you're adding me for. 
*If you're having hesitation over internet security, this website is a BBB certified website and has a TrustE european safe harbor certification. You can click the link below if you want to read more. 

Trust & Safety

At Indiegogo, nurturing a trusted open platform is our top priority.

https://www.indiegogo.com/trust

story:
The Problem

More than 5 million households in Asia have no access to affordable power sources. It is by no means a coincidence that many of these households are located in some of the most impoverished rural areas in the world.

These areas remain under-developed and with little infrastructure and lack modern sanitation facilities. With little economic activity or industrialisation, progress is slow. 


All these, simply because there is no access to a reliable and affordable energy source. 


The Idea

Phosphoresce is working with its partners to start a proposed non-profit organisation focused on bringing clean, reliable and affordable solar energy to these impoverished rural areas in Asia.

We're planning to build, operate and manage solar farms and solar energy facilities in rural communities in Thailand, Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar, starting with a 8,000 sqm solar farm in Chonburi, Thailand that will generate 2.5MW of usable solar power for a local community.


What We Need 

Phosphoresce, together with its partners including private companies, government agencies and advocacy groups, has currently raised USD 250,000 to kick-start the project in Chonburi. We have secured the land titles, and will require funding to build the solar farm.

We require a further USD 250,000 to continue to the next phase of the project in Chonburi, and to purchase land and build solar farms and solar energy facilities in other locations. The proposed non-profit organisation will own, manage and operate these facilities so as to ensure reliability and affordability of solar energy for our beneficiaries. 


The Impact

We believe the project can help improve lives for our beneficiaries. With the provision of clean, reliable and affordable solar power, we can:

  • Help to power up rural homes so they enjoy the ability to have light, heat and even refrigeration at the flick of a switch.
  • Support infrastructure building, improvement works and small-scale industrialisation, especially when our efforts are combined with other conventional power supply reaching to these communities.
  • Facilitate access to clean drinking water and sanitation by way of powering modern electrical pumps and water filtration systems.
  • Provide jobs either directly as employers, or indirectly by supporting local economic development.
  • Advocate and educate people on the impact of how sustainable growth and development can be achieved through clean renewable energy sources and reduce the reliance on fossil fuels.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute in terms of monetary donations, you can still help by helping us get the word out and share our vision with people you know. 

Every little bit helps. Thanks!!!

It is by no means a coincidence that many of these households are located in some of the most impoverished rural areas in the world.These areas remain under-developed and with little infrastructure and lack modern sanitation facilities. With little economic activity or industrialisation, progress is slow. All these, simply because there is no access to a reliable and affordable energy source. The IdeaPhosphoresce is working with its partners to start a proposed non-profit organisation focused on bringing clean, reliable and affordable solar energy to these impoverished rural areas in Asia.We're planning to build, operate and manage solar farms and solar energy facilities in rural communities in Thailand, Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar, starting with a 8,000 sqm solar farm in Chonburi, Thailand that will generate 2.5MW of usable solar power for a local community.What We Need Phosphoresce, together with its partners including private companies, government agencies and advocacy groups, has currently raised USD 250,000 to kick-start the project in Chonburi. We have secured the land titles, and will require funding to build the solar farm.We require a further USD 250,000 to continue to the next phase of the project in Chonburi, and to purchase land and build solar farms and solar energy facilities in other locations. The proposed non-profit organisation will own, manage and operate these facilities so as to ensure reliability and affordability of solar energy for our beneficiaries. The ImpactWe believe the project can help improve lives for our beneficiaries. With the provision of clean, reliable and affordable solar power, we can:
Help to power up rural homes so they enjoy the ability to have light, heat and even refrigeration at the flick of a switch.
Support infrastructure building, improvement works and small-scale industrialisation, especially when our efforts are combined with other conventional power supply reaching to these communities.
Facilitate access to clean drinking water and sanitation by way of powering modern electrical pumps and water filtration systems.
Provide jobs either directly as employers, or indirectly by supporting local economic development.
Advocate and educate people on the impact of how sustainable growth and development can be achieved through clean renewable energy sources and reduce the reliance on fossil fuels.
Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can’t contribute in terms of monetary donations, you can still help by helping us get the word out and share our vision with people you know. Every little bit helps. Thanks!!!

story:
MAKE A DONATION
MAKE A DIFFERENCE


Small donations make a huge difference to us, and we would appreciate your help with creating more awareness regarding the rising issues of climate change. Whether you are an individual offering a personal donation, a business wanting to fund a cause or general fundraising and awareness - we will appreciate your help and nature will repay you.  We call it - PAY IT FORWARD!


What We Do

In short, we need a planet to live on and forests are an important contributor to our air quality, water quality, food chain, and enjoyment. Forests Help Sustain All Life on Earth. We have helped plant trees in an incredible range of environments from coastal areas to mountains, restoring soil that had been unproductive for decades or even hundreds of years.



Values
  • Action: engage in positive, impactful initiatives
  • Youth education: educating our future leaders is critical to building a sustainable future
  • Sustainability: ensuring we help create a healthy environment for future generations
  • Cooperation: engaging in the right partnerships to implement valuable projects
Forests -Produce Clean Water
Forests - Naturally Filter Air
Forests - Regulate the Global Climate
Forests  -  Support People and Nature


1$ = 1 planted tree


DONATE 1.00$ - 99.00$ and get printable certificate with your name on it
DONATE 100$ or more and get printed certificate with your name on it


You can transform a life today
Help Us Plant a Million Trees
Together we can plant roots for tomorrow and donate today. Your donation can turn the tide of deforestation and help us protect and expand forests around the globe before they shrink even further. You’ll do more than put a seed in the ground you’ll make sure these habitats can survive for future generations.

Say a big thank you to mother nature and plant as much trees as you can. That's the way how we can repay for our existence on this beautiful planet! We will seed a tree by tree and make a forest. 


You can choose any of our certificate designs and colors -we will write your name on it and how many trees you had planted. 
It will be AMAZING gift, but this time for NATURE!

Dimensions: 8x10 inches.
Here’s how it works:
- Purchase this listing
- Send us your email and name you wish to see on certificate
- Choose color/design you love
- We send you ( PDF, PNG, JPG ) printable poster / certificate to your email address.

*Digital purchase: no physical item will be mailed unless you donate more than 100$


You are welcome to follow us. And don't forget to ask your family, friends or colleagues to DONATE!



Thank you very much!

Certificate gallery here

What if I don't have money?

Become a natures friend and support us by following!

Follow

story:
PERK UPDATE - CRTFREEJAX Hat reveal! Featuring our favorite Mac.
available for all backer levels Ecycle Enabler and up!


We think solving a global crisis by combining innovation and the power of the crowd is ridiculously cool. This mess isn't going to clean itself, so let's do it together.

My name is Juan Carlos Villatoro.  I’m the founder of eCycle Security (@ecyclesecurity) and I am committed to the end-to-end recycling of electronic waste in a transparent and socially responsible way. I’ve spent years designing and testing a safe, scalable way to recycle hazardous eWaste starting with the part that no one wants to deal with – the cathode ray tube (CRT) - it's the glass inside those bulky old monitors and TV’s made before 2007 that you're having a hard time unloading.

eWaste recycling is a global crisis that is growing at an alarming rate. Here are some quick facts*:

  • Every year, in the US, we improperly dump or incinerate 220 tons of eWaste.
  • There will be 73 Million Metric tons of eWaste for us to deal with by 2015
  • 860 Million lbs of CRT glass is stockpiled in the US
  • 13.8 Billion lbs still need to be collected for recycling.

*source: recycling today & EPA eWaste report 2013.

New technology made CRTs obsolete.  With no use for them, no accessible options for safe recycling, and no financial incentive to handle the process correctly, the pile up of hazardous CRT glass just continues to grow (and sometimes catch fire - yikes!) While governments worldwide acknowledge the enormity of the crisis, they don't have a strategy to clean this up any time soon - but we do.

The eCycle Security CRTFREE project provides a safe, scalable solution - already approved by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection - for recycling the hazardous components found in CRTs.


Why This Matters to YOU

Lead and phosphorus exposure from improperly recycled CRTs poses a huge health risk.  Lead exposure interferes with the development of the nervous system so it’s particularly toxic to children, causing potentially permanent learning and behavior disorders as well as damage to kidney, bones, heart and intestines. 

With funding from the crowd, eCycle Security will complete the final build out of a mobile machine that will:

  • Recycle 7000 units per month
  • Make Jacksonville CRT FREE by 2016
  • Infuse $6 Million into the local economy
  • Employ Vets - creating 36 new jobs in 12 months
  • Introduce a sustainable, scalable way to recycle CRTs nationwide

What We Need

We’re asking backers to fund $75,000 towards the final build out of the machine we will use to process the glass (spoiler alert: we haven’t named the machine yet). We’ve already tested the process on a small scale and the EPA has approved our methodology. However, to recycle CRTs at a meaningful volume, we need to build this machine to its final specifications. Full disclosure: the actual cost of the build out is $200,000.  While we are willing to take a loan, eCycle Security can’t finance the whole build and keep our operations running. With your support, we can launch this solution in 2014.

Your Impact is 1:1

We did the math, for every dollar we raise, we can safely recycle 1 CRT unit. Obviously, there are a lot more than 75,000 CRT units for us to process once we build this machine – but think of it this way - your investment is the one that just keeps giving. Bottom line - this mess isn't going away and it’s important that we pursue a responsible, environmentally sound way to deal with it. We have that solution and believe in the power of the crowd to make this a reality.

Learn more about eCycle Security, and other successful projects executed by Juan Carlos Villatoro: crtfree.com

The Perks
Here’s the fun part! Handcrafted perks & mind blowing geekery for all:
Take a look at the right side of your screen for perk details at each funding level.
Below are some pictures of the perks you can score when you back our Indiegogo Project. As more of our finished perks arrive, we'll keep you updated with more pictures! We'll also be introducing some one of a kind perks along the way - completely retro fabulous.

Limited Edition Photos We love our mascot - The Mac. He likes strong coffee and interesting people… we have no control over what he’s getting into, but we usually document it.  You'll get to select your favorite 4x4" print. Check out his adventures on Instagram @ecyclesecurity and find your favorite starring this Classic Macintosh (he also has a CRT, but we love him anyways.)


Official CRT FREE Backer Lids (complete with under the brim cameo of The Mac you can enjoy every time you rock it.) These premium lids are made by the killer folks at DOME Lids, and as soon as we have our sample to take pictures of, you'll see it here.


Handcrafted Geekery - recycling is in our DNA, so we wanted our perks to match. We’ve designed cuffs, earrings and necklaces from recycled electronics and even some pieces of upcycled awesomeness we'll monogram for your desk. You get your pick of the bling that will compliment your obviously good looks. We're working on some production samples, and those pictures will be up soon! 


Mapping Privileges Here’s your chance to help us decide where to go next. We’re starting our efforts in Jacksonville, Florida where we will process 7000 units a month until we are CRT Free (2016). After that, it’s time to hit the road. Help us map out where to go next.

Naming the Machine – told ya! We haven’t named the process or the machine. We think the person (or group) that makes a bold commitment to our success should have that honor.

If we exceed our goal, we will offset the loan amount and reduce the time it will take to bring the process to market. If we don’t reach our goal, we’ll still use all of the funds raised to offset the final loan amount.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t back us right now? That’s okay – we still really appreciate your interest in what we're doing. The fact that you’re here shows us you care. If you think this is a crisis worth solving and a project worth succeeding, you can still help by spreading the word.

Simply share this campaign with your friends and family (pretty much anyone who has owned a big bulky TV or computer monitor has some skin in this game.) Indiegogo has some killer sharing tools, so hit some buttons and let’s get this party started.

story:
The story:

Greening the Desert Sequel Site, Jordan, with Alex McCausland and Salah Hammad

Starts Apr 19, 2014 and runs for 13 day(s).

Hello everyone, 

I have the opportunity to participate in a greening the desert project from April 19th 2014. The thing is that I can not afford the airfare to travel and the cost to cover the design course prior to the voluntary work. I believe that this is a project with a lot of beautiful elements in its essence. We need to reconnect with the Earth and what better ways are there than to fight desertification and climate changes in order to help the people who really need this for the prospects of a better future.

NB!: If we do not reach the amount needed, the next course available will be six month after (but in a different location). 

This PDC follows the standard accredited 72-hour design course syllabus with running translation into Arabic. All written materials will also be translated. The course covers in detail the ecological basis of Permaculture design, the ethics, the principles of design, strategies for restoring soils, managing water, partitioning land between intensity of uses for efficient management, cycling of energy and minerals within our system, enactment of site survey and assessment as well as design strategies for different climactic, ecological, technological and cultural settings. 

The Jordan Valley Permaculture Project in November 2013

Permaculture is a system that allows us to design sustainability into our own lives. Living sustainably literally means living in a way we can continue to live - a way of life which does not destroy the means of its own sustenance. If we consume food produced in a way that destroys soil, poisons the water and pollutes the air, as current systems of production do, we cannot be living sustainably and we will eventually no longer be able to produce food. The one sentence definition of Permaculture is: "A design system for sustainable human settlements and productive landscapes." It is a conceptual tool-kit for how we can establish productive systems to support our needs while re-generating the ecological processes that support the planet. And it can be done at the domestic, community or commercial scales, as we need.


This course will equip me with all the necessary tools to produce a Permaculture design for my own life situation. It is the necessary first step in becoming a Permaculture practitioner and will allow me to go on to register in internships, training of trainers (TOT) courses or for a Diploma in Permaculture Design (PDP) all offered by various Permaculture institutions around the world. The PDC is a formative stage in career development which may compliment my existing life vision or may allow me to radically re-evaluate where I want to go from here. Either way it's sure to be an eye-opener.

Topics covered on this PDC: 

- Ethics and principles of Permaculture Design
- Ecological basis of Earth-System Function
- Soils - conservation and re-generation: composting and fertility building techniques
- Water - management and treatment in domestic scale systems
- Intensive Garden Design
- Poultry and Small Animal Systems
- Food Forests - planning, nursery establishment, propagation and planting out
- Earthworks for water harvesting, storage, infiltration and distribution
- Ecological Agriculture Systems
- Ecological Pasture Systems
- Ecological Forestry Systems
- Design strategies for Temperate, Dry-Land and Wet-Tropical Climates.
- Aquaculture
- Site survey 
- Community needs assessment
- Full Site Design Development and Evolution

About the teachers

Abdurrahman (Alex) McCausland is an ecologist by background, developed as a Permaculture practitioner and trainer over the last seven years. He graduated in Biological Sciences in 2003 [MA 2.1 (Hons) Merton College, Oxford, United Kingdom]. Alex speaks English (mother tongue), fluent Amharic (Ethiopia's vernacular language) and has basic understanding of Arabic and French.

In 2004-5 Alex studied a post graduate diploma in Economics at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS) in London. Following this he went travelling through the Middle East and Africa visiting Egypt, Sudan and Ethiopia. Astonished by Ethiopia, seeing a land of great ecological wealth and yet economic poverty and food insecurity, he resolved to set up a Permaculture project there. He took his first Permaculture Design Course later that year in Catalunya, Spain. In 2007 he returned to Ethiopia to establish the country's first PC training and demonstration site with a local school-gardens community outreach program. Alex developed the site with input from a number of volunteers, interns and Permaculture practitioners (Guy Rees, Dan Palmer, Rosemary Morrow & Tichafa Makovere). Working alongside these people Alex developed his skills as a Permaculture designer and practitioner. Since 2008 the project has hosted a total of 31 PDCs: 2 led by Rosemary Morrow, 19 by Tichafa Makovere, 1 by Steve Cran, 1 by Rhamis Kent and 8 led by Alex himself since December 2010. Alex has delivered trainings and Permaculture design-consultancies to: the Ethiopian Red Cross Society, the Ethiopian NGO SMART (who administers the Hafto Solar Community WASH Project in Hadyia Zone, South Ethiopia), and the Daughters of Charity Food Security Project in Dembe Dollo, Western Ethiopia.

- Alex McCausland's profile on the Worldwide Permaculture Network website
- Sample consultancy and training delivered by Alex McCausland: Dembe Dollo Training For Daughters of Charity Food Security Project 
- Consultacy for SMART at the Hafto Solar Community WASH Project, Hadyia Zone
Sample course outline.
- Previous student references

Salah Hammad: Salah's passion for sustainable food production started while working with struggling small farmers in Jordan. The experience exposed him to the urgent need for an alternative approach. This is when he decided to make the transition into a career in Permaculture and agro-ecology following a 10 year long career in the food industry. During his career Salah has led and trained large teams in different food production related projects and setups, including manufacturing, service and sales. 

Salah is now designing, teaching and practicing Permaculture at the Permaculture Research Institute Zaytuna Farm, Australia, under the direct management of Geoff and Nadia Lawton. He has direct experience in dry arid, temperate, and subtropical climates, covering urban, rural and broad acre setups. Salah endeavors to design and install systems that empower individuals and communities with Permaculture tools that will help them meet their needs and care for the earth. For the past few months Salah has worked on developing an Arabic language PDC syllabus and he is now due to teach courses together with Alex McCausland in Sudan, Ethiopia and Jordan in the first half of 2014. For Salah, this is an important formative stage: breaking out of the trainee pupa to become one of the world's first bi-lingual English-Arabic PDC teachers.

Articles by Salah Hammad:

- Greening the Desert Internship 2012 - Greener than Ever
- Wadi Hadhramaut - the Start of a Large New Rehabilitation Project in Yemen
- Salah's Arabic YouTube channel

Course Venue

The Jordan Valley Permaculture Project (aka "Greening the Desert - the Sequel" site), PRI Jordan, Al-Jawfa, Jordan Valley.

The site is located in the Al-Jawfa area in western Jordan, Shouneh Janobieh (i.e., South Shouneh), in the Dead Sea Valley just 10km north of the Dead Sea and 6 km east of the Jordanian-Palestinian border, directly east of the West Bank. 

The local population is made up of traditional Bedouin tribes and long-term refugees stemming from displacement of local populations from within Palestine. The project site is typical of the area - a marginal, arid land, low-income settlement. It is currently still under development and upon completion it will demonstrate energy-efficient appropriate housing with natural cooling systems and a plant nursery attachment, solar electricity, solar hot water, biological waste water treatment recycling, dry compost toilets, rainwater harvesting earthworks and diverse interactive plant, animal and tree systems for local food production and processing. The demonstration house will function as a classroom and administration office for the project and local Permaculture groups. Once established, the project will serve as a model that can be replicated within the village, throughout Jordan and other countries in the region. The project, started in 2008, has already seen significant progress. The first trees were planted and are growing well and the first garden is producing some vegetables. Now, the water tank needs to be expanded, the fence and gate improved and the rest of the project started. The current focus is to set up basic living accommodations for volunteers coming to work on the project. PRI has the people power in place to move on this project, but is in great need of funds to purchase supplies. Any financial support is greatly appreciated. In this heightened time of great tragedy for the Palestinian people, this is something positive we can all do to directly affect their survival.

For more info on the history of the site, see: 

http://permaculturenews.org/2011/11/08/letters-from-jordan-greening-the-desert-the-sequel-site-contrasts-against-jordan-insanities/ 

For most recent photos of the site see: 

http://permaculturenews.org/2013/11/19/rough-ready-real-november-2013-update-dead-sea-valley-permaculture-project-aka-greening-desert-sequel-site

Map

He took his first Permaculture Design Course later that year in Catalunya, Spain. In 2007 he returned to Ethiopia to establish the country's first PC training and demonstration site with a local school-gardens community outreach program. Alex developed the site with input from a number of volunteers, interns and Permaculture practitioners (Guy Rees, Dan Palmer, Rosemary Morrow & Tichafa Makovere). Working alongside these people Alex developed his skills as a Permaculture designer and practitioner. Since 2008 the project has hosted a total of 31 PDCs: 2 led by Rosemary Morrow, 19 by Tichafa Makovere, 1 by Steve Cran, 1 by Rhamis Kent and 8 led by Alex himself since December 2010. Alex has delivered trainings and Permaculture design-consultancies to: the Ethiopian Red Cross Society, the Ethiopian NGO SMART (who administers the Hafto Solar Community WASH Project in Hadyia Zone, South Ethiopia), and the Daughters of Charity Food Security Project in Dembe Dollo, Western Ethiopia.- Alex McCausland's profile on the Worldwide Permaculture Network website- Sample consultancy and training delivered by Alex McCausland: Dembe Dollo Training For Daughters of Charity Food Security Project - Consultacy for SMART at the Hafto Solar Community WASH Project, Hadyia ZoneSample course outline.- Previous student referencesSalah Hammad: Salah's passion for sustainable food production started while working with struggling small farmers in Jordan. The experience exposed him to the urgent need for an alternative approach. This is when he decided to make the transition into a career in Permaculture and agro-ecology following a 10 year long career in the food industry. During his career Salah has led and trained large teams in different food production related projects and setups, including manufacturing, service and sales. Salah is now designing, teaching and practicing Permaculture at the Permaculture Research Institute Zaytuna Farm, Australia, under the direct management of Geoff and Nadia Lawton. He has direct experience in dry arid, temperate, and subtropical climates, covering urban, rural and broad acre setups. Salah endeavors to design and install systems that empower individuals and communities with Permaculture tools that will help them meet their needs and care for the earth. For the past few months Salah has worked on developing an Arabic language PDC syllabus and he is now due to teach courses together with Alex McCausland in Sudan, Ethiopia and Jordan in the first half of 2014. For Salah, this is an important formative stage: breaking out of the trainee pupa to become one of the world's first bi-lingual English-Arabic PDC teachers.Articles by Salah Hammad:- Greening the Desert Internship 2012 - Greener than Ever- Wadi Hadhramaut - the Start of a Large New Rehabilitation Project in Yemen- Salah's Arabic YouTube channelCourse VenueThe Jordan Valley Permaculture Project (aka "Greening the Desert - the Sequel" site), PRI Jordan, Al-Jawfa, Jordan Valley.The site is located in the Al-Jawfa area in western Jordan, Shouneh Janobieh (i.e., South Shouneh), in the Dead Sea Valley just 10km north of the Dead Sea and 6 km east of the Jordanian-Palestinian border, directly east of the West Bank. The local population is made up of traditional Bedouin tribes and long-term refugees stemming from displacement of local populations from within Palestine. The project site is typical of the area - a marginal, arid land, low-income settlement. It is currently still under development and upon completion it will demonstrate energy-efficient appropriate housing with natural cooling systems and a plant nursery attachment, solar electricity, solar hot water, biological waste water treatment recycling, dry compost toilets, rainwater harvesting earthworks and diverse interactive plant, animal and tree systems for local food production and processing. The demonstration house will function as a classroom and administration office for the project and local Permaculture groups. Once established, the project will serve as a model that can be replicated within the village, throughout Jordan and other countries in the region. The project, started in 2008, has already seen significant progress. The first trees were planted and are growing well and the first garden is producing some vegetables. Now, the water tank needs to be expanded, the fence and gate improved and the rest of the project started. The current focus is to set up basic living accommodations for volunteers coming to work on the project. PRI has the people power in place to move on this project, but is in great need of funds to purchase supplies. Any financial support is greatly appreciated. In this heightened time of great tragedy for the Palestinian people, this is something positive we can all do to directly affect their survival.For more info on the history of the site, see: http://permaculturenews.org/2011/11/08/letters-from-jordan-greening-the-desert-the-sequel-site-contrasts-against-jordan-insanities/ For most recent photos of the site see: http://permaculturenews.org/2013/11/19/rough-ready-real-november-2013-update-dead-sea-valley-permaculture-project-aka-greening-desert-sequel-siteMap

story:
The Rights of Nature Folk Opera

When I learned about Ecuador and Bolivia’s constitutional amendments giving rights to nature and to Mother Earth, I was immediately captured by the critical importance of this political evolution. I was inspired to write a story and then develop it into a proposal for a folk opera. 

I believe this is the moment in Earth and human evolution where we must learn to live with nature as an interdependent part of the whole. My vision is to aid in this unfoldment. You can read more at Rights Of Nature.

With your help, I will craft a production that not only highlights the important rights of nature legislation and the diverse people involved, but inspires a global movement by taking the production around the world, and working with communities, youth and inspired individuals.

About Nelson

"Nelson’s music opens doors of consciousness, singing the oneness of the Earth and her wonders. His voice spans borders and human differences. Using humor, vitality, good information, true spirit and his gifted hands.”

–Boz Scaggs, Singer, Songwriter

I have been a musician as long as I can remember, and I have been songwriting and composing for many years. I studied Philosophy, (St. John’s College, B.A.), and Education, (Harvard University, M.Ed.), and upon graduation realized I needed to devote myself to finding creative responses to the ecological crisis.

I am a founder of the Santa Fe Green Party/ NMGP, composer bandleader for All Species Project, and was on the Executive Committee of the Northern New Mexico chapter of the Sierra Club. I have taught Deep Ecology, Permaculture and Ecological Design around the world, as well as music to students of all levels, from primary school to university and beyond. I currently live in Hawaii, where I play cello in the Kamuela Philharmonic, the University of Hawaii, Hilo Symphony, and I perform and teach guitar, bass, violin and cello in Hawaii, Santa Fe, nationally and internationally.

How You Can Help 

Project Details
This Indiegogo campaign will cover Phase 1 of the "Rights of Nature" folk opera plan. It includes an information-gathering trip to Ecuador and Bolivia, interviews with key people in the movement, preliminary composition of main songs and themes, and structuring the story/libretto.

Phase 2 involves rehearsing and workshopping the music and libretto with a score. Editing the documentary from the interviews in Phase 1 will begin.

Phase 3 is the premiere performance of the opera and debut of the documentary on the making of "The Rights of Nature."

Any amount over the original $10,000 campaign will go to Phases 2 & 3.

I will offer special perks to enhance the fundraising efforts. They include CDs, sponsorship, naming rights, private concerts and your own personal song.
All funds will go towards travel expenses & the completion of the libretto and musical score.

Ecological Impact of Music & Storytelling

Folk opera has the potential for global impact and popularity. The Rights of Nature is an idea whose time has come. With your help, we will make a work of art that honors and celebrates this magnificent evolution of our legal system.

Other Ways You Can Help

          * Share this project on your social media channels such as YouTube, Facebook, Google Plus, Twitter, Redditt and Pinterest. Here's my YouTube video.

          * Send my Indiegogo campaign to your email list with a personal note.

          * Talk it up with your teachers, students, lawyers, doctors and bankers.

Be a part of this historic folk opera!

Thank you for all your help!

story:
I have been planning this for three years. Continuously walking/hiking from the most southern city in south america (Tierra del Fuego) to the most northern city in north america (Barrow Alaska). No hitch hiking, no car, no bike, or mule. Its been done once before, and i will be the second in history to do so. this trip will take me 3-4 years. It will be a journey. I wil be leaving on Dec. 30th, so i can make it to the southern coast and start my journey Jan. 1st 2014

    While planning i was only thinking how i can benifit out of this experience. Than this year i realized, it is not about me, it is about the people who need help. So i came up with wonderful plan. Help others, and in return have them tell me a story.....

SERVICE FOR A STORY....


So along the way i will be helping others. The one thing in life i love to do. Yes, i will be the second one in history to do this. Yes, i will be breaking a world record. But helping others will be the most gradifiying experience i will tke out of this trip. 

I will be documenting the stories. Which every one who follows my group on Facebook will be able to read. I am very excited to hear the stories of people who i will meet and help. I will also be filming a documentary film about the adventure. (Hopefully if could be made into a real film later on)

The money i am trying to raise will go to this:: 85% will go to the people who i am helping. If its for clothes, shelter, wells, food, supplies, etc. 10% will be back up for emergencies. I have saved the money for gear and airfare. 5% of the money will be used for postage to send memory cards back home. After the trip if there is money left over i will donate it to a childrens hospital. the more i raise the more i help others.

The Impact

I can not imagine the impact this will be on those who need the service i can provide. It overwhelms me that my dream to see the world and to help those in need can be part of one dream. The peoples lives i will impact and the stories that will impact me are just amzing to think about.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cant donate money than please do the following::::

-follow me on facebook and join the group

-maybe be help with dropping off water or food along the way

-a place to stay

-and the most important TELL THREE PEOPLE about this

 

the more people follow me and support in anyway,especially with encouragement, the more strength i will have to help others and complete this journey

story:
The Cause:

The aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan has affected countless families (including my own) across the Philippines. This fundraising  effort is to help the people in the central area of the Aklan Province to:

* start to rebuild their home's which were either totally destroyed or greatly damaged  

* provide electricity through the supply of a generator to power basic communication  devices and household devices

* provide candles and matches for basic lighting at night

* provision of food

* provision of water

* provision of medical supplies


How will this aid be distributed:

My mum has been in central Aklan for the last 2 weeks including the days when Haiyan hit. Mum and my family will purchase the  supplies from either Kalibo city and/or Roxas city in the north of the province and distribute to the families which need assistance the most.


Current Situation:

As the media has reported, there is no power in Aklan and close to 10,000 homes have been destroyed (see links below). On the ground, mum has confirmed hundreds of people sleeping in the local community hall on the ground as there homes are gone. In addition, they are isolated by communication to their families in other parts of the Philippines as their mobiles devices cant be charged due to power infrastructure being damaged.

http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2013/11/11/1255314/power-restoration-typhoon-hit-areas-may-take-2-months

http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/353813-aklan-province-9200-homes-destroyed-in-typhoon/


Gratitude:

Mum will taking photographs of all the individuals the funds will go to help over the coming weeks and ill post these up onto facebook.  It will great to see the actual faces of the people you have assisted in this crisis. Add me on Facebook and stay posted: 

http://facebook.com/kerrin.rowe.3


Timing:

This initial fundraiser can only go for 4 days as my mum is only in Aklan for the next two weeks then she is flying back to Australia. Hopefully we can raise the required funds in these days.


Regards,


Kerrin Rowe
