story:
A documentary about the community of Hoedspruit, a small town in South Africa, & their extraordinary efforts to save rhinos from becoming victims of poaching.

Background - A Strong Community

HOEDSPRUIT is a small town in the south of the Limpopo province of South Africa, 30 minutes from the world renowned Kruger National Park, and surrounded by dozens of Nature Reserves and Private Game Farms.

The community of Hoedspruit has a historical spirit of working together for conservation and the protection of endangered species by defending South Africa’s natural heritage. Now, once again this strong and passionate community have together to fight against the illegal and cruel poaching of rhino, a problem that is close to exterminating the rhino population in Africa.



Why are rhino being poached? 

The reason for this is in some Asian countries Rhino horn is still used as an ingredient in traditional medicine as it is believed that their horns have medicinal properties. It is wrongly used to help cure life threatening diseases such as cancer and some Vietnamese also believe that drinking a tonic made from the horn will detoxify the body and prevent a hangover. In traditional Chinese medicine, the horn, which is shaved or ground into powder and dissolved into boiling water, is used to treat fever, rheumatism, gout and other disorders.

Although it has been scientifically proven that the horn, which is made from keratin (the same as human hair and nails), has no medicinal properties what-so-ever, the number of Rhino being illegally poached is growing at a frightening rate. The value of Rhino horn has increased higher than gold, fetching $65,000 per kilo, making it economically profitable on the black market. The illegal trafficking of wildlife products, which generates $17 billion a year, is the fourth largest illegal trade in the world after narcotics, humans and counterfeit products.

Shocking Statistics

 2009 – 122 Rhino Poached

 2010 – 333 Rhino Poached 

 2011 – 448 Rhino Poached 

 2012 – 668 Rhino Poached 

 2013– 1004 Rhino Poached 

2026 – It is estimated that rhino in the country will be extinct if there is no significant change in the number of rhino being poached. 

Fighting Back - Rhino Gold Film! 

Rhino Gold aims to demonstrate that even the smallest of communities can make huge differences when they stand together and fight for what they believe in.

Hoedspruit has come together to do all it can to stop rhino poaching in the area. Many anti-poaching units has been set up, local farmers have come together to set up a farm watch, and the community frequently holds fundraising events to raise money for Rhino Conservation causes.

We must never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it’s the only thing that ever has!

Rhino Gold will focus on the extraordinary efforts of the people of Hoedspruit and will include interviews with anti-poaching units, game wardens, wildlife vets and local residents. 

Documentary Objectives

  • Establish the town of Hoedspruit, it's love and passion for conservation and the protection of endangered species. 
  • Highlight the problem of rhino poaching in the area and the detrimental effect it has to Africa's natural heritage. 
  • Demonstrate first-hand the importance of nature conservation, anti-poaching units andcommunity initiatives. 
  • Why are rhino being poached?
  • The people of Hoedspruit and their on-going fight for rhino! 
  • The future of South Africa's rhinos. 

Form:Factual actuality documentary with string of interviews and personal stories Narration, sound and music.

Format:High definition film or broadcast quality video format.

Target audience:Public broadcast audience, educational market audience, students and young people. 

Hook: Rhinos are being maliciously slaughtered in great numbers because their horn, which is made from the same substance as your hair and fingernails, is worth more than gold! 

Take-Away: A knowledge and understanding of the Rhino poaching crisis in South Africa and a deep understanding of the love that the people of Hoedspruit have for their natural heritage. To be educated on the needless need for Rhino horn products and to be inspired by the everyday people of Hoedspruit to go out into their own communities and start making small changes, but big differences! 

Why I am making this documentary

In 2011, I spent 4 months living in Hoedspruit, South Africa. In my time there I was heavily involved in wildlife and nature conservation and was asked to assist with the de-horning of rhino on a private Game Lodge. This was part of an area wide de-horning process that was taking place, in order to deter Rhino poachers from the area. This was a frightening, incredible and sad experience for me. The Rhino just looked so sad without their horns, they almost didn't look like Rhino at all – but it is a temporary and necessary measure that will save them from becoming victims of brutal and cruel attacks.

I quickly learned that the community had a deep rooted and historical spirit of working together for conservation and for the protection of endangered species. I saw for myself first had how members from all areas of the community, from farmers and housewife’s to vets and shop owners, came together and did all they could to help save their Rhino. The community of Hoedspruit is a great story and an example to be followed.

Rhino De-Horning in Hoedspruit 

The following is footage that I filmed on a private game reserve in Hoedspruit back in 2011 of the de-horning of 2 rhino.

Meet the team 

RHINO GOLD PRODUCER: Dominique Unsworth / Resource Productions www.resource-productions.co.uk 

Resource Productions is a UK based film and video production company delivering creative, engaging, and innovative videos and training to clients across a variety of sectors. Dominique has over 20 years experience of working in Film, TV and Video and is a Fellow on the Clore Leadership Programme 2012/13.RHINO GOLD DIRECTOR & CAMERAMAN: Kevin Holmes www.kevinholmesfilm.com 

Enthusiastic young filmmaker/photographer and all round-creative artist from South Africa, with a huge passion for wildlife and nature conservation. Kevin has over 5 years of experience working in film and media production and is always on the look out to combine his love of film and passion for wildlife. RHINO GOLD LEAD EDITOR: Tara Scott 

Tara has spent five years studying film, and holds a national diploma in Media Production and a Bsc Hons degree in Entertainment Technology. She has worked as an editor for Darkside FX, volunteers her time as an editor for Real Time and has experience working in Final Cut Pro 7 and X, and Avid Media Composer 6. Credits include: The Uneducated Boy, Termination, In The Darkness and Rejection.CONTRIBUTOR: Laetitia Cronje - General Manager at Campfire Academy

Laetitia has over 18 years of experience as a field guide trainer at Campfire Academy. Her qualifications include FGASA Level 3 Lead Trails Guide, accredited assessor, First Aid instructor and assessor and registered firearms instructor. Her passion for nature is evident in everything she does and she is currently majoring in Botany and Zoology. CONTRIBUTOR: Adele de Beer -  Manager at Campfire Academy

Adele is a FGASA Level 2 Lead Trails Guide and manages the junior nature conservation program. Her dedication as a teacher has a great impact on the youth. CONTRIBUTOR: Brass Brassett - Student Coordinator at Campfire Academy 

Brass visited Campfire Academy during 2008 as a volunteer. Within a week she registered for the next FGASA Level 1 course. She passed with flying colours and her passion for nature made her an ideal candidate for the Campfire team. CONTRIBUTOR: Dr. Peter Rogers - Provet Wildlife Services 

In addition to running a prominent wildlife veterinary practice in Hoedspruit, Dr Peter Rogers is also a specialist in wild animal capture and trans-location. He has previously assisted with the capture and aerial trans-location of various species including white rhino, giraffe, wildebeest, blesbok and cheetah. He’s traveled as far afield as Ivory Coast, Singapore, France and Australia. His most notable achievement was the capture of 20 white rhino from Umfolozi game reserve to the Masai Mara and Lake Nakuru in Kenya.

“One could say that rhinos are my strong point, having immobilised more than 1 500 in my career to date,” says Peter.CONTRIBUTOR: ProTrack Anti-Poaching Unit 

Protrack Anti-Poaching Unit was established in 1992 and was the first private anti-poaching unit in South Africa. Protrack was started with a dream, passion and a shoe string budget. Times were tough, money was scarce but there was no shortage of young men with the same passion to stop the slaughter of wildlife.CONTRIBUTOR: Black Mambas 

A new anti-poaching combat team launched by the Olifants West Conservation Trust in partnership with Transfontier Africa, the Endangered Wildlife Trust (EWT) and Rhino Mercy. The team operates mainly in the Olifants West Region of the Balule Nature Reserve and has already proven successful as animal snaring in the reserve has decreased dramatically. The programme is also supported by Work for Wildlife, a Department of Public Works programme in conjunction with SANParks.CONTRIBUTOR: Craig Spencer - Balule Nature Reserve Warden 

Senior ecologist and warden at Olifants West Balule Nature Reserve. Craig also lectures at various academic institutions, such as Pretoria University and Cape Peninsula University. Craig has a wealth of conservation experience gained from working in and running local government conservation departments, including poverty relief, education, conservation, environmental planning and anit-poaching. He has also set up and ran a successful Baboon research project in the Western CapeCONTRIBUTOR: Blue Canyon Conservancy

Birthchild of Trevor Jordan, conservation and eco-development pioneer – together with neighbours and business partners Dr Scheepers and the Steinberg family, as well as the conservancy’s general manager Tim Parker – Blue Canyon is the newest big game conservancy in Limpopo, and a veritable coup for sustainable lifestyle eco-activity in the area CONTRIBUTOR: Rocking for Rhinos 

Rocking for Rhinos was formed in Jan 2012 and presented a core group of four individuals. By April 2012, this had grown to include 8 extremely motivated, passionate, and dedicated people. The Rocking for Rhinos group is united by one fundamental reason; the now critical plight of South Africa’s disappearing rhinos. Their ultimate goal is to contribute to the abolishment of rhino poaching by spreading awareness and placing pressure on local and foreign governments to create change.CONTRIBUTOR: Rhino Revolution 

Based in Hoedspruit, South Africa Rhino Revolution is a community based initiative dedicated to saving the Rhino Species in South Africa and to educate the world at large as to the useless use of Rhino Horn in medicine.

counterfeit products.Shocking
Statistics
 2009 – 122 Rhino Poached
 2010 – 333 Rhino Poached 
 2011 – 448 Rhino Poached 
 2012 – 668 Rhino Poached 
 2013– 1004 Rhino Poached 2026 – It is estimated that rhino in the country will be extinct if there
is no significant change in the number of rhino being poached. Fighting Back - Rhino Gold Film! Rhino
Gold aims to demonstrate that even the smallest of communities can make huge
differences when they stand together and fight for what they believe in.
Hoedspruit
has come together to do all it can to stop rhino poaching in the area. Many anti-poaching
units has been set up, local farmers have come together to set up a farm watch,
and the community frequently holds fundraising events to raise money for Rhino
Conservation causes.
We must never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it’s the only thing that ever has!Rhino Gold will focus on the extraordinary efforts
of the people of Hoedspruit and will include interviews with anti-poaching
units, game wardens, wildlife vets and local residents. Documentary Objectives
Establish the town of Hoedspruit, it's love and passion for conservation and the protection of endangered species. 
Highlight the problem of rhino poaching in the area and the detrimental effect it has to Africa's natural heritage. 
Demonstrate first-hand the importance of nature conservation, anti-poaching units andcommunity initiatives. 
Why are rhino being poached?
The people of Hoedspruit and their on-going fight for rhino! 
The future of South Africa's rhinos. 
Form:Factual
actuality documentary with string of interviews and personal stories Narration,
sound and music.Format:High definition
film or broadcast quality video format.Target
audience:Public broadcast audience, educational market audience,
students and young people. Hook:
Rhinos are being maliciously slaughtered in great numbers
because their horn, which is made from the same substance as your hair and
fingernails, is worth more than gold! Take-Away:
A knowledge and understanding of the Rhino poaching crisis in South Africa and
a deep understanding of the love that the people of Hoedspruit have for their
natural heritage. To be educated on the needless need for Rhino horn products
and to be inspired by the everyday people of Hoedspruit to go out into their
own communities and start making small changes, but big differences! 
Why I am making this documentary
In
2011, I spent 4 months living in Hoedspruit, South Africa. In my time there I
was heavily involved in wildlife and nature conservation and was asked to assist
with the de-horning of rhino on a private Game Lodge. This was part of an area
wide de-horning process that was taking place, in order to deter Rhino poachers
from the area. This was a frightening, incredible and sad experience for me.
The Rhino just looked so sad without their horns, they almost didn't look like
Rhino at all – but it is a temporary and necessary measure that will save them
from becoming victims of brutal and cruel attacks.I quickly learned that the community had a deep rooted
and historical spirit of working together for conservation and for the
protection of endangered species. I saw for myself first had how members from
all areas of the community, from farmers and housewife’s to vets and shop
owners, came together and did all they could to help save their Rhino. The community of Hoedspruit is a great story and an example to be followed.Rhino De-Horning in Hoedspruit The following is footage that I filmed on a private game reserve in Hoedspruit back in 2011 of the de-horning of 2 rhino.
Meet the team 
RHINO GOLD PRODUCER: Dominique Unsworth / Resource Productions www.resource-productions.co.uk Resource Productions is a UK based film and video production company delivering creative, engaging, and innovative videos and training to clients across a variety of sectors. Dominique has over 20 years experience of working in Film, TV and Video and is a Fellow on the Clore Leadership Programme 2012/13.RHINO GOLD DIRECTOR & CAMERAMAN: Kevin Holmes www.kevinholmesfilm.com Enthusiastic young filmmaker/photographer and all round-creative artist from South Africa, with a huge passion for wildlife and nature conservation. Kevin has over 5 years of experience working in film and media production and is always on the look out to combine his love of film and passion for wildlife. RHINO GOLD LEAD EDITOR: Tara Scott Tara has spent five years studying film, and holds a national diploma in Media Production and a Bsc Hons degree in Entertainment Technology. She has worked as an editor for Darkside FX, volunteers her time as an editor for Real Time and has experience working in Final Cut Pro 7 and X, and Avid Media Composer 6. Credits include: The Uneducated Boy, Termination, In The Darkness and Rejection.CONTRIBUTOR: Laetitia Cronje - General Manager at Campfire AcademyLaetitia has over 18 years of experience as a field guide trainer at Campfire Academy. Her qualifications include FGASA Level 3 Lead Trails Guide, accredited assessor, First Aid instructor and assessor and registered firearms instructor. Her passion for nature is evident in everything she does and she is currently majoring in Botany and Zoology. CONTRIBUTOR: Adele de Beer -  Manager at Campfire AcademyAdele is a FGASA Level 2 Lead Trails Guide and manages the junior nature conservation program. Her dedication as a teacher has a great impact on the youth. CONTRIBUTOR: Brass Brassett - Student Coordinator at Campfire Academy Brass visited Campfire Academy during 2008 as a volunteer. Within a week she registered for the next FGASA Level 1 course. She passed with flying colours and her passion for nature made her an ideal candidate for the Campfire team. CONTRIBUTOR: Dr. Peter Rogers - Provet Wildlife Services In addition to running a prominent wildlife veterinary practice in Hoedspruit, Dr Peter Rogers is also a specialist in wild animal capture and trans-location. He has previously assisted with the capture and aerial trans-location of various species including white rhino, giraffe, wildebeest, blesbok and cheetah. He’s traveled as far afield as Ivory Coast, Singapore, France and Australia. His most notable achievement was the capture of 20 white rhino from Umfolozi game reserve to the Masai Mara and Lake Nakuru in Kenya.“One could say that rhinos are my strong point, having immobilised more than 1 500 in my career to date,” says Peter.CONTRIBUTOR: ProTrack Anti-Poaching Unit Protrack Anti-Poaching Unit was established in 1992 and was the first private anti-poaching unit in South Africa. Protrack was started with a dream, passion and a shoe string budget. Times were tough, money was scarce but there was no shortage of young men with the same passion to stop the slaughter of wildlife.CONTRIBUTOR: Black Mambas A new anti-poaching combat team launched by the Olifants West Conservation Trust in partnership with Transfontier Africa, the Endangered Wildlife Trust (EWT) and Rhino Mercy. The team operates mainly in the Olifants West Region of the Balule Nature Reserve and has already proven successful as animal snaring in the reserve has decreased dramatically. The programme is also supported by Work for Wildlife, a Department of Public Works programme in conjunction with SANParks.CONTRIBUTOR: Craig Spencer - Balule Nature Reserve Warden Senior ecologist and warden at Olifants West Balule Nature
Reserve. Craig also lectures at various academic institutions, such as Pretoria
University and Cape Peninsula University. Craig has a wealth of conservation
experience gained from working in and running local government conservation
departments, including poverty relief, education, conservation, environmental
planning and anit-poaching. He has also set up and ran a successful Baboon research project in the Western CapeCONTRIBUTOR: Blue Canyon ConservancyBirthchild of Trevor Jordan, conservation and eco-development pioneer – together with neighbours and business partners Dr Scheepers and the Steinberg family, as well as the conservancy’s general manager Tim Parker – Blue Canyon is the newest big game conservancy in Limpopo, and a veritable coup for sustainable lifestyle eco-activity in the area CONTRIBUTOR: Rocking for Rhinos Rocking for Rhinos was formed in Jan 2012 and presented a core group of four individuals. By April 2012, this had grown to include 8 extremely motivated, passionate, and dedicated people. The Rocking for Rhinos group is united by one fundamental reason; the now critical plight of South Africa’s disappearing rhinos. Their ultimate goal is to contribute to the abolishment of rhino poaching by spreading awareness and placing pressure on local and foreign governments to create change.CONTRIBUTOR: Rhino Revolution Based in Hoedspruit, South Africa Rhino Revolution is a community based initiative dedicated to saving the Rhino Species in South Africa and to educate the world at large as to the useless use of Rhino Horn in medicine.

story:
Urban Farming Camp for Kids

CAMP GREEN STAR

Short Summary

Camp Green Star is a kids summer camp where kids get their hands dirty with urban farming.  Camp Green Star is offering its second summer of camp in Madison, Wisconsin.  I, Mary Eberle, and my nephew, Sam, founded the camp to provide kids with hands-on experience gardening and raising chickens.  I earned a permaculture design certificate and am a former biotech patent attorney.  Sam and I have raised chickens and gardened together for many years.

Last summer, the camp was supported by Organic Valley, whose support provided scholarships for kids to attend camp.  This support allowed us to accept all kids, regardless of whether they can pay.  This summer, we ask for your support to help pay for some of our operating expenses.  This will allow us to continue our tradition of providing camp to kids regardless of whether they can pay.

The camp’s goals are to let kids:

  • garden sustainably,
  • grow their leadership skills and self-confidence,
  • see permaculture in action,
  • have fun, and
  • connect with the outdoors and other kids.

What We Need & What You Get

To make Camp Green Star a success this year, we need to raise $6,000.  Your donations will help with the camp’s operating expenses, which include staff wages, gardening supplies, marketing, and insurance.  It costs roughly $9,700 annually to operate camp, with about half of that for staff wages.  We raised about $3,700 of income thus far, leaving $6,000 to raise.

Your generous support helps us continue our tradition of accepting all kids, regardless of whether they can pay.  Around half of campers receive full or partial scholarships to camp.

Our unique perks include thank yous, recipes, 100% organic cotton camp T-shirts, a camp session for adults, a wild edible walk, naming rights to the pizza gardens, business coaching, and more.  Perks start at the $10 donation level.  There is something for everyone!  And all of the perks are consistent with the camp’s sustainability values.

If we don’t reach our entire goal, the funds raised will still be used for operating expenses and scholarships.  However, we will need to drastically reduce some expenses and raise funds elsewhere.

The Impact

Camp Green Star provides kids with

  • a place to run and play
  • support and attention from experienced teachers with a low student to teacher ratio
  • healthy snacks that kids harvest from the garden
  • screen-free time

At Camp Green Star, kids get to

  • connect with nature and the outdoors
  • learn about where their food comes from
  • run and explore the camp's seven-acre space
  • make butter and ice cream by hand

Camp Green Star has

  • 800-foot organic garden designed with permaculture principles
  • chicken coop with a flock of laying hens
  • compost pile and compost worms
  • restored prairie
  • garden tractor that runs on waste vegetable oil
  • rainwater collection system for watering the garden
  • honeybee hives

This is the camp’s second summer.  Last year, parents said that they liked the camp because:

  • That the kids are enjoying the great outdoors
  • The people
  • Enthusiasm for fresh food and great teaching
  • Location, being outside, educational activities, [our daughter] loved the staff too!
  • Focus on sustainability at a kid’s level
  • Involvement with other kids, helping with things in the garden

Risks & Challenges

The main risk and obstacle we face are the financial risk and burnout.  To address the financial risk, as the Camp Director, I, Mary Eberle, meet regularly with a small business advisor from the University of Wisconsin Small Business Development Center.  She helps me plan and budget.  I also actively seek financial support for camp.  For example, last year, I successfully gained support from two strong Wisconsin companies.  Organic Valley Cooperative provided a grant, and Fiskars America provided craft supplies. 

Financial risk is further mitigated by expanding camper enrollment each year.  This is accomplished by referrals, advertising, and media exposure.

To avoid burnout, as the Camp Director, I, Mary Eberle, have planned down time.  I also find time in the garden to be restorative.  It recharges the mind and spirit. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us by spreading the word about our IndieGogo campaign and about Camp Green Star in Madison, Wisconsin.  Also, please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The Amazon Express Expedition is the fulfillment of my personal ambition to be the first person to solo kayak down the entire (4225 mile) length of the Amazon River – and do it faster than anyone ever has before.

But it’s not just about kayaking, or accomplishing some sort of world record. My first visit to the Amazon in 2008 as a part of Team Easy Living (which achieved a still-held, record-setting win in the Great Amazon River Raft Race) was eye-opening.

Team Easy Living, in 2008.

(From left: Captain David Kelly, Carter Johnson, me, and Mike Scales.)

A tiny, adorable girl from a small village deep in the Amazon jungle (about 20 miles downriver from Iquitos, Peru), handed me this baby three-toed sloth.

The Amazon River was both inspiring and incredibly humbling – it is immense, a true force of nature. It is saddening to see all the industrial and human waste that spills into this jewel of the Earth, untreated and unregulated. The tiny girl with the three-toed sloth, along with so many others, are forced to drink the same water that holds these pollutions.

The Amazon is also home to some of the most remote regions in the world, many of them accessible only by water. Thus, few people outside of the local population have been there. Throughout my trip, I’ll be collecting data and samples for the Adventurers and Scientists for Conservation, a group that works with adventurers to access data from some of the world’s most remote areas.

www.adventureandscience.org

These are the things that have moved me to make this journey, and my sincere hope is that many others will help support my expedition.

story:
Meet Nourish Boston

Tess and Masha came to Boston to work in healthcare, and they were both surprised by the prevalence of chronic disease in some of Boston's communities. They started the Nourish Boston project as a response to their experience. In the span of just a few months, Nourish Boston has transformed from an idea to a full-fledged 100% volunteer-run organization.

Nourish Boston connects people across socioeconomic boundaries with local, healthy food sources to improve individual and environmental health. Through classes, online tools, and outreach, we educate community members about the importance of food choices and teach skills that facilitate continued healthy living.

As part of this effort, Nourish Boston and its members support local sustainable farms through education and volunteer work. Human health and environmental health exist in reciprocity, and nurturing the interconnectedness of people and land helps both to thrive.

Get to Know Our Programs

Cooking Classes

To promote healthy eating of fresh, local food, we offer hands-on cooking classes to community members at risk for diet-based chronic diseases. Our experts review the latest scientific articles to ensure that our nutrition curriculum is based in science, not trends.

Outdoor Programs

We all know that diet alone is not sufficient to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Nourish Boston involves community members in a number of outdoor activities, including local nature hikes, visits to farms, and local neighborhood events.

Farm Support

Since Boston’s health – both human and environmental – depends on the health of our farms, we also support local agriculture. We offer local farms access to training for non-profits farms and boards, volunteers during busy seasons, and ways to reach new audiences and supporters

Education

While we feel we can best reach our audience in person through educational courses and events, we also get out the word about healthy living through our blog. We have a team of dedicated volunteers that research the latest topics in human health and sustainability.

What We Need & What You Get

While we are 100% volunteer-run, we still need funds to get our programs off the ground. We plan to use donated food and materials for our cooking and nutrition classes, volunteers to run our outdoor programming, and a wonderful team to connect with local farms.

But, in order to achieve our goals and make our programs a reality, we need the right paperwork in place so that we can be eligible for grants and larger corporate sponsorships. With $1,500, we are confident we will be able to file for 501(c)3 status, secure the necessary legal protections, and launch our first cooking classes by summer 2013.

Notice, we are a very lean organization, and all of these funds will go toward helping us apply for 501(c)3 status and file for liability insurance.

In return for your generous contributions, we want to reciprocate with a number of contributor perks, including recognition on our website and social media sites, access to Nourish Boston events, organic seeds for planting in your garden, and the chance to partner with us as we move forward with our mission.

Your Impact

By contributing to the Nourish Boston, you become a key member of our community and a valuable addition to our project.

Your donation is key to helping us acheive our mission, which is two-fold:

  • Educating community members about the importance of food choices and teaching skills that facilitate continued healthy living
  • Supporting local sustainable farms through education and volunteer work

As far as real-world applications go, you'll help us acheive 501(c)3 non-profit status, enabling us to launch our cooking courses and create outdoor programming. While doing so, you'll also show your support for the local Massachussetts business ecosystem.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because now might not be the right time for you to donate, that doesn't mean you can't get involved with Nourish Boston.

  • Facebook - "Like Us" on Facebook
  • Twitter - Follow Us @NourishBoston
  • Blog - Keep up with our blog, we promise, it's good!
  • Email - Email info@nourishboston.com for more information about our classes or for ways to get involved
  • Share our campaign on Indiegogo - the more people who know about our cause, the better!

Since we're just starting out and do not have 501(c)3 status yet, donations made via indiegogo will not be tax deductible.

story:
Our Story

The EarthTeam Environmental Network, a non-profit environmental education provider serving low income middle schools and high schools throughout San Francisco’s East Bay Area, is looking for some support of its Green Screen multimedia program. The Green Screen program consists of 15 Bay Area teens that meet weekly in Richmond to produce multimedia content related to environmental issues in the Bay Area. Under the mentorship of the EarthTeam multimedia director, the students learn the technical points of researching, writing, shooting, producing, and editing video segments for upload onto the Green Screen YouTube channel. Local TV station KCRT also runs half-hour programs composed of these segments. Click here to learn more about the Green Screen students.


Asthma is a chronic condition affecting the lungs, causing inflammation inside the airways, as well as bronchospasm (constriction of the muscle around the airways). The cause of asthma is unknown. Those with asthma often have certain “triggers” that lead to attacks or asthma symptoms.  The Asthma rates for children in Richmond are some of the highest in the state of California.  However, the issue is not just in Richmond, but the San Francisco Bay Area as a whole.  In fact there are heavily polluted sections of San Francisco, Oakland, and Richmond, which have become known as the “toxic triangle.”  Because the issue affects so many people in the community, The Green Screen students feel like it is the most important topic for them to address in their next video.  The Green Screen wants to focus on triggers of asthma, including vehicle pollution, cigarette smoke, pesticides, and household hazardous waste products. 


The proposed video will build on the short PSA that Green Screen students produced last fall. This PSA, which was funded by As You Sow, highlighted pesticides as a trigger for asthma. This video has been featured by San Francisco-based youth group, Smashcast.


The Green Screen creates content by teens, and for teens. In order to engage their peers, they will present the asthma issue in the Bay Area as a compelling narrative short film, appealing to teens and young people, and empowering them to take action in their local communities to improve air quality and health.

The Impact

The asthma video will be shown on KCRT local TV, as well as published to YouTube and the Green Screen website to highlight the issue of air quality in the Bay Area, and empower young viewers to make a difference. Students involved in production will learn the facts about asthma and air quality, and throw their own spin on the subject to bring it to Bay Area teens.

What We Need & What You Get

A very special donor has agreed to put in a $500 donation if we can raise $2000, providing us with the money necessary to provide stipends for the Green Screen team, as well as a working budget for the Green Screen program director to assist in shooting, editing, and post production.

Other Ways You Can Help

Pass our information along to anyone who supports teens in spreading their green message!

on triggers of asthma, including vehicle pollution, cigarette smoke, pesticides,
and household hazardous waste products.  

The proposed video will build on the short PSA that Green Screen 
students produced last fall. This PSA, which was funded by As You Sow, 
highlighted pesticides as a trigger for asthma. This video has been 
featured by San Francisco-based youth group, Smashcast.

The Green Screen creates content by teens, and for teens. In
order to engage their peers, they will present the asthma issue in the Bay Area
as a compelling narrative short film, appealing to teens and young people, and
empowering them to take action in their local communities to improve air
quality and health.

The Impact
The asthma video will be shown on KCRT local TV, as well as published to YouTube and the Green Screen website to highlight the issue of air quality in the Bay Area, and empower young viewers to make a difference. Students involved in production will learn the facts about asthma and air quality, and throw their own spin on the subject to bring it to Bay Area teens.

What We Need & What You Get
A very special donor has agreed to put in a $500 donation if we can raise $2000, providing us with the money necessary to provide stipends for the Green Screen team, as well as a working budget for the Green Screen program director to assist in shooting, editing, and post production.

Other Ways You Can Help
Pass our information along to anyone who supports teens in spreading their green message!

story:
Our Story

It's as simple as gardeners helping gardeners.

The Regrow Together Projectworks to connect gardeners all over the United States with fellow green thumbs who have been impacted by tornadoes, wildfires, floods, hurricanes and other natural disasters. While other organizations see to the important work of meeting immediate needs for medical care, food and shelter, we see it as our duty to bring hope to our fellow gardeners and help them recapture the joy and fulfillment of the home garden.

The Regrow Together Project is about more than rebuilding, it's about strengthening shattered communities by bringing community gardens to neighborhoods devastated by storm damage. It's about restoring a sense of pride and dignity where they have been stripped away.

The Regrow Together Project is supported by an ever-growing network of volunteers around the country who devote their time and resources to be harbingers of hope when thinks look bleak.

Nature offers us a chance to grow, but it is up to us to Regrow Together.

What We Are Doing

Simply repairing a building does not make it home. The Regrow Together Project stands to help thousands of people impacted by natural disasters across the country by making their houses and neighborhoods feel like home again. It's bigger than planting a garden, it's supporting rebuilding efforts by cleaning up gardens and landscapes that have been damaged or destroyed.

 

Why We Need Your Help

This fundraising campaign is to help us prepare the paperwork and go through the process of becoming a recognized nonprofit 501(c)3 organization in the United States. Such a designation will make it easier for us to receive donations as they will be tax deductible (within the limits of the law). It will further enable us to apply for and secure grants and other funding sources to continue and expand our work.  All money received will be solely used for the purpose of creating the legal nonprofit entity and running it.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate every contribution, but there are other ways to help. Please use the sharing tools on this page to tell your friends, coworkers, garden clubs and family members about Regrow Together. With your help we will make a tremendous difference in the lives of those who feel helpless in the wake of disaster.

story:
Short Summary


A few  years ago, two engineering graduates grew frustrated with the lack of indoor power outlets for people to power devices at public facilities and came-up with an idea to build an outdoor table with a built-in  solar power supply.

The SolGreen Evodia SmartTable is an outdoor table that allows users to enjoy comfortable outdoor seating and plug devices (Laptops, cellphones Tablets) into AC outlet plugs that are built into the table, with the  SmartTable Mini you can run electronics off of 100% renewable solar energy for 24 hrs. This table can be set-up to work anyplace there is sun, even in the middle of a remote Desert. Our SolGreen SmartTable also has built-in weather sensing technology and an auto power-shutdown system to track bad weather conditions and send alerts to weather reporting agencies. Over the past few years we have built this concept into a working prototype, patented our design, released and sold this outdoor Solar Table to a few universities.

 SolGreen Solutions Successful Milestones

Over the past few years my business partner and I have continued to work our daytime jobs as we grew  our co-founding company, SolGreen Solutions, into a quality manufacturing institution.  We incorporated SolGreen Solutions in 2009; it's a sustainable energy research and development company that builds sustainable technologies for everyday, on the go users.  My business partner and I have personally funded all of our operating and development cost thus far and we have successfully completed many milestones including (1) designed and built  a full working prototype for the 100% Solar Table; (2) successfully tested the technology with Arizona State University, (3) applied for and received a US patent for the technology (4) manufactured and built two commercial Solar SmartTables, for Bowie State University and received rave reviews of the technology (5) introduced a new product line (Evodia Mini) that has a current backlog of three units already sold to some major universities, (6) registered our company Trademark with the USPTO, (7) contracted with a marketing team to push sales of the Evodia Mini.   

NOW We need your help to keep moving, as we introduce our next design and to make this a commercially successful product. 

Our Next Project-  Evodia Mini SmartTable

A major risk of the large Evodia SmartTable is the fact that it is extremely durable and heavy weighing over 1100 pounds, additionally the turnaround time is long and the logistics are expensive, and that's why we are building a smaller, and more cost effective model that will have a much faster more efficient manufacturing turnaround time. Our new SmartTable is titled the Evodai Mini SmartTable and it has all the same wonderful features of the larger Evodia, but it's lighter and much more affordable for us to manufacture and sell to our customers.

 

Why We Need Your Support

As with most start-ups we underestimated how much it would take to get it to a profitable state, and we underestimated the difficulty of getting credit. Now we are right there, we have pushed past many milestones and we have some demand for both our legacy and our new design (Mini SmartTable), additionally we have built up a backlog to several universities in the US and Canada, however, we still need funds to fill these backlogs of our new release.
In the End, we will make a decent profit and we will be able to apply for the banking credit we need to move forward with production after we have completed the sale of these three units, however we currently need money (seed money) to complete these first three units that we have Purchase Orders for, and to pay for the  onetime costly molds needed to build the first Evodia Mini Prototype. We have already built the molds and three units and now we desperately need funding for the remaining balances to purchase the Fiberglass and Steel for the Units that have already been sold.


What You Get For Your Contribution

In addition to supporting a small, minority-owned start-up, your contribution will also help us compete on a global scale and develop emerging solar technologies that everyday consumers can use.

The Impact

With support from you, SolGreen Solutions will be able to introduce a much needed green technology to  Universities in the US and Canada for users like you to enjoy.  Not only is this green technology a much needed assets on today's stressed power grid system, but it will also allow for a much cleaner and enjoyable setting for thousands of people just like you to power  on the go device from any outdoor remote location 24/7.

"As the campus moves forward with optimizing its level of sustainability, the Solar Powered SmartTables purchased from SolGreen Solutions is another great step forward. These tables are happily used by faculty and students alike!"- MaryAnn Jackson-Student Green Ambassador Bowie State University

The  continued development of the SolGreen SmartTable Mini will:

  • Create sustainable jobs in the clean energy market.
  • Introduce a  quality commercial  product to everyday users like yourself.
  • Encourage more developments in the solar energy and sustainable market.

Risks & Challenges

As with most start-ups we underestimated how much it would take to get it to a profitable state. Now we are right there, we have pushed past many milestones and we have some demand for both our legacy and our new design (Mini SmartTable), additionally we have built up a backlog to several universities in the US and Canada, however, we still need funds to fill these backlogs of our new release.

In the End, we will make a decent profit with the sale of these three units, however we currently need money (seed money) to complete these first three units that we have Purchase Orders for. We have already purchased half of the equipment and now we desperately need funding for the remaining balances to purchase the Fiberglass and Steel for the Units that have already been sold.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you are not in a place to contribute financially, we ask that you please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools, links that have been sent to you to share with your friends and family!

And that's all there is to it, thank you for your support.

story:
What We are Doing:

17th International Symposium on Education for Peace, Justice, and Human Rights

We are ten students from the Technical University of Berlin (Technische Universität Berlin-TUB), the Faculty of Humanities and Education. We seek to participate in the forthcoming 17th International Symposium for Peace, Justice and Human Rights, which will take place in Corvallis, Oregon, in the US in the summer of 2015.
And We Need Your Help!

In this friendly American university town, know for its advanced environmental politics and practices, we will meet and learn from some 50 other students from China, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Mexico and the United States.

Together with them, we will be working under the motto:

“Climate Change: A Global Problem, Human Solutions—Challenges for Intercultural Education”. Discussions will concentrate on how educational practices in different countries can respond effectively to climate change. We will discuss such questions as, What role do the industrialized countries play in this process? Which countries or regions of the global South have particularly suffered from industrial development? We want to also take a hard, critical look at our own individual patterns and behaviours of consumption, which sustain economic growth. We will explore our own ecological “footprint”. This symposium will build on the “peace education workshops” which began in 1982 in Denmark. There, professors from TUB came together with Dutch, Polish and Danish colleagues. Traditionally since then, these symposiums have taken place every two years. We want to continue participating in these essential symposiums, and strengthening this tradition.

However, to attend, we are largely dependent on your support, and that of many others. Only with this support is our participation possible!

With your support, we will become “multipliers” as part of the global movement against accelerating climate change. And so we are asking for your support in our various fundraising activities. You can inform yourself more about the project on our Facebook (Link attached below).

 

The voices of some participants:

Lena: “This year’s theme, “Climate Change” is particularly close to my heart because as a teacher of international students, often with a multi-cultural background, I am always conscious of how we discuss this topic. But we do it from a very one-sided cultural perspective, particularly here in Germany. However, because climate change is so clearly a global phenomenon, we must learn how to discuss this from a global perspective, and together, internationally, find the right answers with teachers from other countries.”

Stefanie: “In Norway, for example, there has been an extended debate about the use of palm oil, while in Germany we waste our time talking about waste separation and re-cycling more than in almost any other country. I ask myself, why is that? What mechanisms actually work to slow down and reduce climate change? My friends from Poland, Croatia, Syria, Lebanon, Turkey and Nigeria can’t understand this discussion. Nor do they bother with waste separation, because they come from countries that have entirely different problems. However these countries are sometime the [ecological??] victims of “our” way of life, and of the significant ecological “footprints” of the Western world. Therefore it is so very important that we speak to and learn from educators from all parts of the world, from different backgrounds and cultures.”

Intercultural education is both forward looking, and an effective pedagogic platform. Teachers are among society’s most effective “multipliers”. That is, their individual efforts in the classroom are quickly multiplied in society through their students. Teachers are trained to raise awareness of the issue of climate change by asking students questions and exploring the possible answers with them. This pedagogic inter-action raises the consciousness of the students to think about making the necessary changes in their own lifestyle and habits of consumption, habits which can work to slowdown climate change. An understanding of the problem is a fundamental prerequisite for positive change.


We want to become Multipliers in Germany!

The symposium is able to look back and and build up with its long tradition. It has been held every two years in different parts and places in the world. Because of the news and political controversies surrounding the discussions of drastic climate changes of an human nature, this year’s symposium is dedicated to understanding better how education can respond to the challenges of changing lifestyles and behaviours which contribute to climate change.

At the symposium we will meet with students and teachers from the countries noted above. With them we will discuss these difficult issues, and no doubt there will be some heated arguments about how to sustainably change something important is all of our hearts and minds.

However, we can only make this vital journey to Oregon with your financial help, and that of others. Naturally it is a costly thing to make such a long journey. But we are so very eager to share our attitudes towards climate change, and to learn with and from others who also wish to make a positive difference.

We Look Forward to Your Support!


If you want to make a donation but you don´t have Paypal:


Recipient: Gesellschaft von Freunden der Technischen Universität Berlin e.V.
Credit institution: Berliner Volksbank
Reference: Oregon
BIC: BEVODEBBXXX
IBAN: DE62 1009 0000 7270 0040 02

story:
Summary

Can you help us develop a brand new bee friendly wildlife garden at the front of our Bassett Street Community Hub?
Our bee population is decreasing year or year, causing deep concern in crop pollenation. Bassett Streets new wildflower area will provide our bees with a safe space in the heart of urban South Wigston, Leicestershire.
Working with local children and local police we want to fund a brand new wildflower area at the front of our building, this area will provide a safe space for bees while also providing the residents of Bassett Street with a new colourful garden area.

We are looking for £500 to enable planting and new large troughs for wildflowers. That means we need just 25 people to donate £20 each to make our garden a reality.

Every person who donates will be listed on a sign in our new garden as a friend of our bees.

The work needed in clearing current planting beds and planting new wildfowers will be led by children and local police from the community, making this a community led project that benefits everyone in South Wigston.

Other Ways You Can Help

If cannot donate money but would still like to support our project we can also accept bee friendly plant donations for the garden. Just phone us on 0116 2784230

story:
The Aquarium Steampunk Reading Room is the largest private, independent, green marketing research & reference library in the country.

We are seeking assistance to keep the space open, to keep up the rent.

It is a project of the Environmental Library Fund founded in 1984. The library

found a physical space in 2010. It has been at this location in Norwalk, Connecticut since then.

The collection chronicles the history of the environmental movement as a pop culture phenomena, focused on assisting green businesses and start ups position their new products and services in a competitive marketplace.

The Collection

Present are tens of thousands of books, magazines, other periodicals, technical journals, DVDs,.. constantly updated to remain current.

  • Green Design & Architecture
  • Green Business & Marketing
  • Nuclear Power & Electric Vehicles 
  • Alternative Politics & Activism
  • New Energy & Science
  • Style, Trends & Fashion
  • Art, Pop & Fringe Culture
  • Alternative Health & Medicine
  • World Religions & Spirituality
  • Bioelectromagnetism

Why we need your support

Rent in Fairfield County is expensive. While already partially funded by silent contributors, it is no longer enough to cover all its expenses.

The library is open to the public by appointment. It is a permanent collection, materials do not circulate, are always available in their integrity to researchers traveling long distances to come visit.

Who benefits

Countless companies, groups, activists, organizers have benefited greatly from the intellectual environment provided by the space. Unlike surfing the net, the physical experience of holding printed materials, touching photographs, inspires. 

The Aquarium was slang for think tank at the KGB, the old Soviet Union spy agency.

The entire space is lit with daylight LED tubes.

How to visit

We have a website and a facebook page:
www.the-aquarium.org
www.facebook.com/steampunkreadingroom

We are located on:
10 Knight Street
Norwalk, CT 
(This address is not used to receive mail)

Call for an appointment
203-227-2065

Mailing address
Remy Chevalier
Environmental Library Fund
25 Newtown Turnpike
Weston, CT 06883

Please donate what you can.
Keep the Aquarium open!
(The perks are per year.)

We have a website and a facebook page:www.the-aquarium.orgwww.facebook.com/steampunkreadingroom
We are located on:10 Knight StreetNorwalk, CT (This address is not used to receive mail)Call for an appointment203-227-2065Mailing addressRemy ChevalierEnvironmental Library Fund25 Newtown TurnpikeWeston, CT 06883
Please donate what you can.Keep the Aquarium open!(The perks are per year.)

story:
“The best time to plant a tree was twenty years ago. The second best time is now.”

For centuries, the abundant forests of Haiti have been depleted. The growing problem of deforestation threatens the nation’s environment, energy security, agriculture and, most importantly, the quality of life of its citizens.  A Dollar a Tree for Haiti’s mission is to restore the wealth and well-being of the Haiti, one tree at a time.

Support Us:

It’s simple: For every $1 dollar donated to A Dollar A Tree For Haiti, one tree is planted in Haiti. Founded in 2012 by the former Ambassador of Haiti to the United States, Raymond Joseph, this nonprofit organization seeks to rebuild the country by physically replanting it.  With decades of experience working in the public policy and affairs of Haiti, Ambassador Joseph saw that reforestation could be a simple solution to a complex problem. The continuous depletion of the nation’s trees has led to mass erosion that has had a negative ripple effect reaching Haiti’s environment, economy, and people. The simple act of planting a tree today, nurturing it through growth, and preserving it for the future can reverse the effects of the near-destruction of the land and begin a positive cycle of prosperity.

A Dollar A Tree For Haiti provides a holistic approach to reversing the negative effects of deforestation by not just planting new trees, but lifting up the Haitian community in the process. A Dollar A Tree For Haiti’s unique approach to reforesting the country includes: partnering with the Haitian Diaspora, committing itself to transparency, working with outside organizations, and continually encouraging economic growth and development for the people and the nation. Specifically, with the help of and employment of the local landowners to plant trees and cultivate the land. In turn, the reforestation effort will generate revenue for the Haitian people and boost the economy. Donations will have an impact on Haiti’s physical infrastructure now and in the future!

History of Deforestation:

Deforestation has been a part of Haiti’s history going back hundreds of years. From colonial-era environmental abuse to the modern day lack of policy aimed to protect Haiti's physical instrastructure, the source of the current crisis is difficult to isolate. While the root causes and perpetuating actors of deforestation are valuable to understand, the path leading to a prosperous future is the most important consideration for A Dollar A Tree For Haiti. 

Consequences of Deforestation:

Deforestation of Haiti has resulted in severe deleterious consequences. Dams, irrigation systems, roads, and coastal marine ecosystems are also greatly affected by the erosion caused from lack of trees. The productivity of the land and the droughts which come as a consequence of erosion have resulted in parts of Haiti approaching total desertification. This is a factor that has led to political instability, poverty, food scarcity, and vulnerability to hurricanes, lack of development, poor infrastructure, deaths, and more.  

A Dollar A Tree For Haiti's First Tree Planting Success:

A Dollar A Tree For Haiti's first tree planting excursion in the mountains of Kikwa, Kafou Badgio, Godet, Viard I and Viard II, in the mountains beyond Kenscoff.

story:
How many students does it take to change a lightbulb?

thirty-seven!

But Energy Corps isn’t just changing one light bulb, we’re looking to change them all.  So we’re searching our campus for opportunities to upgrade Cornell's facilities with the newest energy efficient technology.  

Every year, students are given the opportunity to evaluate project payback, submit investment recommendations, and assist with implementation.  What's more, Energy Corps has developed our members into the leaders of tomorrows by building upon valuable teamwork skills beyond the classroom walls.

We are on our way to saving $38,000 and eliminating 24.2 tons of carbon emissions (and that's only this year)!

With your amazing support, Energy Corps will be able to—

  • Provide energy audit training for our project ID and management teams
  • Purchase power monitors and light meters to assess buildings around campus
  • Further our research on t-bulbs and smart plugs
  • Begin funding our trip to the 2014 Verge conference in San Francisco

Our organization brings together talent and enthusiasm from all across campus in order to work towards a common interest furthering Cornell University's energy efficiency initiative and promoting environmental sustainability.

Any size donation is welcome and greatly appreciated.  Your contributions will help sustain Energy Corps’ commitment to educating future energy & sustainability leaders and preserving the planet.

LOVE WHAT WE DO?

Share our enthusiasm by posting to Facebook & Twitter and sharing with your family & friends.

to learn more about our history and the projects we have completed, check out our site @ www.rso.cornell.edu/energycorps

story:
The Flintstone Car Team aims to travel to the Ciclovida farm in northeastern Brazil to build a pedal-electric hybrid “Flintstone car” and a windmill irrigation system. The Flintstone Car will serve as a mobile off-grid power generator for Ciclovida to show their film in rural communities far from conventional power grids. The windmill irrigation system will provide year round water to the farm, located in a desert region of Brazil.

Ciclovida is a film, a team, and an international movement started by permaculturists, artists and activist farmers, based out of Northeastern Brazil. Their central purpose is to foster a new relationship with the land, which they achieve through promoting small scale agriculture, education, and access to heirloom vegetable seeds.


Two of the Ciclovida farmers, Inacio and Ivania, recognized the need to develop an heirloom seed bank, so they set out on a 6,000 mile bicycle journey across South America collecting seeds and building personal relationships with farmers.

They filmed their journey with the help of friends from the United States who eventually compiled this footage into the documentary Ciclovida: Lifecycle. In April 2011 they went on tour in the USA to promote this film using a bike powered movie theater built by Scott Guzman, the founder of Flintstone Car.

The bike generator system has successfully powered 25 film screenings in 12 states across the country, and is still in use around New England today.



In January 2012, Scott travelled to Barra do Lemme as part of the Ciclovida Encontro. During this trip, a group of 50+ people from the US and Brazil participated in projects on the farm, including the construction of a rainwater catchment cistern, healing house, bike generator and windmill irrigation system. Due to time constraints, the windmill was not completed, and in need of additional components beyond those initially located in Brazil.

The Brazil bike generator is fully operational, but large and immobile, which makes it impossible for them to show their film outside of their farm.


Four members of the Flintstone Car team want to return to the Ciclovida farm in January 2013 to complete the projects that were started one year before.

The total estimated cost to complete these projects is $4000. We hope to raise $3500 of this money through Indiegogo and the remainder from our personal funds as well as a local fundraising campaign. 100% of donations will go toward the project expenses listed below:

  • Materials to build the Flintstone car:  $1400

  • 3 bicycles, welder, electric drive Motor, Wiring, Controller, fasteners, battery, steel, hardware, chains, cables, lights, brakes, paint

  • Windmill Irrigation System: $1000

    • Concrete, Steel structure, Water pump, rotor and blade material, bearings, water tank, water pipe, tail and brake assembly.  

  • Consumables in Brazil: $700

    • Tools, fuel, welding rod, grinding wheels, food and water

  • Transportation: $900 

  • Total Project Cost: $4000

This is a Fiscally sponsored project of Worcester Earn-a-Bike, 501c-3. All donations are tax deductible.


If you can’t make a donation, but would like to help, please share this page with your friends.

story:
This past summer may feel like a long time ago, the memories we have and the relationships we forged on our Birthright trip last with us until this day.  Unfortunately, we all remember the passing of our dear friend Josh Schwabenbauer shortly after our Birthright trip. We have honored Josh’s memory in different ways over the months and we come to our group with a meaningful opportunity to honor him once more at a special time of year.

There is a minor Jewish holiday called Tu B'Shvat (the 15th day of the month of Shvat), which occurs this year on January 26, and it is the "New Year of the Trees."  One of the main projects of an organization called the JNF (Jewish National Fund - http://www.jnf.org/about-jnf/, which was started in the early 1900's) is to plant trees in Israel (they have planted over 250 million so far!).  It has beautified and protected the land, and has changed the landscape of Israel in many different ways.  Unfortunately, over the past few years, Israel has experienced a few forest fires, some of them destroying significant amounts of forest land in Israel.  One of the reasons that it was so destructive was the fact that Israel was not properly equipped with firefighters and methods of fighting these terrible fires.  

As we approach this holiday, we think it might be an appropriate idea to plant trees in Josh’s memory.  While these trees can never be who Josh was, they can grow, they can be strong, they can protect and they can shine brightly in the landscape of the Land of Israel, the same way Josh did to his friends, family and nation. 

While Josh still remains in our thoughts, we know that his family still mourns his death on a daily basis.  We must not forget that while Josh was a loving brother, son, cousin and friend, he was also a dedicated lifeguard and firefighter.  He cared about others, the way all of us dream of.   

We created this page, with a goal of $500 for us to raise.  This will be enough money to plant 100 trees in his memory.  We hope that all of you will be able to join us on this project. 

Sincerely,

David and Dahlia

story:
Shark-Con

As avid scuba divers and ocean conservationists, we wanted to create an event where like minded people could gather as a community. This community has the power to inspire the general public and educate them on the importance of ocean conservation. The visionaries for this project come from a background working in the marine science field and in AZA accredited aquariums. We have seen the power of educating the public and have also seen how powerful an experience can be when its entertaining.

Shark-Con will have an amazing line-up of speakers like Dr. Eugenie Clark, stars of Discovery and Nat Geo channels, and other professionals speaking on conservation issues.  Scuba experts, special dive trips, robotic sharks, demonstrations, art, films, and more will make this an event like no other! Together we could bring national and international attention to the need for ocean conservation and marine research.

To get Shark-Con started, we need to raise $5000. Once we are there we will be ready to book exhibitors. Commitments from speakers have already been given and they are ready to get here as soon as we give the word.
 
Check out our video!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1wnQx-VX9o4&...
 

Help save sharks by becoming a Shark-Con sponsor!

Your donation will help us bring Shark-Con to Tampa in May 2014!

What You Get!

  • $2 - Sharky Friend
  • $5 - Shark-Con Friend and Thank you!
  • $15 - you get Shark-con stickers - the logo is super sool!
  • $30 - you get a Shark-Con shirt - the logo is super cool!
  • $75 - you get a Shark-Con shirt and a mention in the program
  • $200 - back stage VIP pass to meet different convention speakers
  • $1000 - official Sponsor status with a half page ad in the program, 4 VIP passes, and a mention before a speaker as a sponsor of that Q & A / presentation

Go to the Contribute button on the bottom and click on it!

The Impact

Shark-Con will inspire a new generation of young minds to protect our ocean and its resources

We will bring education and solutions to conservation issues to public light.

We will have a great time while learning and networking with other ocean enthusiasts.

We will get to experience cutting edge scuba equipment and learn about great places to dive

We will be able to make a difference by donating proceeds from Shark-Con to ocean conservation organizations!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute or if you can pass this along to as many people as you can! Share us on Facebook! Like our Facebook page http://www.facebook.com/SharkCon

story:
Donations are for:

- Legally binding registration in the local register of associations. (<150$)

- Costs for the activation and deployment of the Web server.(<90$)

- The further development of a herbarium.

 


Help us to build up a collection of native, cultivated plants and its wild relatives from extra-tropical regions. Help to protect crops, weeds and vegetables against contamination by GMO´s !


We like to network against GMO´s and pesticides and hope to offer more and more sustainable solutuions, documented to the world per sozial-media. First step is to build up a network and seed banks for local native weeds and vegetables. Further we will beginn to exchange seeds with other GMO-free communities and institutes all around the world.

 

 

 

Genetically modified seeds and food spiral out of control

The launch of a non profit Organisation. A herbarium with seed banks which will help to collect and protect native weeds and vegetabes for further generations:

  • Boycott of genetically modified organism.
  • Total waiver of any pesticides and herbicides.
  • No monocultures.

Our goal is to ensure plant and spezies diversity in the existing ecosystem.

Return to the natural, regional production

If we do not want to ruin our planet:

  • No international mass production under questionable circumstances..
  • Use natural circumstances. Produce, supply and do no harm to your environment!


Other Ways You Can Help

Share our link with your friends, family, and co-workers. If you are interested in the environment and sustainable agriculture, please help us make this small step forward a reality.
