story:
Short Summary

  • Established in 1991, Texas Campaign for the Environment (TCE) is one of the largest grassroots environmental organizations in Texas with more than 40,000 members. We work on sustained, strategic campaigns to reduce waste, improve recycling and keep toxic chemicals out of our land, air and water. What sets us apart from most other groups is our amazing staff of door-to-door organizers who care passionately about protecting our planet and work hard every day, educating and talking face-to-face with tens of thousands of Texans every year. We have members from Amarillo to McAllen; El Paso to Texarkana. Through the canvass, Texans write 85,000 letters a year to decision-makers in corporations or in state and local government to provide the consumer or constituent pressure that makes polluters and elected officials pay attention. 

  • Rayovac is one of the four largest battery makers in the U.S. market and they tell their customers here to throw their batteries in the trash - but to recycle them in Canada and Europe. Landfilling or incinerating batteries means those resources are wasted when they could be recycled, and disposal can leak toxic chemicals into our environment. Unlike Duracell, Energizer and Panasonic, Rayovac has refused to make any public commitments on recycling, especially for alkaline batteries. Wisconsin-based Rayovac is the last holdout in a battery industry that is starting to support recycling programs for alkalines and rechargeable household batteries.

    Our goal is to work with manufacturers and retailers to establish convenient recycling programs, not just in Texas, but all over the U.S. We are so close to being one step closer to victory, and your support is needed more than ever to send committed recycling activists to Madison to get the word out with our local allies. 
  • Texas Campaign for the Environment (TCE) has won many victories in the past by attracting national media coverage around our theatrical, creative direct actions targeting corporate polluters. Wisconsin-based Rayovac is the only major battery maker that does not publicly support household battery recycling, so we are pressuring the company to take responsibility for the products it creates. Rayovac’s parent company Spectrum is a corporate sponsor of a festival in Madison on July 26 and we plan on sending a clear message to the world that the company should not be lagging behind the other mayor battery makers on battery recycling. 
  • Over 3 billion batteries are thrown away in the U.S. each year, including 150 million rechargeable batteries -  250 million pounds worth. Once Rayovac changes their policies, all of the major battery makers will be publicly on record supporting U.S. battery recycling. This will provide the momentum to get battery recycling legislation passed in key states and a nation-wide battery recycling system in place. Retail stores and local government facilities will serve as drop-offs for these products without being burdened with the cost of  shipping and processing them. Making the producers responsible for recycling also helps them internalize the costs of waste and gives them an incentive to design greener, better products!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We have 4 campaign vehicles that will drive 20 TCE activists from Houston, Austin and Dallas - 2000 miles round trip to Madison for a cost of $1780. We’re going to need $1000 for food and lodging at state parks and we’re budgeting $820 for additional campaign materials. For maximum impact we plan to spend $1,000 for a two hour plane flyover banner! Finally, $1500 will pay for the lost time of our canvassers who spend 40 hours making the trip.
  • While in Madison we will hold an action at a festival sponsored by Rayovac’s parent company, Spectrum Brands, to raise awareness and get news coverage about their irresponsible policies and in order to convince them to change. We’ve done this before and it works, so please help with whatever you can.

  • Anyone who gives $15 or more will get a virtual or actual postcard from the trip so you can see what we are doing to put the pressure on Rayovac to step up to the plate on battery recycling. Other perks include an “I Recycle, I Vote” bumper stickers for all who give $25.
    For a $50 gift, you’ll receive our mini-Recycling Guide magnet. If you give $100, we send you an actual postcard from the trip.

    •  

  • For $250 you will get an actual postcard and a beautiful 4-color TCE “When we heal the earth, we heal ourselves” t-shirt that you can wear with Texas pride - even if you are not from Texas! Our $500 donors will get an actual postcard AND a SURPRISE gift from Madison. Those who step up at the $1000 level will receive an actual postcard AND SURPRISE gifts from Madison AND Texas. (We hope the suspense doesn’t kill you!)

  • If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will cut out the plane banner flyover first. Then we would ask the canvassers to participate and forego a day’s wages. After that we’d probably spend less on food by eating lots of rice and beans. Please support us with as much as you can and share with your friends so we can do this right and make household battery recycling a reality in the U.S!

The Impact

  • Single-use batteries are a perfect example of products “designed for the dump.” We envision a Texas and a planet free from pollution, which means we need to re-think the way we design the products we consume. “Disposable” batteries don’t make any sense when producers can easily design batteries and battery containing products to be recyclable and sustainable instead. Winning our campaign is one step closer to making sustainability a reality.

  • In 2003 we convinced Dell to stop using prison labor to recycle electronics and embrace producer takeback recycling by dressing up in striped inmate outfits at the huge Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

    We got Apple to set up electronics recycling by demonstrating at the Apple Headquarters, MacWorld Expo and the office of former Vice President and Apple Board member Al Gore. We played a leadership role in the passage of a local ordinance to keep fracking out of Dallas parks and neighborhoods by building a 15-foot tall mock drilling rig to use at protests. Our “bag monster” actions built momentum for the passage of local ordinances on single-use bags in Austin and Dallas. Texas has more people live in cities with ordinances on single-use bags than any state except California - that doesn’t happen by accident! You can read more about our many victories on our website, here.

  • Whenever we host rallies or protests to advance our campaigns, we go through training and planning processes to make sure we are operating within the law as we exercise our First Amendment rights. Our protests are never ugly, profane or violent. We practice positive messaging so that the companies we are targeting can transition with us into communicating and implementing real solutions.

Risks & Challenges

  • We’ve got grassroots, face-to-face organizing down… Although we have gone on many road trips, this is our first crowdfunding endeavor to support an action of this scale! 93% of our funding comes from small individual contributions. We are transitioning into more online organizing - like this - building a new website and will be piloting the use of mobile devices in our field canvassing. Part of this campaign is also to let Rayovac know we are coming and that we have public support, so please share this online with everyone you can!
  • We have shown through campaign after campaign that we can confront any challenge with flexibility and energy on our way to victory! In the past two months, we’ve had one-on-one conversations with powerful figures including Rayovac executives and Walmart’s new CEO who are starting to listen to us. If anybody can make this road trip happen, it’s TCE and our supporters.
  • Please share this campaign with as many friends as possible. And while you’re at it, switch to using rechargeable batteries in all devices you use! Landfills and incinerators are a problem for our communities and with smarter design and recycling infrastructure, we can reduce, reuse and recycle making them virtually obsolete and unnecessary.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Short Summary 
Established in 1991, Texas Campaign for the Environment (TCE) is one of the largest grassroots environmental organizations in Texas with more than 40,000 members. We work on sustained, strategic campaigns to reduce waste, improve recycling and keep toxic chemicals out of our land, air and water. What sets us apart from most other groups is our amazing staff of door-to-door organizers who care passionately about protecting our planet and work hard every day, educating and talking face-to-face with tens of thousands of Texans every year. We have members from Amarillo to McAllen; El Paso to Texarkana. Through the canvass, Texans write 85,000 letters a year to decision-makers in corporations or in state and local government to provide the consumer or constituent pressure that makes polluters and elected officials pay attention. 

Rayovac is one of the four largest battery makers in the U.S. market and they tell their customers here to throw their batteries in the trash - but to recycle them in Canada and Europe. Landfilling or incinerating batteries means those resources are wasted when they could be recycled, and disposal can leak toxic chemicals into our environment. Unlike Duracell, Energizer and Panasonic, Rayovac has refused to make any public commitments on recycling, especially for alkaline batteries. Wisconsin-based Rayovac is the last holdout in a battery industry that is starting to support recycling programs for alkalines and rechargeable household batteries.

Our goal is to work with manufacturers and retailers to establish convenient recycling programs, not just in Texas, but all over the U.S. We are so close to being one step closer to victory, and your support is needed more than ever to send committed recycling activists to Madison to get the word out with our local allies. 

Texas Campaign for the Environment (TCE) has won many victories in the past by attracting national media coverage around our theatrical, creative direct actions targeting corporate polluters. Wisconsin-based Rayovac is the only major battery maker that does not publicly support household battery recycling, so we are pressuring the company to take responsibility for the products it creates. Rayovac’s parent company Spectrum is a corporate sponsor of a festival in Madison on July 26 and we plan on sending a clear message to the world that the company should not be lagging behind the other mayor battery makers on battery recycling. 

Over 3 billion batteries are thrown away in the U.S. each year, including 150 million rechargeable batteries -  250 million pounds worth. Once Rayovac changes their policies, all of the major battery makers will be publicly on record supporting U.S. battery recycling. This will provide the momentum to get battery recycling legislation passed in key states and a nation-wide battery recycling system in place. Retail stores and local government facilities will serve as drop-offs for these products without being burdened with the cost of  shipping and processing them. Making the producers responsible for recycling also helps them internalize the costs of waste and gives them an incentive to design greener, better products!
  What We Need & What You Get 
We have 4 campaign vehicles that will drive 20 TCE activists from Houston, Austin and Dallas - 2000 miles round trip to Madison for a cost of $1780. We’re going to need $1000 for food and lodging at state parks and we’re budgeting $820 for additional campaign materials. For maximum impact we plan to spend $1,000 for a two hour plane flyover banner! Finally, $1500 will pay for the lost time of our canvassers who spend 40 hours making the trip.
While in Madison we will hold an action at a festival sponsored by Rayovac’s parent company, Spectrum Brands, to raise awareness and get news coverage about their irresponsible policies and in order to convince them to change. We’ve done this before and it works, so please help with whatever you can.
Anyone who gives $15 or more will get a virtual or actual postcard from the trip so you can see what we are doing to put the pressure on Rayovac to step up to the plate on battery recycling. Other perks include an “I Recycle, I Vote” bumper stickers for all who give $25. For a $50 gift, you’ll receive our mini-Recycling Guide magnet. If you give $100, we send you an actual postcard from the trip.
 
For $250 you will get an actual postcard and a beautiful 4-color TCE “When we heal the earth, we heal ourselves” t-shirt that you can wear with Texas pride - even if you are not from Texas! Our $500 donors will get an actual postcard AND a SURPRISE gift from Madison. Those who step up at the $1000 level will receive an actual postcard AND SURPRISE gifts from Madison AND Texas. (We hope the suspense doesn’t kill you!)

If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will cut out the plane banner flyover first. Then we would ask the canvassers to participate and forego a day’s wages. After that we’d probably spend less on food by eating lots of rice and beans. Please support us with as much as you can and share with your friends so we can do this right and make household battery recycling a reality in the U.S!   The Impact 
Single-use batteries are a perfect example of products “designed for the dump.” We envision a Texas and a planet free from pollution, which means we need to re-think the way we design the products we consume. “Disposable” batteries don’t make any sense when producers can easily design batteries and battery containing products to be recyclable and sustainable instead. Winning our campaign is one step closer to making sustainability a reality.
 
In 2003 we convinced Dell to stop using prison labor to recycle electronics and embrace producer takeback recycling by dressing up in striped inmate outfits at the huge Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. 

We got Apple to set up electronics recycling by demonstrating at the Apple Headquarters, MacWorld Expo and the office of former Vice President and Apple Board member Al Gore. We played a leadership role in the passage of a local ordinance to keep fracking out of Dallas parks and neighborhoods by building a 15-foot tall mock drilling rig to use at protests. Our “bag monster” actions built momentum for the passage of local ordinances on single-use bags in Austin and Dallas. Texas has more people live in cities with ordinances on single-use bags than any state except California - that doesn’t happen by accident! You can read more about our many victories on our website, here.


Whenever we host rallies or protests to advance our campaigns, we go through training and planning processes to make sure we are operating within the law as we exercise our First Amendment rights. Our protests are never ugly, profane or violent. We practice positive messaging so that the companies we are targeting can transition with us into communicating and implementing real solutions.   Risks & Challenges 
We’ve got grassroots, face-to-face organizing down… Although we have gone on many road trips, this is our first crowdfunding endeavor to support an action of this scale! 93% of our funding comes from small individual contributions. We are transitioning into more online organizing - like this - building a new website and will be piloting the use of mobile devices in our field canvassing. Part of this campaign is also to let Rayovac know we are coming and that we have public support, so please share this online with everyone you can! 
We have shown through campaign after campaign that we can confront any challenge with flexibility and energy on our way to victory! In the past two months, we’ve had one-on-one conversations with powerful figures including Rayovac executives and Walmart’s new CEO who are starting to listen to us. If anybody can make this road trip happen, it’s TCE and our supporters.
Please share this campaign with as many friends as possible. And while you’re at it, switch to using rechargeable batteries in all devices you use! Landfills and incinerators are a problem for our communities and with smarter design and recycling infrastructure, we can reduce, reuse and recycle making them virtually obsolete and unnecessary.   Other Ways You Can Help

story:
What is Power Shift?

In just a few weeks, 10,000 youth will converge in Pittsburgh to address the climate crisis. We will be fighting to move towards cleaner energy, away from corporate greed, and to build an inclusive movement for environmental justice. Power Shift 2013 will be the conference that defines and inspires a new generation of activists to take on today's biggest issues.

Such an amazing conference needs plenty of U of M students, right? Right! We're organizing to send as many Gophers as possible to Pittsburgh to join in the movement. We need your help to make this happen.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to send U of M students to Power Shift 2013 we need to raise:

  • At least $1000 to lower the cost of bus tickets below $130/person. 
  • Many students are unable to attend due to financial constraints, and transportation is a large part of that. The lower we are able to bring the transportation cost, the more students can attend!
  • If we exceed our goal, we'll be able to drop the price of transportation even further! This will directly impact the students who need it most, since students who have the financial means to pay a higher price will be asked to donate the difference.

The Impact

"Power Shift was one of the best experiences of my life -- it's incredible to be surrounded by so many other young activists and movement-builders." 

"I've always been interested in environmental issues, but I didn't know how passionate I could be about them until Power Shift. Now I'm looking for ways to get even more involved in my community."

"There's simply nothing like this conference. It's an amazing experience that I wish more people could have!"

These quotes from past Power Shift attendees from the U of M showcase the importance of sending more U of M students this year. Attendees learn skills, take workshops, and make connections that facilitate the growth of a nationwide climate movement. To make sure Minnesota remains a leader in sustainability, we need to make sure as many U of M students as possible are able to gain the skills and resources that Power Shift provides.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Thanks so much for supporting our film- and to the farmers for the great perks! There is still time to support our film- become a member of Montgomery Countryside Alliance and support our work all year to grow vibrant farms on Metro's edge!

Update! The world premiere will be September 25 at Universities at Shady Grove in Rockville, MD. 

In the early 80's- planners in busy Montgomery County, Maryland had a common problem, small family farms were being wiped from the map as the DC suburbs sprawled ever outward. The bold action they took in response has protected 93,000 acres of farms, parkland and open space- called the Agricultural Reserve-  just 20 miles from the White House- resulting in the most successful farmland protection effort in the US.

But- growing food and farms on the edge of a major metropolis is not easy. In an area of astronomical land costs, it is difficult for new farmers to even get started. Development interests tend to look at farms as "empty space" upon which to expand. Reliance on antiquated traffic "solutions" lead others to press for  highways that would swallow up productive land and open space. 

 


Poplar Spring Animal Sanctuary in the Reserve looking across to Virginia's high rises- 30 years on, you can see the impact of the Ag Reserve from a mile up. 

Montgomery Countryside Alliance is the small (but mighty) nonprofit that works to protect and celebrate the County's farms in the present and grow the next generation of farmers for the future.  We started the "Growing Legacy" film project to share the Ag Reserve story with local audiences ( with an emphasis on local schools)  so they might better appreciate this marvel in their own backyard; as well as with the world, to prove that you can grow cities and farms in harmony. 

Our vision: this film will be like the tomatoes you get from the farmers market at the peak of summer-  telling a story of the land, those who work it and those who toil to ensure it will all endure. With your help, this could be a bumper crop....


What We Need & What You Get

We have taken our time making this short film because we want to get it right. Why limit the film to 30 minutes? We are focused on the length most suitable for showing in classrooms and we view this film as a powerful teaching tool, both in the DC area and further afield. We have 40 hours of footage encompassing all 4 seasons of production and harvest, interviews with decision makers, consumers and especially farmers. Now comes the tough part- post production. We need funds to finish the job and get "Growing Legacy" out there. 

We already have some amazing backers for the film and we thank them - Lauren Kay Pollin and her family's foundation, as well as a mini-grant from Heritage Montgomery (which is in turn supported by the Montgomery County Government and Maryland Heritage Areas Authority). All the crucial details- narration, sound mixing, stock footage, music licencing and particularly editing - pile up really quickly. The $20,000 reflected here is the total cost we have left after some generous gifts from our supporters- but we need your help to wrap this project up right. 

MCA is a 501c3 nonprofit so all support of our film is tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.  

And- we have some pretty neat perks; see the premiere, (or see it from the front row), milk a goat,  see the Reserve for yourself, get some local applesauce- even get an assistant producer credit! We will be adding more perks throughout our campaign, so stay tuned. 

The Impact

The Ag Reserve is a successful model for protecting farms on the edge of metro areas. MCA is an award winning  nonprofit in the perfect position to share this model, Help us share this story with the world and inspire more practical farm protection efforts everywhere. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We have a giving level for everyone, but if you can't help with funding- help raise us some friends. Share our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools! Be sure to follow us on twitter and facebook so you can help amplify out message! Thanks!

Make Sure I Get My Close-Up!

story:
Support Cycle for Change's Youth Apprentices to attend the Recycle-A-Bicycle's Youth Bike Summit, a three day gathering geared toward youth, bicycles, education, and advocacy. This national conference aims to bring people from different disciplines to explore, network, and learn how bicycling can be a legitimate and safe form of transportation for today's youth. 

Cycles for Change is a non-profit community bike shop in the Frogtown neighborhood of Saint Paul, MN.  Our mission is to be an open, accessible space to educate and empower people to use bicycles as transportation, helping to build a sustainable environment and community. 

Cycles for Change's Youth Apprenticeship program includes sixteen amazing youth ages 15-18 who are gaining extensive skills in bicycle mechanics, learning how a small non-profit business operates, and helping with many other parts of Cycles for Change's operations such as teaching classes and doing outreach.  

The $2,500 will go towards transportation, food, lodging, and the summit registration fee for our sixteen youth apprentices and two youth programs staff chaperones. 

Thank you for your support.  Our goal is to bring back what we learn at the Youth Bike Summit to our community here in Saint Paul!

story:
We, Edwin and Marjo, have been live aboards for a while now. It is an amazing experience: the vastness of the ocean, visiting coastal communities and islands, dolphins playing around the bow.....

It is also a life that has made us really aware in many ways. Especially it made us aware about the importance of the oceans for life on the whole planet. And about the sometimes devastating effect of human life of it. 

With Ocean Conservation we bring our Awareness into Action. With our skills as a diver, a technician, a writer and a teacher and our sailing boat we support smaller organizations that

  • protect and preserve ocean life
  • support coastal communities in their sustainable development
  • educate about marine life

Furthermore while on the way we collect invaluable data for scientists and host them on our boat to facilitate their research.

Our campaign goal: air and water!

So far we have put a lot of effort into Orion to make her a go anywhere boat, next level would turn her into a stay anywhere boat.

To stay in the remotest of places a watermaker, which turns salt water into drinking water, is essential. Not only does it give us the independency to stay somewhere as long as needed, it also means that we don't have to take drinking water from places where it is already scarce. On tropical islands for instance.

The other part of the investment will be used for a diving compressor. Diving is one of our core activities in raising awareness with the local people, and in remote places there are no facilities to refill our diving cylinders. So a stand alone compressor will also be invaluable.

The watermaker is the larger part of the investment: GBP 6.000,00. This includes making adjustments in the boat to give it a good, solid place. The good thing is that the watermaker is partly sponsered by Schenker Watermakers and by the supplier Rob Wink Serious Seatools!

The other GBP 2.500,00 will be used for the diving compressor including all necessary parts to get it up and running.

Stretched goal: support for 'our' organizations

After reaching our campaign goal we will share the donations with the organizations we support:

So any donation will finally reach the ultimate goal: to improve marine life and help sustainable development of coastal communities.

Our next project

Our next project will take us to the Cape Verde Island of Sal, where we will assist SOS Tartarugas with their educational programs. 

The good thing is: we are almost there, so you can help us on the way as quickly as possible!

What is in it for you?

Of course we want to express our gratitude for your contribution! So we have come up with nice perks, that all will be personal, that is guaranteed. From postcard to T-shirt, to Photobook and even a week on our ship, it will be unique!

 

 Your Impact

We want to increase the impact we are having and you can help us do that. Your contribution will enable us to expand our activities:

  • we will be able to enhance the facilities we offer to scientists on board, which will facilitate them in their research.

  • we will be able to set up our own projects where there are none and there is a clear demand .

Other Ways You Can Help

Any publicity is welcome, so please share this campaign far and wide on Facebook, Twitter, through e-mail, anywhere !

It also possible to help us with goods: Educational material on marine biology and marine ecology, especially for kids, paper or pdf,  is always welcome. And the more pictures the better. Just get in touch!

On behalf of the oceans and all life that is connected to it, thank you so much for your support!

Edwin and Marjo

 

For more information visit the websites:

Ocean Conservation

SOS Tartarugas

Adventurers and Scientists for Conservation

Oceanswatch 

 

Our Sponsors:

story:
“The beauty of this whole thing is that because it’s the greatest challenge that we’re facing, it’s also the greatest opportunity to come together and reclaim community” Dorian Williams, SJSF 

Our Vision for the Climate Justice Hub

This summer, we want to launch a project called “the Climate Justice Hub,” a student-run community space in Boston to intensify the climate movement in New England. The Hub will be active 7-days-a-week from June through August of 2013, in Somerville, MA.

The space will help maintain the momentum among local students in Boston, who have been leading incredible direct actions all year. From locking themselves in TransCanada’s corporate office to organizing thousands to attend the Forward on our Future march in Washington, DC, students and young people in New England are putting their time and bodies on the line to build a climate justice movement.

Students participate in nonviolent direct action protesting the Keystone XL pipeline

Students Rally for Fossil Fuel Divestment

 

What Will Happen at the Hub?

Six student staff will facilitate the space, with an explicit focus on four key areas: leadership development, campaign planning, creative direct actions, and relationship-building.

 

Leadership Development

To ensure the Hub has an impact that lasts beyond the summer, the student staff will focus on developing leadership and building capacity within the Boston-area climate justice movement. 

Student staff will work with community organizations to host organizing trainings and workshops throughout the summer. Cultural diversity trainings and exercises will be held throughout the summer, incorporating inclusive values into the ongoing activities at the space. The student staff will also bring in leaders from communities directly impacted by fossil fuels, academia and local social justice organizations for events, discussions, and trainings. Participants will be encouraged to organize their own events, workshops, and skillshares in The Hub space, and offered student staff support as necessary.

At the end of the summer, our goal is to have built power by deepening leadership and spreading skills across the Boston-area climate justice community. The six student staff will also grow as leaders, returning to their campuses in the fall with new skills, community connections, and a fuller understanding of the craft of organizing as a result of their experience in the Hub. 

 

Campaign Planning

The Hub will provide a home for new and existing grassroots campaigns, host strategy sessions and action planning meetings, and provide a place for citizen activists to connect with local social justice organizations.

Student staff members have already identified several existing campaigns that they plan to spend time on:

  •  Locally, student staff will help bring fossil fuel divestment to the city/state level, focusing on reinvestment in a way that connects with local social justice organizations’ existing goals and projects.

  • Regionally, student staff will focus on campaigns such as Boston-area transit justice, shutting down the Brayton Point coal power station, or pushing for the completion of Cape Wind.

  • On the national stage, student staff will contribute time towards campaigns such as stopping the Keystone XL pipeline or pressuring Bank of America to divest from coal.


In addition, the space and resources of The Hub will be available for community members wishing to work on other existing campaigns or launch new ones. Allowing all of these efforts to share space and resources will create a dynamic environment ideal for facilitating strategic and well-coordinated campaigns.

 

Creative Direct Action

The Hub also intends to be a basecamp for creative direct action planning. The Hub will provide materials and a creative space for arts and culture workshops and large scale art builds.

Hub student staff and community members will arrange large non-violent direct action trainings, and encourage participants to form small affinity groups to provide them with the support necessary to participate in direct actions.

Student staff time will also be put towards helping plan three large-scale direct actions for the region around local fossil fuel infrastructure projects, in conjunction with Fearless Summer, Summer Heat, and the national movement.

 

Relationship Building

The Hub will be a social destination as well as an organizing space. That continuity will enable the development of strong relationships, providing a necessary foundation for effective organizing.

The student staff will work together to make the space inclusive, and incorporate cultural diversity into the activities taking place at the Hub. One of the student staff members will devote her time to intentional outreach and relationship-building between the environmental and social justice communities in Boston.

Student staff will also design the Hub as an intentional space for new activists to enter the movement. They will connect new participants to existing organizing groups and support their development as leaders and activists.

 


Student activists at the Forward on Climate rally in DC

 

Your Donation Will...

  • Enable us to rent a beautiful space to serve as the home for the climate justice movement in Boston.

  • Allow student climate justice organizers to maintain the space and lead campaigns full time

  • Help us keep the space free of cost for the community

  • Provide us with resources to bring in top trainers, climate justice leaders, academics, and artists for programs, events, and skill-shares.

 

The kinds of things your donation will pay for:

$25 - snacks and refreshments for an intensive training workshop

$50- paint and materials for the Art Build space

$100- honoraria for trainers from community organizations

$250- help cover the cost of the Wifi for the space

$500 - travel costs for a speaker from a community directly impacted by fossil fuel extraction

$1000- help cover the stipend for one of the full-time student organizers

 

Our Team: CJ Hub Student Staff

 

Dan Jubelirer


I am is a rising Junior at Tufts University, majoring in Peace and Justice studies. I attended a small Quaker high school in North Carolina, where I came to love the ideals of interconnectedness,  respect for all, and stewardship of nature. I believe human beings are deeply interconnected with the earth and with each other, and that working towards environmental sustainability also means creating social justice in all parts of society. I have worked with Advocates for Youth on youth sexual health, Students for Justice in Palestine at Tufts, Generation Waking Up, and joined Students for a Just and Stable Future in the fall of 2012.  

 

Will Pearl

I am a rising sophomore at Tufts University majoring in Environmental Studies. Hailing from Vermont, I have grown an appreciation for the land and the people who work and care for it in my own state but more importantly in connection to the rest of the world. I see climate change as the single greatest environmental and social justice issue of our time and am committed to working in solidarity with frontline communities and those affected by the climate crisis. I recently became very involved in the fight against the Keystone XL pipeline and have worked to fight the fossil fuel industry through Tufts’ divestment campaign. I am also a musician, a poet and a solar panel enthusiast!

 

Alli Welton

I recently finished my second year at Harvard College.  I grew up in a ranching community in eastern Washington state, angry at the economic inequality I saw around me and what poverty did to my friends’ lives. That experience led me to care about social justice more broadly, including climate and environmental justice. Since moving to Boston, I have worked with Students for a Just and Stable Future on campaigns around Keystone XL, fossil fuel subsidies, and fossil fuel divestment.

 

Jacklyn Gil


Hello! I am a rising senior at Brandeis University, majoring in Peace & Justice Studies. Growing up in a largely Latino immigrant community has led to a passion in environmental justice organizing (and salsa dancing).  Over the past year I have worked on campaigns in various areas of social justice including tenants rights, labor rights, student debt, and fossil fuel divestment. In February of 2013 I participated in an act of civil disobedience against the Keystone XL pipeline and became fully aware of how powerful the growing climate justice movement has become. This summer I hope to help cultivate an empowering, inclusive culture of solidarity through peacebuilding arts and creative cultural exchange.

 

Ben Thompson


Ben is a graduate student studying Mathematics at Boston University.  Originally from the Seacoast Region in New Hampshire, Ben attended Cornell College in Iowa, graduating in 2012 with a major in Mathematics and a minor in Physics.  Ben has been an active environmentalist since 2004 and a climate activist in earnest since 2008 when he began organizing 350.org events.  In August of 2011, he participated in the Tar Sands Action sit-in outside the White House.  Ben  SJSF in the summer of 2012, and helped organize the January 7th sit-in at the Westborough TransCanada office.  Outside of Mathematics and fighting global warming, Ben enjoys running, biking, crocheting, and pretending to play the clarinet.

 

Sophia Goodfriend

I am a rising Sophomore at Tufts University majoring in American Studies. Originally from Seattle, Washington I got turned onto issues of social and economic justice after spending time in El Salvador my junior year of high school. My time abroad opened my eyes to the scope of inequality and injustice suffered by the majority of our globe’s population. Over the past few years I have become attuned to how the diverse social-justice issues I am committed to are interconnected and the way in which climate change affects the world’s least fortunate to the greatest and most harmful degree. I have worked with Citizens in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador, Students for Justice in Palestine at Tufts and became heavily involved with Tufts’ Divestment campaign this past winter.
story_txt:
“The beauty of this whole thing is that because it’s the greatest challenge that we’re facing, it’s also the greatest opportunity to come together and reclaim community” Dorian Williams, SJSF 
Our Vision for the Climate Justice Hub
This summer, we want to launch a project called “the Climate Justice Hub,” a student-run community space in Boston to intensify the climate movement in New England. The Hub will be active 7-days-a-week from June through August of 2013, in Somerville, MA.
The space will help maintain the momentum among local students in Boston, who have been leading incredible direct actions all year. From locking themselves in TransCanada’s corporate office to organizing thousands to attend the Forward on our Future march in Washington, DC, students and young people in New England are putting their time and bodies on the line to build a climate justice movement.

Students participate in nonviolent direct action protesting the Keystone XL pipeline

Students Rally for Fossil Fuel Divestment

Student staff will also design the Hub as an intentional space for new activists to enter the movement. They will connect new participants to existing organizing groups and support their development as leaders and activists.

Enable us to rent a beautiful space to serve as the home for the climate justice movement in Boston.


Allow student climate justice organizers to maintain the space and lead campaigns full time


Help us keep the space free of cost for the community

$250- help cover the cost of the Wifi for the space

story:
Why we need your help!

The Institute for Conservation Research and Education's mission is to restore habitat through the use of community engagement.  The funds earned from this campaign will be going towards the continued improvement of Fairview Park in Costa Mesa, California. Firstly, the park already provides a great place for the community to use, it improves water quality, and increases the value of the surrounding homes.  Secondly, Fairview Park is also one of the few homes to our local sensitive wildlife. Southern California is one of the world’s few biodiversity hotspots- meaning we have a very large number of diverse plant and animal species in an area that is also highly threatened by human activity.  A lot of the species found here are already endangered or threatened due to extreme habitat loss. In order to ensure the survival of what is left in our community, the remaining areas of existing habitat need to be preserved and restored.

   

There are hundreds of species of animals and plants that are only found in Southern California and Orange County hosts many of these. ICRE, a non-profit organization based in Huntington Beach, is working to restore the remaining areas of space into usable habitat for our remaining species. Specifically, ICRE has launched this Indiegogo campaign to help fund the completed restoration of Fairview Park. This 200-acre area is Costa Mesa’s only wildlife park, and the city only had funding for us to restore a portion of the total area. 

              

However, what we have restored so far has been very successful! The restored portion of the park is not only a beautiful place for park goers, joggers, and locals, but it has become home to many species of local wildlife that would not have any habitat otherwise. In addition to wildlife habitat, the site also provides water quality improvement and treatment for the city. The ponds restored on the site filter run-off water from the city, filtering it naturally and replenishing ground water, instead of having to divert the water to the plant at the Orange County Sanitation District for treatment. In order to further these benefits and continue establishing populations of our local species, the restoration of these spaces needs to continue!  Acres of this area are still filled with weeds and non-native grasses that choke out the beautiful native habitat that houses these species, and with the right financial backing, this area could be fully restored!

(Fairview Park on September 2009)


(Fairview Park on September 2010)

What happens to my donation?

As long as we can find money to purchase plants and put them in the ground, the rest of the habitat will do the work all on its own!  After only two years, the first portion of this park was restored and hundreds of species of lizards, frogs, birds, and other animals then settled themselves into the newly created habitat. So with the help of your financial support, 10 more acres of a community park and new habitat could be established and preserved! And for your donations you can receive a number of thank you gifts, and even get a private tour of the park!!  You can even come out and help put the plants in the ground yourself during our restoration planting day- which will be announced soon after the funding campaign!


The price breakdown

We at ICRE have estimated the price breakdown for this project as follows: To restore 10 acres of habitat, at least 1000 native plants need to be purchased (but more is better!). Plants are typically five to ten dollars each, along with getting all the plants to the site, into the ground, and watered. We therefore set our goal at $10,000 in the hopes that, with your help, we can reach that goal and fully restore the entire area! And if we get more than our goal of $10,000 that just means we can restore more acres- there is plenty of space to restore at the park!

                                    

Every little bit helps. Just five or ten dollars can buy a plant or two, bringing us that much closer to our goal.  Even if we are not fully funded, every plant can create a little bit more habitat. Your ten dollars could turn into a giant sycamore, home to hundreds of critters, or maybe some cattails, which filter run-off water everyday. Can’t donate financially but still want to help? Share this Indiegogo link via email, Facebook, or any way possible to help us get the word out!  And thank you for making our community a better place for everyone!

story:
Eco Vets!

Our country has a real fresh water problem, in many areas the water shortage is critical.

Our Men and Women have fought, served and risked their life while wearing heavy combat gear in unmanageable heat!

Upon returning home they find themselves at the back of a very long line looking for work. But for each job opening 5 workers apply.

Wounded warriors have an even tougher battle.
We will hire these vets to install low flush toilets.
The disabled vets will work at the phones and computers; dispatching the trucks and customer service scheduling the appointment. And in management!

These will not be low paying, minimum wage jobs. Our goal is to pay $50,000 per year.
This will be a win, win, win, win, win project.
  • Vets will get high paid jobs
  • Wounded Warriors will get meaningful and well paid employment
  • The countries potable water supply will not be flushed down the drain!
  • The homeowner will get a very attractive price for the new fixture. In some cases it will be free after the water district rebate! And their water bill will drop.
  • Schools, Religious Organizations and Service Groups will promote the sale and will receive $20 per sale.

The homeowner will pay $200 of which the fundraiser keeps $20. the home owner will get a rebate from the water district ranging from $50 to the full $200!

With computer routing softeware and GPS we can effinectly route the Vets to the homes. We can re-schedule and re-route on the fly and very little time will be lost. I estimate that each Vet will be able to install an average of 5 or 6 toilets per day. We will get a good wholesale price for a decent low flow toilet.

Toilets are water hogs: They use the most water in a home, more than showers, washing machines, dishwashers, bathtubs, and faucet.

A low flush toilets will save 20 gallons of water per day, 7,000 gallons of water year for one person, 9000 gallons in the average home. The average person flushes 65 cents per day, $236 a year, per person!. Even without the rebate, the toilet will pay for itself in less then a year! I will start the program as soon as the PayPal money starts coming in. The Goal of $5000 is enough to accelerate the launch.

Please join our program. For the Vets and the water supply.

The Perks  (mock ups)
The Vets

Certificate of Appreciation

The Master Award Display
Of course all the images are mock ups... We haven't hired the Vets yet.

story:
Hello. My name is David Grau and for many years I have been an organic farmer. With my experience in farming I realize the potential and need for quality tools and the possibility of creating electric tractors for the small farmer.

I am dedicated to promoting ecological harmony, especially in agriculture. With this thought in mind, I became interested in building electric tractors that are designed to be economical for the small local farmers.

Electric tractors for the small farmer will move society’s thinking into the future by making farming green. However, with the costs involved for producing such a product your support is greatly needed. With your generous donations you can help make this dream become real.

SPECIFICS:

We will convert a Farmall Cub Tractor to run on electricity instead of fossil fuel. This conversion will cost approximately $6000 to $8000 dollars. This money will be used to:

Build and install a new frame member for the electric motor.

Materials and labor to rebuild the wheels, gears and seals and the installation of the motor, controls and batteries.

Sandblasting and painting of parts and reassembly of the tractor frame

The various costs which are needed to complete the conversion to electric.

PROFILE

I am the owner of Valley Oak Tool. We manufacture and sell tools to small farms and gardeners  such as broadforks, wheel hoes and stake pounders. All of the tools are of my own design.  

Global transformation to ecologically sustainability has been my passion for many years. Electric tractors will improve farming. They are quiet, they do not produce fumes, and they minimize the waste resources.

IF WE DO NOT REACH OUR GOAL:

All money raised for our endeavor will go toward the tractor conversion.  However, our work will be delayed if our resources run out.

WHAT THIS ACCOMPLISHES:

Using electric tractors will help make small farms more economically viable and ecologically sustainable.

WHY I AM THE ONE TO DO THIS:

You can trust me to do the job. I have a team of friends who are ready to start work and want to make this idea a reality. I have many years of manufacturing experience. We are knowledgeable about farm equipment and electric conversions, and  I understand what farmers need.  My tools are eco-friendly and my hope is to someday include the electric tractor into my business.  The tractor shown in the photo gallery is an electric tractor I help convert.

FINAL PLEA:

Help support healthy small farms by your generous donations.

Your donations will continue the success of a small business operation set on improving global sustainability. There is a need for electric tractors to be put into operation on a grander scale. With your donations you will not only be helping to support the small farmer, but to bring back to our communities more resources and good quality food.

With this thought in mind, once the tractor is in operation, you might even find yourself interested in owning one for yourself. Again, Help support farming of the future by your generous donations.

PROFILE
I am the owner of Valley Oak Tool. We manufacture and sell tools to small farms and gardeners  such as broadforks, wheel hoes and stake pounders. All of the tools are of my own design.  
Global transformation to ecologically sustainability has been my passion for many years. Electric tractors will improve farming. They are quiet, they do not produce fumes, and they minimize the waste resources.
IF WE DO NOT REACH OUR GOAL:
All money raised for our endeavor will go toward the tractor conversion.  However, our work will be delayed if our resources run out.
WHAT THIS ACCOMPLISHES:
Using electric tractors will help make small farms more economically viable and ecologically sustainable.
WHY I AM THE ONE TO DO THIS:
You can trust me to do the job. I have a team of friends who are ready to start work and want to make this idea a reality. I have many years of manufacturing experience. We are knowledgeable about farm equipment and electric conversions, and  I understand what farmers need.  My tools are eco-friendly and my hope is to someday include the electric tractor into my business.  The tractor shown in the photo gallery is an electric tractor I help convert.
FINAL PLEA:
Help support healthy small farms by your generous donations.
Your donations will continue the success of a small business operation set on improving global sustainability. There is a need for electric tractors to be put into operation on a grander scale. With your donations you will not only be helping to support the small farmer, but to bring back to our communities more resources and good quality food.
With this thought in mind, once the tractor is in operation, you might even find yourself interested in owning one for yourself. Again, Help support farming of the future by your generous donations.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Tom Morgan, I am from the UK, but have been wandering the globe for several years, exploring and learning. After being introduced to Permaculture this year I have an urge to learn more, and share this knowledge and these ideas for alternative, more natural and symbiotic ways of living. South america I feel is a great place to do this, indiginous populations hold the fogotten knowledge which can reconnect us with the land, things that need to be relearned in order for us to live in harmony with the earth as we once did, many years ago.

And what better vehicle on which to carry out this adventure than the bicycle, travelling by bicycle slows down a journey and connects you with the place in which your travelling, it is a pure and free means of travel and should be adopted by everyone.

The plan is to cycle from Bogota, Colombia to Patagonia over the following year, visit and work on permaculture projects, local farms, and anything inspiring along the way. I will be Recording my experiences and sharing what I learn with photographs and blogs on my website. www.wheelingitsouthamerica.blogspot.com 

This trip was well under way untill 2 days ago when my bicycle, which had been lovingly built from scratch here in bogota along with alot of gear, was taken from me by an opportunistic thief. I was set to leave in 2 weeks, but now as I dont have a bicycle and my funds are low this doesnt seem so possible

Your contribution will help me to get set up (again) with the gear I need to hit the road and allow me to carry out this adventure, although partly a selfish pursuit, as most projects inevitably are, I have a real passion to share and promote a different approach to life, trying to re-connect us humans with the natural world and re-discover our true place within it. If i inspire just 1 person to change their life i will be happy.

 

What I Need & What You Get

The funding I am in need of will pay for my bike and some gear i will need for the trip, for example panniers, rain gear, some camping equipment ect. The gear which was stolen from me. I will build the bike from scratch using second hand components where possible, and some other gear i need such as panniers, lights, clothing, A LOCK, and some other things I can buy at cost price from a friend at a bike shop here in Bogota, anything left over will go towards maintenance and supplies once on the road. 

In return I will write interesting insigntful and humurous blogs about my experiences and upload photographs and videos on my website. I will write instructional how-to's on interesting permaculture techniques that can be applied at home. Spread the knowledge and get people inspired. 

I will promote cycling everywhere as a healthy green and exciting mode of transport.

Anything will help, even if its $1, if I dont meet my projected goal the money will still go to the same project. it might take a bit longer, and I might need to hunt more thoroughly through the second hand stores for some bargains but your donation will go to the same cause.

I appreciate this is alot to ask and if you cannot contribute but still want to help me you can tell someone about my project, spread the good word by posting a link on facebook or twitter (I dont know how to use twitter so some help with that would be very much appreciated)

Join me on my journey!

story:
My Story

In September and October, I will be cycling 2,000 km through Canada as part of a non-profit organization called the Otesha Project (http://www.otesha.ca).  We will be traveling as a 15 person theatre troupe, performing street theater, plays, and hosting workshops for hundreds of school aged children along the way, with an inspiring educational message about sustainability, and how to make every day choices that have a positive effect on our environment!  


Last year, I travelled to 13 countries on Semester at Sea and when I returned I felt disheartened and unsure of how to process the incredible things I witnessed (both beautiful and heartbreaking) and now, I am learning the best way to make a change is to take action, given the gift of this life-experience education.  


I am going to be making a documentary as a I travel with Otesha, in order to bring it back to the States to start showing here, in Boulder, Colorado, in an attempt to begin the project here in the States!  You can watch a short video about Otesha's mission here:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ViVjnLoE3ZA


The Impact

Otesha educates thousands of people every year through workshops, play performances, and the Otesha book. The more youth we can reach through the positive Otesha message, the more youth we have committing to making positive changes toward helping the world!!!


What We Need & What You Get

As part of my contribution to the project as a volunteer, I need to raise $1,600.00 .  I am putting down $300.00 of my own money to kick start it---which goes toward keeping the project alive, our food, some money for our kindly host families....  


What it does NOT cover is my transportation to and from the project, travel insurance, a bicycle, gear, or money for repairs.  I am aiming to raise $2,000 in total to offset these expenses, as I am a (soon-to-be!!!) college graduate with student loans, as we all are :D


As a donor, I will send you:


a)  a postcard from a location yet to be determined in Canada!!!

b) a copy of my documentary upon its completion

c) love notes in the form of emails, updating you on the progress of the project

d) the opportunity to be listed in the credits for the documentary!

e) warm, fuzzy feelings, along with youtube videos of my team dancing on the sides of highways.


Other Ways You Can Help

-GEAR DONATIONS!

        If you or your organization would like to donate a 50 cm road bike, panniers, front and back bike lights, a bright orange vest, a single person tent, sleeping pad, anything gear-ish for touring, that would be BOMB!


-SPREAD THE WORD!

       I can't help but gush about the amazing work Otesha is doing in Canada.  Let people know, if you think this is cool!  Also, I could use all the support I can :D


-SEND PRAYERS SO THAT WE ALL RIDE SAFELY!  

      I promise I'll wear my helmet.

story:
A little About Ourselves

We are a group of Sophomores at Austin High School in a program called The Academy of Global Studies. The Academy of Global Studies, or AGS, strives to educate students about the world and its numerous cultures through five pillars; Investigate the World, Recognize Perspectives, Take Action, and Communicate Ideas. 

What We Are Doing

In order to follow these pillars, we often do projects in groups. These projects are almost completely free-range, with our only goal in mind being to help change the world for the better. In our project, we are attempting to curb deforestation on a local level. We plan on planting Lob-lolly Pine trees in Bastrop, Texas, and White Oak Trees in Austin, Texas.

The Impact

We hope that by initiating this project, we can educate our community about the problems of deforestation and the effects that it has on our environment. We hope that by planting these trees in the Austin area, we can do our part to help keep our city healthy and set an example for other high-schoolers across the world.

Risks & Challenges

While this is a fairly risk-free venture, there is always the chance that the trees never grow correctly and die in their new homes. While this is a slight risk, this is also the perfect time to plant, giving these new trees plenty of time to grow and develop before winter.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that not everyone can donate to our project, and we completely understand. However, if you are still interested in making a difference, please do your part by planting a tree or two in your yard or neighborhood.

Thank you, and happy planting.

story:
Hello everybody!

So, in 16 days (today is August 14), I will finally be a grown ass little boy. I never thought I'd make it to 30, but look at me now!! I have much to be thankful for in my life, like the fact that I don't have any kids to worry about, and my tribe and friends to keep me on the straight and narrow, and fill my heart with love and joy.

Anyway, August 30th is my 30th birthday and though I feel weird about doing this, I am asking all my friends and family to help me get a bike. I haven't had a bike of my own since my darling bike that Uncle Matt gave me was stolen 2 years ago. I've also NEVER owned a brand spanking new bike, and would really like to.

I've looked at several bikes, and found quite a few for less than $500 that are totally awesome. I want a light but durable frame and a flip-flop hub to easily switch between fixed and single speed. One of the bikes I've been eyeing is a Jamis Beatnik and it's MSRP is around $450. If Campus Wheelworks is carrying this bike, then it'll be the one I get, because my impatience won't want to wait for a custom made mail order bike. However, if Campus isn't carrying this bike, then I am going to order the bike pictured above (I'll probably order it anyway because I can customize it looking all awesome like the picture.) It's a custom Republic Bike, Aristotle model. After shipping and handling, it comes out to $467.00.

If I don't make enough money for a new bike, then I'll use whatever I make to buy a new wheel set and use an old frame I have.

Anything that I get over the cost of the bike will go towards a nice bike lock and other bike accessories.

Anyway, thank you for taking the time to read this, and thank you even more for helping to make my birthday wish come true and making this grown ass little boy the happiest in the world.

<3,
Gander

story:
Urban woodlands provide oases of habitat for birds and other wildlife and form a “green infrastructure” of life-supporting services from aesthetic enjoyment to protection of water resources and energy conservation. The Bloomington Urban Woodlands Project is “Takin’ It to the Streets” with a special campaign to expand native woodland habitat through curbside plantings. To increase their visibility and impact, we will install QR-coded signage that links to fun and informative video and infographic digital resources about native landscaping.

Who Are We?

The Bloomington Urban Woodlands Project brings community, campus and commerce together to restore urban forests and reconnect people with nature. Habitat loss and invasive plants are intertwined challenges, making our central strategic goal a shift in people’s landscaping choices to native plants. Towards this goal, we engage nursery retailers and current and future land caretakers in restoration, research, and education designed to restore urban forest habitat. We take direct action to restore local green spaces and we create marketing materials that communicate the costs vs. benefits of invasive vs. native plant species and help plant sellers and buyers to make appropriate choices. We’ve improved habitat in local woodlands and neighborhoods, designed marketing materials for two nursery retailers, and developed web and social media resources.

What We Need

Your contributions will support our efforts to convert five urban curbside areas into woodland bio-islands planted with native trees, shrubs and wildflowers and to create associated QR-coded signage linking to engaging and informative video and infographic digital resources.

What You Get

We have some great perks to offer you for your help! 

For just a five-dollar donation, your desktop wallpaper can be a beautiful photo taken in our woodlands. 

For ten dollars you can show your native pride with an “I went native!” bumper sticker.

For a thirty-dollar donation you can come pick up a native seedling plug from the greenhouse.

Gorgeous native plant photo prints and poster options can be yours at the twenty-five and fifty-dollar donation levels, respectively. 

We offer wildflower tours, bird outings, and invasive control workshops for larger donations.

Do you want to help us get the word out? Please post our IndieGoGo campaign on your social media networks and connect with us on Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, and Instagram.

story:
Short Summary

Musk deer, predominantly found in Asia, produce a pleasant smelling pheromone, muscone, which is used both in traditional Chinese medicine and by the perfume industry. Unfortunately, the deer have been hunted to near extinction in pursuit of this valuable material and as a result are now listed as an endangered species. Nick aims to provide an alternate, economically viable method of producing muscone in order to save the musk deer.

What We Need & What You Get

Preliminary work in the our lab has demonstrated the viability of a four step preparation of muscone. Nick's work will focus on identifying reaction conditions that will improve the preparation by balancing two important factors: environmental impact and overall yield. As an example the current reaction used to prepare one of the intermediates uses a common but environmentally unfriendly reagent. He will explore alternative conditions for this reaction to avoid the harmful reagent. He will also seek to identify reaction conditions that maximize the yield of each step, which will minimize the environmental impact of the preparation and reduce the overall cost of producing muscone.


Through the course of this summer research project Nick will:

1.  Improve the conversion of a Grignard reaction by studying alternate initiating reagents.

2.  Identify oxidation conditions that will optimally balance environmental impact with overall reaction yield.

3.  Improve the conversion of a linear ketone into a cyclic ketone by investigating catalyst choice, solvent, and temperature.

4.  Fully characterize all compounds in preparation for a publication.

*More importantly, by participating in summer research Nick will gain valuable experience that will will improve his career and educational options post-graduation, and it will also help him to be better informed to make decisions regarding his future career path.

The Impact

Musk deer are endangered due to mankind’s pursuit of its natural musk (muscone). A population of 6000 musk deer is currently held in captivity, while as few as 300 are believed to survive live in the wild. According to a 2012 Science article the combination of the limited supply of musk with continued high demand provides a clear need for an economically viable synthesis of this material.  (Cao, S.; Feng, Q. Science, 2012, 335, 1168.)  Providing a cheap source of this compound would remove the incentive to hunt the animal and may as a result enable it to return to the wild.

The Budget

Summer student salary (40 hrs/week @ $7.25/hr for 8 weeks)   $2320

One allocation for summer student housing (double occupancy rate of $70/wk for 11 weeks) $770

Research Materials  $500

TOTAL  $3590

story:
XL DISSENT is the vision of a group of young organizers to respond to one of the most pressing environmental decisions of our time. If approved, the Keystone XL pipeline would increase the economic viability of extraction in Alberta, exacerbate pollution and health risks from refining, and spell game over for the climate. As young people we must respond: our future is on the line. We believe that by orchestrating the largest youth climate civil disobedience in US history we can send a strong message to President Obama: Unlock us from a fossil fuel future. XL Dissent is a weekend event that will include a civil disobedience training and divestment campaign meeting on Saturday, and an action on Sunday.

What We Need 

This action will also bring together students from all across the United States to converge on a shared vision of our planet's future. The other cost for us is transportation-- we will be having buses come to DC from Minnesota, Maine, Wisconsin, Vermont, and others! Since this is a student-driven action, we want to be able to offset the cost to make it accessible to anyone who wants to be a part. If we do not reach our entire goal, the fundraised money will simply help to decrease the cost for students to be involved.

The Impact

Generations before have created the infrastructure that has led us to impending climate catastrophe. As young people who will be most impacted, we are standing up to say “enough”, and we need your support to speak truth to power.

We are working with 350.org, Energy Action Coalition, Greenpeace, and Chesapeake Climate Action Network to pull off this event. With their organizing assistance and the 75+ campuses that have already committed to attending, we know this will be a success.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Check out our website and share it with your friends, families, lovers on Facebook, twitter, e-mail, and the longstanding options of in person conversation and snail mail.
    www.xldissent.org

Since this is a student-driven action, we want to be able to offset the cost to make it accessible to anyone who wants to be a part. If we do not reach our entire goal, the fundraised money will simply help to decrease the cost for students to be involved.The ImpactGenerations before have created the infrastructure that has led us to impending climate catastrophe. As young people who will be most impacted, we are standing up to say “enough”, and we need your support to speak truth to power.We are working with 350.org, Energy Action Coalition, Greenpeace, and Chesapeake Climate Action Network to pull off this event. With their organizing assistance and the 75+ campuses that have already committed to attending, we know this will be a success.Other Ways You Can HelpCheck out our website and share it with your friends, families, lovers on Facebook, twitter, e-mail, and the longstanding options of in person conversation and snail mail.www.xldissent.org

story:
Our Story

We are a dedicated and dynamic team who direct a young Ecuadorian non-profit organisation named Fundación Fauna de la Amazonía (FFDLA) (http://www.amazoniarescue.org) that works for the protection of wildlife and wild areas in Ecuador. Two years ago we set off on a new venture working specifically towards the protection of forested land in the buffer zone of the Llanganates National Park near Mera in the Pastaza Region by obtaining title to a 37.5 hectare piece of land in the area. This land is within the Llanganates Sangay Ecological Corridor, an area granted special recognition as a "Gift to the Earth" by the World Wildlife Fund in 2002 for its mega diversity and importance to world ecology. The majority of the water resources of the region originate in the Llanganates Mountain Range, flowing down and joining bigger rivers farther along, such as Rio Pastaza and Rio Napo, which are tributaries of the great Amazon River. Huge numbers of towns, communities and businesses are provided for from these sources.  It is a hotspot area where vast numbers of fascinating species of orchids and plants, insects, frogs and other animals including Andean bears, tapirs, jaguarundis, tamarin monkeys, and emblematic birds such as the cock of the rock and the umbrella bird, correlate to form astonishing ecosystems which are still yet to be studied in depth – new species of animals and plants are being discovered here every year. Unfortunately, however, the area is deteriorating due to tree-felling, intensive animal hunting, contamination, inappropriate land use including unsustainable agricultural practices, and lack of sustainable opportunities for local community members. We are working to develop a wildlife conservation centre on the land to implement research, wild animal rehabilitation and release, community development and educational programmes, and increase established protected areas. Our objective is to protect and enhance the area working with members of the local community and other groups that work in the area and to spread awareness about the importance of these ecosystems for the future of our communities worldwide.

When we acquired title to the 37,5 hectare piece of land we were only able to pay for around 50% of the total price. The owner approved the deed transfer, urged by his desire to conserve the land that he had lived on from for more than 30 years. This left us $10500 (USD) to find. Since then we have raised funds to pay a further $5000, leaving a final amount of $5500 to be paid before the end of May 2012. We are reaching out to all passionate animal, plant, life and nature lovers to help us raise this amount by the start of May. By contributing you will help ensure the survival of thousands of animal and plants species and communities and you will give us the support we need, afterwards, to develop a model wildlife conservation centre to benefit the wildlife and natural resources of Ecuador and of the World. Together we can change the World!

 

The Impact

By protecting this land there will be an increase in land protection and biodiversity, including attracting further land purchase for conservation. We will use publicity on a national and international basis to generate further investment to protect this area which is so important for world ecology. It will allow our team to actively develop priority activities in the area including increased environmental awareness, the production of inventories of native animals and plants, and land management and community development plans.

If we aren’t able to raise the mentioned funds we will be forced to expend most of our current budget and we will not be able to action the activities which are vital to support the continued existence of the wild animals and plants, natural resources and communities of this important area.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to pay the final instalment on the 37.5 hectare piece of forested land that FFDLA works to protect. We have already raised funds and paid for around 70% of the total price of the plot, leaving a remaining amount of $5500 to be paid before the end of May 2012. Simultaneously, several of our team members and supporters are organising cultural and musical fundraising events in Spain and the UK during the month of April. For more information about these please keep checking our Facebook page (http://www.facebook.com/fauna.amazonia) and web sites (http://www.amazoniarescue.org, http://www.flordelaamazonia.org). All money received will go towards the final payment on the land. If we exceed our aim, the extra amount will go towards the development of our wildlife conservation centre, specifically towards the construction of our first accommodation house for staff, assistants and students, which we are planning to build on site using alternative materials such as bamboo and recycled materials, with assistance from Kenku - colleagues specialised in the use of alternative materials and energies.

If you are in a position to contribute towards our project, make sure you read about the amazing gifts that come with our set amount donations. We greatly appreciate any support you are able to give us. Every little bit helps!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many other ways in which you can help us: join our support group in the UK (http://www.flordelaamazonia.org), join our Facebook group (http://www.facebook.com/fauna.amazonia), become an active supporter through our Givengain page (http://www.faunadelaamazonia.givengain.org), spread the word, download and distribute our awareness flyers and posters from our web site (http://www.amazoniarescue.org/en/how.php), organise a benefit event in your town... We need your help! If you believe in what we are fighting for, it would be great if you could help us to get more people to know about us and support us.

If you are in a position to contribute towards our project, make sure you read about the amazing gifts that come with our set amount donations. We greatly appreciate any support you are able to give us. Every little bit helps!
 


Other Ways You Can Help
There are many other ways in which you can help us: join our support group in the UK (http://www.flordelaamazonia.org), join our Facebook group (http://www.facebook.com/fauna.amazonia), become an active supporter through our Givengain page (http://www.faunadelaamazonia.givengain.org), spread the word, download and distribute our awareness flyers and posters from our web site (http://www.amazoniarescue.org/en/how.php), organise a benefit event in your town... We need your help! If you believe in what we are fighting for, it would be great if you could help us to get more people to know about us and support us.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Yongo Otieno Wycliffe and I am 23 years old and live in Kenya Africa. My project is called S.H.A.R.E. (S-Sustainable, H-Housing, A-Agriculture, R-Reaching, E-Everyone). 

I studied Permaculture Design and am volunteering in all kinds of gardening & farming work on different farms in Kenya. I help repair soil through composting, planting food, seeking water sources and help to protect animals, birds and insects. No job is too big or small for me. 

I am fascinated by nature and sustainable farming practices especially permaculture & ecovillages. I was excited to learn about permaculture because my vision is to start  a permaculture demonstration site which will act as an educational centre in order to educate & empower many African communities about this ethical, revolutionary form of sustainable farming. We can work together as communities, providing an abundance of food, low to zero energy housing, general cleaning and waste management and sustainable living and improve the lives of the younger generation. 

My mission is to work with individuals and communities by empowering them, especially disabled people, because being disabled doesn't mean you are disqualified from life's opportunities. We will provide solutions to early marriages and pregnancies amongst young girls, help to reduce crime rates and other problems amongst youths due to boredom. Your assistance will help us achieve this goal because.....

For my vision to become a reality we require the following resources: 

  • $4000 for 1 acre of land.
  • $500 for education materials such as books, to create a library.
  • $500 for solar panels 
  • $100 for water tank 
  • $100 for green house 
  • $700 for building materials 
  • $100 for garden tools 
  • $2000 for training and teaching fund to share Permaculture knowledge.
Total needed: $8000

Check out our S.H.A.R.E. postcard which we'd like to give you as a gift for being a valued donor!

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please ask your friends and networks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

You can use the Indiegogo share tools and with your help, we can make a difference to the lives of many!
