story:
WHAT? is International Antarctica Expedition (IAE)!

Every year 2041 takes a team of ~ 40 carefully selected individuals from around the world on a voyage down south to Antarctica to inspire and engage the next generation of leadership for a sustainable future.

 WHAT? is 2041!

2041 Ltd  is a non-profit organization led by Sir Robert Swan, dedicated towards the preservation of Antarctica by the promotion of recycling, renewable energy and sustainability to combat the effects of climate change on earth.

2041 led its first corporate organization  in the year 2003 and since then taken over 1000 corporate leaders, educators, students and entrepreneurs from around the world on its 'LEADERSHIP ON THE EDGE' program at Antarctica.

It is time to start a movement and be united on this noble journey!

WHO? is Sir Robert Swan!

                                       


Sir Robert Swan, OBE, is the first man in history to walk to both the North and South Poles and founded 2041. He is an environment leader, polar explorer and public speaker, who has dedicated his life to preservation of Antarctica- the last pristine continent on this earth.

Robert Swan through his Leadership program has been successful in removing 1,500 tons of rubbish from Antarctica.

         


WHO? is going!

                                                 


My name is Yashvika Mittal, an engineer by education, a sales consultant by profession but fore-mostly an environmentalist at heart. Even as a child garbage, dirt, pollution, resource wastage and the carefree attitude of the people with it bothered me and hence I decided to work for the cause and bring the change that I want to see. Now I feel very proud to be joining Sir Robert Swan and his team to engage people world over in this mission of sustainability.

 The Greatest Threat To Our Planet Is The Belief That Someone
Else Will Save It!

Post the expedition, as an Antarctic Youth Ambassador my mission would be to educate people on Waste management with the hope that we make electricity out of garbage in the near future. We must join hands to imbibe the mantra of 4R's- Refuse, Reduce, Reuse and Recycle.

Why? save Antarctica!

Antarctica, without  any native population or governance, is today ruled by an International treaty which prohibits mining and drilling until  the year  2041, post which this agreement can be altered, changed, modified, or even abandoned. As the year 2041 quickly approaches, we must ensure that this last wilderness must be left untouched from any human activity.

Let us all Save Antarctica Together!

Did you know:

·  More than 99 percent of Antarctic blue whales have been killed by commercial whalers during the 20th century (From 250,000 Whales, the total has dwindled down to fewer than 400).

·  The West Antarctica region is shedding a Mount Everest equivalent amount of ice every two years

·  Enough Ice Has Melted in Antarctica to Alter the Earth’s Gravity

·  If the Antarctic ice sheets were to melt, sea level would rise 60 meters or 200 feet, affecting  600 million people living on land that will go below sea level or regular flood levels by the end of the century

HOW?- can we all contribute!

·  Doing our bit of living as sustain-ably as we can by reducing our carbon footprint and becoming active in our local community.

·  Think about investing in renewable energy for your house.

·  The responsibility is  now upon each one of us to engage a change in the society and join more hands to combat climate change.

Would you all join me?

·  I invite you to support me in raising awareness about this cause and help make this world a better place. Please help me raise $5,000 through this forum. Every contribution counts!

·  Of course monetary donations are not the only way to help. Any advice, encouragements, or comments would be awesome!

You can help in multiple ways!

·  Share this page with your colleagues, family, friends and people you know are passionate about sustainability, climate change and saving Earth.

·  Share the link on your social media pages to help us spread the word.

·  Use the Indiegogo share tools.

WHEN?- is this expedition!

I will be taking on this once in a lifetime journey to Antarctica from 13th March- 25th March 2015.

Reference links
Robert's TED Talk:
http://www.ted.com/talks/robert_swan_let_s_save_the_last_pristine_continent

Leadership on the edge:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zCUeX7XdzW0

From words to action - Lessons from Antarctica:

 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w76GGM7SVC0

Website link :

 http://www.2041.com/overview.php

story:
Update: we were fully funded by our campaign deadline of Oct 14, 2019, and we successfully completed both trips! To contribute to Cycle for Science's future efforts, visit our website and click the "donate" button. To check out our adventures, read our xNL blog and xNY blog!
 

overview

Cycle for Science is a grassroots solution to address major challenges in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and climate change awareness. We accomplish this by sending early career scientists (aka “sci-clists”) on bicycle tours to teach interactive lessons about their research in classrooms. Our aim is to introduce the creativity, diversity and urgency of climate and renewable energy-related science, while both literally and figuratively meeting communities where they are.

In the late spring of 2015, scientists Elizabeth Case and Rachel Woods-Robinson launched Cycle for Science with a bicycle ride across the United States, teaching hands-on lessons about solar energy and physics to >1,000 students. Two years later in 2017, Johanna Heyer and Kelly Jiang joined Rachel in a pilot week-long Cycle for Science through the California Central Valley, reaching another 1,000 students.

Fast forward two more years to 2019, and Cycle for Science is returning for a double whammy! A bi-Cycle for Science! This time, Rachel and Elizabeth are independently launching their own week-long trips, back-to-back on two different continents. These tours will focus on two unique themes: solar energy materials engineering, and the past and present climate.

  1. C4S Netherlands → Materials: During our first international trip, Rachel will be joined by two female professors (!) Prof. Mónica Morales Masis and Prof. Rebecca Saive, as well as mathematician Lennart Bastian, to traverse the Netherlands and teach about solar cell materials science using a make-you-own dye-sensitized solar cell lesson.
  2. C4S Hudson River → Glaciers: Elizabeth Case and colleagues from the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory will lead a trip through New York's Hudson River Valley, stopping in schools to teach students how ice moves and shapes landscapes using "glacier goo" demos.

 

To accomplish these two ambitious trips and bring our interactive lessons into every classroom, we need your help.

 

motivation

Ok so what exactly is Cycle for Science? And — you’re probably wondering — why are we crazy enough to do this darn thing for a third and fourth time?

Climate change continues to ravage our world, and we are still nowhere near a global solution. The ppm of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere has soared to at least 410 ppm. Global temperature has risen by at least 0.85ºC since 1880, and will continue to rise if we do not dramatically change the way we use and generate energy. We have witnessed global disasters brought about by our inaction, such as the ongoing fires devastating the Amazon, melting in the Arctic and Antarctic, and devastation by drought and floods of homes and cities worldwide. Now more than ever, the world urgently needs politically conscious scientists and creative STEM innovation in renewable energy fields. We believe this starts with science and mobilizing the next generation.

As scientists, we strongly believe that it is our duty to share the pressing need for renewable energy and climate research with the public, and to reach out to younger generations to get them excited about science. In today's political climate, when the very idea of facts and objective knowledge is under attack, it is increasingly important to stand up for science, and to inspire the next generation of scientists to keep working toward an inclusive, sustainable, and equitable future.

Additionally, women and people of color are still highly underrepresented in STEM majors and STEM careers. We need a diverse working body of scientists and scientifically literate citizens to come up with creative solutions to the world’s most pressing issues, such as climate change.

 

mission

Cycle for Science brings interactive, renewable-energy and climate change focused science lessons to communities by bicycle. Our driving mission (well, bicycling mission) is fourfold:

  1. Introduce the next generation of global scientists and citizens to renewable energy, climate science, and basic physics, in a way that is creative, hands-on, and culturally relevant.
  2. Bring young, diverse scientists into classrooms across the country to provide students with real examples of who scientists are, what they do, and why they do it.
  3. Enable scientists to learn from and connect with communities outside academia.
  4. Demonstrate to students and scientists, via our trip (centered around a carbon-free energy generation method ... pedal power!), that science is an epic adventure. That’s what makes it exciting.

 

c4s Netherlands → materials

Cycle for Science Netherlands will expand upon our pilot Cycle for Science lesson, which teaches students about solar energy through a 3D-printed, solar-powered miniature bicycle called the Sol Cycle. The new feature of this lesson will incorporate materials physics and device challenges that Mónica and Rebecca research in their laboratories at the University of Twente, and Rachel researches as part of her 2019 ThinkSwiss research fellowship at EPFL. We will have an activity where students assemble their own dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) using very simple ingredients: raspberries, pencils (graphite), titanium dioxide paste (what’s in mineral sunscreen), an electrolyte solution. Although these are very low efficiency cells, their development has paved the way for perovskite photovoltaics (PV) and their simplicity allows for a safe interactive lesson. With two generous donations from EPFL’s PV-Lab and hiLyte Power, we will compare the properties of our DSSCs with a variety of other Si and thin film cells, both commercial and research modules, and then have students test some of these cells using multimeters and the Sol Cycle. This comparison will give a sense of the materials challenges required to make a high performing solar cell. We will use this hands-on activity as a launching point to discuss real-world challenges of PV, including grid integration, and the need for energy storage.

A dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC) device schematic, materials we’ll be using for the lesson, the lesson in action, and an array of DSSCs in action.


This is also the first Cycle for Science excursion outside of the United States. By spreading the message of the role of solar energy, and connecting it with our own faces and passions, we hope to inspire more students to start thinking about these time-sensitive problems and how they can put their minds together to work towards a better future.

A fleet of Sol Cycles prepping for take-off at a middle school in Sacramento in 2015.


This trip will launch on Sunday, September 15 at the Netherlands’ eastern border with Germany and cycle 30-60 miles (~45-90 km) daily to end near Den Helder on Monday, September 23. Our team of sci-clists will teach the first lesson near University of Twente in Enschede (where Mónica and Rebecca are professors), and then traverse the entire country to ride from the east border to the Atlantic Ocean and teach in six classes along the way. Our exact stops and schools are still being arranged, but here is a tentative sketch of the route:

Tentative sketch of C4S Netherlands route.

 

c4s New York → glaciers

Cycle for Science New York will focus on understanding how glaciers shape the landscape and respond to climate, and how natural climate variability differs from human-caused climate change. Cycling through the Hudson Valley, which was covered by the Laurentide Ice Sheet 20,000 years ago, we will teach students how ice moves, builds and erases landscapes, and how understanding the past can inform our predictions of the future. The classroom-portion of the lesson will use a variety of hands-on activities to demonstrate natural climate cycles, glacier flow, and how glacier geology is formed. After, we will take students outside and look at evidence of the Laurentide ice sheet like glacial striations, rounded hilltops, glacial erratics and meltwater channels (like the Hudson River). Students will learn that the land is history, and that evidence of the massive changes that happen in Earth’s geologic cycle remain in their backyards. We will disentangle natural changes from current, anthropogenic changes and discuss the future of ice on earth. By comparing the pace of natural climate cycles with the devastatingly quick human-driven processes, we hope to inspire students to help lead climate change adaptation in their own communities.

DIY "glacier goo" instructions (from CReSIS), a "glacier goo" experiment in action (from Mariana Esteves of Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory), and a glacier (taken by our very own Elizabeth Case in Glacier Bay during her 2019 summer field research).

Elizabeth will lead a tour of graduate students and postdocs from the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. This trip will start with a lesson in New York City on Monday, October 7, and cycle 20 miles each day to arrive in Poughkeepsie, NY on Friday, October 11. Here is a tentative route of this trip:

Tentative sketch of C4S New York route.

 

team

Each team member is a scientist and avid cyclist, is an expert in their respective fields, and is passionate about science communication:
 

Co-founders Rachel Woods-Robinson and Elizabeth Case teaching  (L) and on the road (R).
 

Elizabeth Case is the co-founder of Cycle for Science, and will be leading the Hudson River trip. She is a Ph.D. student at Columbia University and the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory studying how glaciers flow and melt. She is an NSF Graduate Fellow, and has been recognized for her writing and journalism along with her science. She believes strongly in the power of community outreach, and is actively involved at Columbia and through the Juneau Icefield Research Program, a summer trek that teaches undergraduates glaciology and mountaineering in one of the most beautiful places on earth. When she's not outside, she plucks the banjo, speaks gently to her plants, and climbs.

Rachel Woods-Robinson is the co-founder of Cycle for Science, participated in the 2017 Central Valley trip, and will be leading the Netherlands trip. She is a Ph.D. student at UC Berkeley, and is a UC Chancellor’s Fellow NSF Graduate Fellow. Her thesis research, conducted at Berkeley Lab and the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), focuses on high-throughput computation and synthesis of new materials for solar energy applications. She is actively involved in STEM outreach and mentorship, and in 2017 taught Cycle the Rockies, an undergraduate course where students ride bicycles across Montana to learn about renewable energy. She carries a harmonica, headlamp, and hammock with her at all times in case adventure strikes.

 

New C4S Netherland team members adventuring! (L to R) Mónica Morales Masis, Rebecca Saive, and Lennart Bastian.

Mónica Morales Masis is an Assistant Professor at the University of Twente in The Netherlands. She is a Physicist and Materials Scientist interested in Renewable Energy, Science Education, Art and Cycle for Science! She is an Advisor of hiLyte Power and a former Project Leader at EPFL's Photovoltaics Laboratory (both 2019 sponsors of Cycle for Science!). She joined C4S for the Netherlands adventure. While building her lab and growing her team to make and study materials for solar cells, she joined C4S to inspire and share with young and future scientists this passion for science and renewable energy!

Rebecca Saive is an Assistant Professor of Applied Physics working on photonic materials systems for solar cells at the University of Twente in the Netherlands where she started in January 2018. From 2014 to 2018 she was a postdoc and senior research scientist at California Institute of Technology and graduated with her PhD from the University of Heidelberg, Germany in 2014. Rebecca is also co-founder of ETC Solar, an award-winning Caltech start-up commercializing front contacts for solar cells. Rebecca loves to transmit her passion for science, renewable energy, and ........ solar cells!!! She has been organizing and participating in outreach events for almost a decade, and will be joining the Netherlands trip. In her free time she enjoys horse riding, dancing, gardening and other stuff that involves fresh air. 

Lennart Bastian's passion for biking and the outdoors began at a young age, but it wasn’t until his childhood friend Rachel introduced him to bike touring that he discovered his favorite way of exploring the outdoors. Lennart joined Cycle for Science for an opportunity to share his passion for the natural sciences and outdoor preservation, as he continues to pursue a Masters degree in Applied Mathematics at the TU Munich.

Link to bios of past team members, Johanna Heyer and Kelly Jiang.

… and you? We are still looking for qualified and interested sci-clists to joining either of these two trips! We are also looking for sci-clists to pilot their own trips in the future, please reach out if you are interested in starting your own Cycle for Science.

 

budget

We aim to keep costs low for all parties: the lessons are completely free for teachers and students, and the teacher training is free for participating sci-clists. Our fundraising goal of $5000 primarily covers the costs of (1) lesson materials for Cycle for Science: Materials, (2) emergency funds, travel funds, and lodging, and (3) feeding and housing sci-clists during the trips. These funds will also cover the costs of travel, gear, and promo material, though lesson materials will be prioritized. In the event that we do not reach our fundraising goal, we will cover all costs personally. In the event that we exceed our fundraising goal, leftover funds will be retained for use on future Cycle for Science trips, prototyping future lessons, and expanding Cycle for Science into a 501(c)3 non-profit organization.

Below is an approximate breakdown of our costs:

  • Lessons for Netherlands trip: $1,605.00
  • Lessons for Glaciers trip: $227.00
  • Transport & lodging for Netherlands trip: $755.00
  • Transport & lodging for Glaciers trip: $349.00
  • Food: $1,400.00
  • Project Maintenance: $318.00
  • Bicycle support: $346.00

Since we are starting this campaign less than three weeks before the first trip, we will plan to leave it running during both adventures and for a couple weeks afterwards.

 

perks

In exchange for your donations, we are offering our greatest hit from our past crowdfunding campaigns …. STICKERS! That’s right, high quality stickers that Elizabeth and Rachel designed in-house (in-tent?). They can be plopped onto your bicycle, your laptop, a state capitol building (nope, that’s never happened…), your forehead, you name it! Here is a preview of some of the stickers that you’ll be receiving, as well as a pile of buttons. We have a slew of other perks available at various tiers of sponsorship. As always, we will add your name to the "superstar funders" section of our website, as described below.

Some perks of helping out your friendly neighborhood sci-clists.

 

partners

We'd like to acknowledge some of the people and organizations that have made this project possible throughout the years, both for these current trips and in the past:

  • A group of over 150 "superstar funders" aka individuals who have donated to our past crowdfunding efforts (listed here on our website ... add your name to the ranks by donating $10 or more to this campaign! If you're a multi-year funder we'll add you to your own special section!)
  • David Lambelet and hiLyte Power for donating 3D printing resources and expertise
  • Professor Christophe Ballif and EPFL's Photovoltaics Laboratory (PV-lab) for donating PV modules
  • Spectacle Marketing for tips on how to best reach and impact the STEM community 
  • Rock the Bike for past sponsorship and donation of cycling resources
  • The Materials Research Society (MRS) for past sponsorship
  • The American Physical Society's (APS) Education and Diversity Division for past endorsement
  • North American Association for Environmental Education (NAAEE) for past endorsement

 

Let us know if your company or organization is interested in a sponsorship -- we'd be happy to chat!

 

past trips

Map of past Cycle for Science trips, 2015-2018.

xUSA

In the summer of 2015, Rachel and Elizabeth cycled 3,500 miles for science, from San Francisco to New York City. Along the way we stopped in classrooms, libraries, and summer camps to premier the Sol Cycle, catalyze conversations about renewable energy in science and society, and share our experiences as young women in STEM careers. We connected with over 1,000 students ages 4-17 from 13 different states, and left Sol Cycles in every classroom we visited. Along the way, we shared our experiences in the classrooms and camps with our community via social media and on our blog. 
 

xCA

Then, from March 25 - 31, 2017, Rachel was joined by Johanna Heyer and Kelly Jiang to cycle over 200 miles through the California Central Valley from Sacramento to Fresno during their Spring Break. The sci-clists stopped primarily in middle school classrooms (as well as one elementary school and one museum) to teach about climate change, renewable energy, and basic energy conversion to over 1,000 K-12 students.

 

publicity and awards

Here are links to some of the publicity we have received:

  • NBC Nightly News

 
  • US Department of Energy
    • Blog
    • Feature Video

 

  • Materials Research Society (MRS)
    • Article
    • Feature Video

 

And some of our most memorable moments:

  • A group of fifth grade girls came up to us after our lesson in Boise, ID, and started flooding us with questions about science. One girl marched up and asserted: “I want to do what you do when I grow up.” We asked her what she meant, and she replied “bike across the country AND be a scientist!”
  • At the end of a lesson in Philadelphia with a group of Burmese refugee students, an eleventh grader who'd initially boasted "I hate science" told us, bright-eyed, that she was now interested in studying the role of international relations in renewable energy and science, and maybe going to college to do so.
  • On the same day we climbed the Great Divide in Wyoming, we came nearly face to face with a GRIZZLY BEAR on the side of the road, and made lingering eye contact. Fortunately for us, it was distracted by the rodent dangling out of its mouth. We felt an intense fight or flight moment — we chose the latter, and raw adrenaline pushed us up the rest of the Rockies to the highest point of the entire trip (10,000 feet).

Because of our work with Cycle for Science, Elizabeth and Rachel were selected in 2016 to be part of the inaugural class of the SHIFT Emerging Leaders Program (ELP), and were finalists for the 2016 SHIFT Youth Leadership Award. And the Cycle for Science pilot lesson won the Outstanding Outreach Award through Quantum Energy and Sustainable Solar Technologies (QESST), an NSF-DOE Engineering Research Center that studies photovoltaics.

 

looking forward

We expect these two new projects to be highly impactful in various ways. This fall, we anticipate direct engagement with at least 2,000 students, the development of two more open source curricula for teachers to use freely, and the training of at least four more Cycle for Science educators. By using these funds to train educators, we expect the impacts and inspiration to ripple outward across the scientific community.

Starting with our adapted pilot lesson and this new lesson, we will work with educators to compile an interactive, regularly-updated online repository of high quality, relevant, hands-on lessons that address the Next Generation Science Standards for renewable energy and climate change. We already share the Sol Cycle’s 3D printable file and our lesson plan for free on our website, and a variety of different outreach organizations have been using the Sol Cycle as a teaching tool! These include the Lending Library at Cornell’s xRaise, an NSF-funded science outreach program, the QESST outreach library, and volunteer groups in Sweden, Philadelphia, and Indiana. We are working on new lesson plans around making your own “DIY-cycle,” as well as prototyping a “Sol Cycle 2.0.” These complementary goals will link communities with scientists in meaningful, long-lasting ways.

Our ultimate goal for Cycle for Science is to create a network of diverse scientists who embark on bicycle adventures to connect with their communities about science. The length of the trip, location, and subject matter are very flexible as long as the mission of the trip is to empower and inspire the next generation with science. Join us!

 

“Those who have the privilege to know have the duty to act, and in that action are the seeds of new knowledge.”

— Albert Einstein.

 

 

Thank you for your support, we could not do this without you.

See you on the bike path.
story_txt:
Update: we were fully funded by our campaign deadline of Oct 14, 2019, and we successfully completed both trips! To contribute to Cycle for Science's future efforts, visit our website and click the "donate" button. To check out our adventures, read our xNL blog and xNY blog! overviewCycle for Science is a grassroots solution to address major challenges in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and climate change awareness. We accomplish this by sending early career scientists (aka “sci-clists”) on bicycle tours to teach interactive lessons about their research in classrooms. Our aim is to introduce the creativity, diversity and urgency of climate and renewable energy-related science, while both literally and figuratively meeting communities where they are.In the late spring of 2015, scientists Elizabeth Case and Rachel Woods-Robinson launched Cycle for Science with a bicycle ride across the United States, teaching hands-on lessons about solar energy and physics to >1,000 students. Two years later in 2017, Johanna Heyer and Kelly Jiang joined Rachel in a pilot week-long Cycle for Science through the California Central Valley, reaching another 1,000 students.Fast forward two more years to 2019, and Cycle for Science is returning for a double whammy! A bi-Cycle for Science! This time, Rachel and Elizabeth are independently launching their own week-long trips, back-to-back on two different continents. These tours will focus on two unique themes: solar energy materials engineering, and the past and present climate.

C4S Netherlands → Materials: During our first international trip, Rachel will be joined by two female professors (!) Prof. Mónica Morales Masis and Prof. Rebecca Saive, as well as mathematician Lennart Bastian, to traverse the Netherlands and teach about solar cell materials science using a make-you-own dye-sensitized solar cell lesson.

C4S Hudson River → Glaciers: Elizabeth Case and colleagues from the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory will lead a trip through New York's Hudson River Valley, stopping in schools to teach students how ice moves and shapes landscapes using "glacier goo" demos.
 To accomplish these two ambitious trips and bring our interactive lessons into every classroom, we need your help. motivationOk so what exactly is Cycle for Science? And — you’re probably wondering — why are we crazy enough to do this darn thing for a third and fourth time?Climate change continues to ravage our world, and we are still nowhere near a global solution. The ppm of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere has soared to at least 410 ppm. Global temperature has risen by at least 0.85ºC since 1880, and will continue to rise if we do not dramatically change the way we use and generate energy. We have witnessed global disasters brought about by our inaction, such as the ongoing fires devastating the Amazon, melting in the Arctic and Antarctic, and devastation by drought and floods of homes and cities worldwide. Now more than ever, the world urgently needs politically conscious scientists and creative STEM innovation in renewable energy fields. We believe this starts with science and mobilizing the next generation.As scientists, we strongly believe that it is our duty to share the pressing need for renewable energy and climate research with the public, and to reach out to younger generations to get them excited about science. In today's political climate, when the very idea of facts and objective knowledge is under attack, it is increasingly important to stand up for science, and to inspire the next generation of scientists to keep working toward an inclusive, sustainable, and equitable future.Additionally, women and people of color are still highly underrepresented in STEM majors and STEM careers. We need a diverse working body of scientists and scientifically literate citizens to come up with creative solutions to the world’s most pressing issues, such as climate change. missionCycle for Science brings interactive, renewable-energy and climate change focused science lessons to communities by bicycle. Our driving mission (well, bicycling mission) is fourfold:
Introduce the next generation of global scientists and citizens to renewable energy, climate science, and basic physics, in a way that is creative, hands-on, and culturally relevant.
Bring young, diverse scientists into classrooms across the country to provide students with real examples of who scientists are, what they do, and why they do it.

Enable scientists to learn from and connect with communities outside academia.
Demonstrate to students and scientists, via our trip (centered around a carbon-free energy generation method ... pedal power!), that science is an epic adventure. That’s what makes it exciting.
 c4s Netherlands → materialsCycle for Science Netherlands will expand upon our pilot Cycle for Science lesson, which teaches students about solar energy through a 3D-printed, solar-powered miniature bicycle called the Sol Cycle. The new feature of this lesson will incorporate materials physics and device challenges that Mónica and Rebecca research in their laboratories at the University of Twente, and Rachel researches as part of her 2019 ThinkSwiss research fellowship at EPFL. We will have an activity where students assemble their own dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) using very simple ingredients: raspberries, pencils (graphite), titanium dioxide paste (what’s in mineral sunscreen), an electrolyte solution. Although these are very low efficiency cells, their development has paved the way for perovskite photovoltaics (PV) and their simplicity allows for a safe interactive lesson. With two generous donations from EPFL’s PV-Lab and hiLyte Power, we will compare the properties of our DSSCs with a variety of other Si and thin film cells, both commercial and research modules, and then have students test some of these cells using multimeters and the Sol Cycle. This comparison will give a sense of the materials challenges required to make a high performing solar cell. We will use this hands-on activity as a launching point to discuss real-world challenges of PV, including grid integration, and the need for energy storage.A dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC) device schematic, materials we’ll be using for the lesson, the lesson in action, and an array of DSSCs in action.This is also the first Cycle for Science excursion outside of the United States. By spreading the message of the role of solar energy, and connecting it with our own faces and passions, we hope to inspire more students to start thinking about these time-sensitive problems and how they can put their minds together to work towards a better future.A fleet of Sol Cycles prepping for take-off at a middle school in Sacramento in 2015.This trip will launch on Sunday, September 15 at the Netherlands’ eastern border with Germany and cycle 30-60 miles (~45-90 km) daily to end near Den Helder on Monday, September 23. Our team of sci-clists will teach the first lesson near University of Twente in Enschede (where Mónica and Rebecca are professors), and then traverse the entire country to ride from the east border to the Atlantic Ocean and teach in six classes along the way. Our exact stops and schools are still being arranged, but here is a tentative sketch of the route:Tentative sketch of C4S Netherlands route. c4s New York → glaciersCycle for Science New York will focus on understanding how glaciers shape the landscape and respond to climate, and how natural climate variability differs from human-caused climate change. Cycling through the Hudson Valley, which was covered by the Laurentide Ice Sheet 20,000 years ago, we will teach students how ice moves, builds and erases landscapes, and how understanding the past can inform our predictions of the future. The classroom-portion of the lesson will use a variety of hands-on activities to demonstrate natural climate cycles, glacier flow, and how glacier geology is formed. After, we will take students outside and look at evidence of the Laurentide ice sheet like glacial striations, rounded hilltops, glacial erratics and meltwater channels (like the Hudson River). Students will learn that the land is history, and that evidence of the massive changes that happen in Earth’s geologic cycle remain in their backyards. We will disentangle natural changes from current, anthropogenic changes and discuss the future of ice on earth. By comparing the pace of natural climate cycles with the devastatingly quick human-driven processes, we hope to inspire students to help lead climate change adaptation in their own communities.DIY "glacier goo" instructions (from CReSIS), a "glacier goo" experiment in action (from Mariana Esteves of Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory), and a glacier (taken by our very own Elizabeth Case in Glacier Bay during her 2019 summer field research).Elizabeth will lead a tour of graduate students and postdocs from the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. story:
Quest for the Inaccessible Pole Expedition

There is something hugely positive going on.

In February 2015, the Ice Warrior Project is undertaking one of the most significant and ambitious polar expeditions of our time; to be the first expedition in history to reach the Northern Pole of Inaccessibility, carrying out crucial scientific research along our journey. 

The Ice Warrior Project is unique. Founded by Jim McNeill, an accomplished polar veteran with over 30 years's extreme expeditioning, the remaining team-members are ordinary people from all walks of life, with little or no experience of polar explorations, pushing themselves to their limits for the benefit of modern-day exploration and scientific advancement. 

    To the very centre of the Arctic Ocean - for the first time in history

    The Northern Pole of Inaccessibility is defined as the most distant point from land; the very centre of the Arctic Ocean. Our transect is an 800 mile journey from the northern shores of Canada. As Scientific American put it: "Of all the places on the surface of the Earth, few are harder to reach than the appropriately named north pole of inaccessibility." It remains the last truly significant place in the Polar Regions yet to be reached by mankind. 
    The journey will take our team more than 80 days, across treacherously unstable sea-ice, in one of the most inhospitable environments on Earth. We will face relentless cold temperatures of -50°C that will freeze flesh in seconds. There will be the ever-present threat of polar bear attack. 


    Ordinary people, doing extraordinary things

    Our journey will be split into 4 legs, each 20 days in duration and hopefully 200 miles in length. 6 team members will accompany Jim on each leg, skiing for up to 16 hours per day and hauling more than our bodyweight behind us. 
    We are not seasoned explorers. The Ice Warrior Project is about training ordinary people from all walks of life, all echelons of society and all nations to become competent, safe modern-day explorers, undertaking ground-breaking, purposeful and worthwhile expeditions. 

    We still don't know enough about global change - you can be a part of changing this

    The state of the Arctic Ocean is one of the most important unfolding stories of global concern. The Polar Regions are vital ‘early warning indicators’ of climate change; the Arctic, for example, is warming at a rate of almost twice the global average. Yet, ironically, we have only a limited understanding of the change. Despite satellites and modern technology, the data required to probe this can only be gathered reliably on the ground. And without this data, it is near-impossible to assess the impact of our mitigating actions.

    Our expedition is a major ‘citizen science’ project. By going to the very centre of the Arctic Ocean, we will build a full transect dataset for the first time. Our mission is to gather frequent, crucial field data on ice composition, thickness and break-up, to allow leading scientists to better understand the state of the Arctic sea.

    The data we gather will be used in partnership with leading global institutes including: the NASA-funded National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), The Met Office, Royal Geographical Society, The Scott Polar Research Institute, The Norwegian Polar Institute and the Russian Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute.


    How can you get involved?

    For over half a century we have known that the world's extreme environments convey the pulse of the planet. If we are to be real guardians of our planet then we have to research, understand and share our knowledge of these regions.

    You can join us to achieve a major citizen science endeavour, and a polar world first. You can be a part of history.

    1. Help fund the Expedition Team - pledge a financial contribution (see our list of rewards on the right-hand side of this page)
    2. Like our links on Facebook and Twitter
    3. Spread the word! Tell and share this link with 3 other people 

    Why do we need this money?

    An endeavour of this size means huge commitment, in terms of time, training and finances. It is something we believe passionately about, and so we are all putting in the long hours to ensure a strong and successful team, in terms of team building, technical proficiency, and physical and mental fitness.

    But it is also costly. Team members need to fund part of the expedition itself (including the science), as well as paying for their own individual expenses.

    Any contributions made towards the expedition will be used for:

    • Logistics i.e. transport in & out of base camp, fuel, etc.
    • Scientific research
    • Kit and equipment
    • Food

    Note: the total costs of this expedition are much, much greater than the £75,000 goal we have targeted. Those wishing to contribute a larger sum should contact us directly – we have a range of unique rewards that we would be happy to discuss.

    In addition, the more funding we raise, the more science we are able to do. Should we exceed our goal, we hope to broaden the scientific scope of our mission – for example, purchasing a specialist drone to help us to monitor thermodynamics of the sea ice.

    Beyond money - become an Ice Warrior advocate and spread the word

    A core part of the Ice Warrior Project is about building awareness of our mission, our expedition, and our findings. Whether you donate to our campaign or not, you can still help us to make history. Here are some ways you can help:

    • Spread the word about the Ice Warrior Project #lastpole on Facebook or Twitter
    • Connect us to those who might be interested in this expedition
    • Stay connected. Follow Ice Warrior on Facebook and on Twitter to stay up-to-date as the expedition develops
    • Tell us how you would like to get involved!
story_txt:
Quest for the Inaccessible Pole Expedition
There is something hugely positive going on.
In February 2015, the Ice Warrior Project is undertaking one of the most significant and ambitious polar expeditions of our time; to be the first expedition in history to reach the Northern Pole of Inaccessibility, carrying out crucial scientific research along our journey. 
The Ice Warrior Project is unique. Founded by Jim McNeill, an accomplished polar veteran with over 30 years's extreme expeditioning, the remaining team-members are ordinary people from all walks of life, with little or no experience of polar explorations, pushing themselves to their limits for the benefit of modern-day exploration and scientific advancement. 

  To the very centre of the Arctic Ocean - for the first time in history
The Northern Pole of Inaccessibility is defined as the most distant point from land; the very centre of the Arctic Ocean. Our transect is an 800 mile journey from the northern shores of Canada. As Scientific American put it: "Of all the places on the surface of the Earth, few are harder to reach than the appropriately named north pole of inaccessibility." It remains the last truly significant place in the Polar Regions yet to be reached by mankind. 
The journey will take our team more than 80 days, across treacherously unstable sea-ice, in one of the most inhospitable environments on Earth. We will face relentless cold temperatures of -50°C that will freeze flesh in seconds. There will be the ever-present threat of polar bear attack. 
  
Ordinary people, doing extraordinary things


Our journey will be split into 4 legs, each 20 days in duration and hopefully 200 miles in length. 6 team members will accompany Jim on each leg, skiing for up to 16 hours per day and hauling more than our bodyweight behind us. 
We are not seasoned explorers. The Ice Warrior Project is about training ordinary people from all walks of life, all echelons of society and all nations to become competent, safe modern-day explorers, undertaking ground-breaking, purposeful and worthwhile expeditions. 




We still don't know enough about global change - you can be a part of changing this

story:
Salam (Peace) from Palestine! 

The Marda Permaculture Farm is a working farm and demonstration site for permaculture principles, techniques and strategies in Palestine. Based in the picturesque ancient village of Marda, the project promotes food sovereignty, health, self-reliance and empowerment.  This is accomplished through modeling water harvesting, recycling, energy conservation and home-scale garden production with readily available and locally-appropriate materials.

Farm Founder and Director Murad AlKhufash has long dreamed of a Teaching Building using natural materials and techniques such as earth bag construction, cobb, adobe, and local building technologies.  The building, which would maximize space at two stories would provide a much needed office, indoor space for workshops, and lodging for interns and volunteers.

We are ready to begin this process, with your help!  $4000 will support Murad in launching the project by working with students at nearby Birzeit University to complete renderings for the building, begin the permitting process, and initiate a Natural Building Workshop  April 2015 to jumpstart the project!

This Teaching Building will integrate passive and active solar power, rainwater catchment and graywater recycling, thus enabling the farm to go "off grid" and so reduce dependence on Israeli-controlled and high cost energy and water supplies.

Over the past eight years the farm has become a destination for international visitors as well local farmers and backyard gardeners.  The farm has thrived despite continual challenges posed by the occupation ranging from destructive hogs unleashed by settlers that destroyed crops and fences, high costs of materials, food, and water. 

Murad and his neighbors have endured ongoing curfews, harassment by the Israeli military, difficulty leaving and returning.  Thanks to Murad's dedication and strong partners the Farm has survived, on a shoestring.

We are grateful for your contribution and our farm has bounties to offer to send a warm thank you for believing in our cause. Olive oil, organic soap and from Palestine as well as fantastic donations from our international allies Starhawk, Albert Bates, and Brad Lancaster are our small thank you for your generous support, with an open invitation to visit us in the Marda Permaculture Farm and Palestine anytime.

Please specify "Marda Teaching Building " in comments sections when submitting the donation.

Please share widely with friends and colleagues who are passionate about the environment, farming, sustainable agriculture and Palestine.  Just spreading the word about the work we do will be very much appreciated.

Our next Permaculture Design Course with instructors Klaudia Van Gool and Leslie Buerk will take place from March 25 to April 10, 2015.   April Natural Building Course to be announced soon!

Please consider joining us!

Shukran (Thank you) from the Marda Permaculture Team!

story:
This year's class of newborns turns north this March with their mothers. The seasonal migration intersects with an increasingly dangerous industrialized ocean. We are in the ship channel when the migration transits Rhode Island, in a position to be able to help them.

Rhode Island Sound is critical right whale habitat

THE BASICS

Rhode Island Marine Animal Support (RIMAS) uses a fast powerboat to monitor threats to right whales in Rhode Island Sound.  The crew is comprised of a National Park Service field biologist, a Scuba instructor, a paramedic, a NOAA technician, a heavy equipment operator, a crewman on the Martha's Vineyard ferry, a retired Air Force mechanic, a marine engineer, and a licensed boat captain.

Last week a small plane pilot volunteered to fly for us. 

So it's a good crew.

The boat alone at the dock in March 2014, ready to go

The goal of our winter 2015 campaign is to fund our fuel budget of $10,000 for the migration months of March, April, and May.

We need this fuel to get us out into right whales' migration route, where we can intercede for them, to prevent ship collisions, to locate entangled whales, and to lead disentanglement teams to them. Also to monitor ship traffic to slow it down through the migration area. 

We have a strong, fast boat, and satphone communication with our network in Massachusetts and Connecticut. 

All your donations will go directly to buying gas for the boat.


THE FIRST WHALE TO BE HUNTED COMMERCIALLY
They were driven to the brink of extinction by centuries of whaling, reaching a low of 100 individuals in 1900. Recovery of the population is being severely hampered by mortalities that could be avoided, if stronger protections were put into place, and existing laws were enforced. Every loss of a reproductive female and her newborn is an especially damaging blow to the population. Thanks to protections under the Endangered Species Act right whales have made a modest comeback to 500 individuals in recent years, but commercial activity along the coast is keeping the species perilously near extinction. Our goal is to see a more robust population, with lower mortality along the migration route.

GILLNETS & LOBSTER LINES ARE A LEADING CAUSE OF MORTALITY

Entanglement in vertical lines and buoys from lobster & crab traps...

Entanglement in gill nets, vertical lines and buoys...

Right whales are the most coastal of whales. Seasonal migration requires them to swim 1,000 miles of ocean choked with industrial activity. 

Fishing boats use thousands of miles of nylon gill nets and the vertical nylon ropes that connect buoys on the surface to lobster and crab traps on the ocean floor, entangling ropes that arc hundreds of feet from the seabed back to floating buoys. In the dark water, at the depths that right whales hunt, entanglements can't be avoided. When a whale runs into one of these lines, the entanglement often delivers prolonged illness, starvation, and a terrible death.

Regulations about when and where commercial fishing can be done is a compromise between protecting the whales and allowing fishermen to earn a living. The gear fishermen are allowed to use is regulated to offer some measure of protection to whales, but the modified gear is not working well enough, and whales continue to die from entanglements in numbers that are preventing their recovery. Until they are afforded better protections, the difficult task of disentanglement will continue to be the option of last resort for those of us trying to protect right whales.

SHIP TRAFFIC IS A LEADING CAUSE OF MORTALITY

Commercial ship traffic in the Providence ship lanes

 Rhode Island ship traffic cuts through right whale habitat

Rhode Island Sound has a 10 knot speed limit for commercial shipping, but we see ships every day making 15 knots through areas protected by law, at speeds known to kill whales. With a hydrophone and good eyes we can report when whales are in the shipping lanes, and make these ships slow down.

Hydrophones (underwater microphones) tuned for the right frequencies do a good job recording right whales' distinctive voice. This year we'll add a hydrophone to our gear, and lower it at the entrance to the Providence shipping lanes.

Our photos and recordings will be posted at www.facebook.com/mvoceanstate and the website www.riwhale.com. Shipping companies are sensitive to public perceptions, so it is important to spotlight ships that ignore their responsibilities within the migratory area.


Examples of right whale vocals, including upcalls

Passive acoustic monitoring for right whales in Boston's shipping lanes

Our ship mortality reduction project has a shore-based component; using an AIS application running on an iMac and iPad we are able to monitor ship traffic when we can't be on the water, during bad weather and at night. Remote monitoring does not let us locate whales like the hydrophone does, but it does let us identify speeders and report them to the USCG and to our followers on Facebook. Until they are given better protections from ship strikes, the limited protections they have must be enforced, so we will closely watch Rhode Island Sound for ships that endanger the whales.


Passive monitoring ship speed from our office computer and iPad

Ocean State drifting in the shipping lanes

We are members of the Atlantic Large Whale Disentanglement Network (ALWDN) and operate under the authority of the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). 

MV OCEAN STATE is a 501 (c)(3) non-profit public charity under the IRS Code.

story:
The Overview

We are a team of researchers aiming to perform the first ever thorough biodiversity survey on the near-pristine but vulnerable island of Koh Rong Samloem, off the south coast of Cambodia.

Recent, small studies have found several new species of orchid and reptile, and it is likely that there are more to be discovered.

Ultimately, we want to establish how the island's fascinating ecosystems can be maintained in an area of the world undergoing rapid human development.

To achieve this, we will be working with a number of conservation groups on-site, surveying the ecological status of the islands Fauna and flora.

The Team
The expedition team is composed of postgraduate and undergraduate students from the University of Exeter and University College Falmouth. The project itself is entirely self-generated and is not a component of our courses.

We are working in collaboration with the Cambodian Royal University of Agriculture to help with field identification and to create links between Koh Rong Samloem and the three aforementioned universities.

In addition, we shall also be working with the Natural History Museum in London with regards invertebrate research, and Kew Gardens with regards to botanical research.

We are passionate about ecological and conservation research, and have gained the skills needed for this work through several years of both theoretical science education and practical field work in locations such as the mediterranean and southern Africa.

 

 

What else can you expect from us?

In addition to the perks that we are offering here, we shall also be providing blogs and video updates before, during and after the expedition. This way, we hope we can keep you as involved with the expedition as possible.

We will also be producing a documentary or two once we have completed the project, all our backers will receive recognition in the credits and will get to see them before anyone else.

What stage are we at?
We have already secured some funding in the form of an expeditions grant from the Royal Geographical Society, Percy Sladen Memorial Fund and the Gilchrist Educational Trust.

In addition we have each made personal contributions towards the project, a minimum of £500 each, allowing us to cover the cost of our flights, insurance and visas, but we also need your help.

Along with the funds outlined above, the £6,000 we raise here will fund the most critical elements of the project including in-country transport, food, accommodation and supplies. These essentials are what will make the project possible. If you are not in a position to contribute financially, please spread the word, via email, social networks and anything else you can think of.

Finally
Given that the majority of the islands in this region have and are undergoing substantial development for tourism, Koh Rong Samloem is one of the few of any size which still possesses most of it's intact ecosystems. Help us paint a picture of a place worth preserving as an example of how these Islands should look.

If you've read this far then you may want to check out our social media, which you can find here:

www.expeditionsamloem.org

https://www.facebook.com/expeditioncambodia

https://twitter.com/Ex_Samloem

Thanks for your time and helping us to make this happen!

story:
Who Am I?

World traveled, formerly working as a stunt woman, actor, model, filmmaker and massage therapist, (and still doing some of that) I am a passionate lover of nature, with a deep sensitivity to life, while also having a very strong drive and energy to build, create and get things done. An outta-the-box thinker, health enthusiast and activist, I have been supporting organic farming as long as it existed and have reaped the rewards of robust health because of it. I have designed and built an urban farm in Los Angeles, volunteered for LA Green Grounds to put organic gardens in the front yards of low income families in South Central LA, and grown gardens all my life whenever I had the chance. A recent trip to a village in Bulgaria where people still grow much of their food, as well as my growing awareness of the toxicity and corporate control of much of our food supply, has inspired me to make growing my own food a top priority. I left all my city life and work behind to move to the country and build a dream . . . to live in deep harmony with the land and teach others to do the same. I have the vision, and am very adept at getting support to build and create something out of nothing on a dry desert moutainside, based off of permaculture teachings and other innovative types of land managment.

I have found the perfect land in a small town not far from LA, in which the owner is willing to finance (no banks!) and we have agreed to terms that work for me. I am currently renting a room just down the street from the land which will make it easy to continue building and making the land productive while there is no house on the property (and much less expense). I am also writing a regular column about sustainability in the local paper, to create more awareness and support with the locals.

I believe in my abilities and resourcefulness to create all that is needed to build this farm. From work parties and workshops, to building with recycled materials and using what would normally be thrown away to create beautiful and functional structures and environments.

For more information on me and what I've done (films etc.), follow the links under 'What I've Done' below.

 

What I Need

I need $10,000 to close escrow, pay insurance and pay one year of property taxes. The land owner has agreed to low monthly payments for the first 5 months in order to get the ball rolling and the first episode of the documentary series shot and edited. $5,000 will be the downpayment, roughly $1500 for insurance, and $1,750 for the first years' property taxes (having this paid for up front will give me time to get things going before I take on that extra monthly expense). I'm estimating the escrow fees will make up the remainder of the money, along with Indiegogo's 4% they take out.

Indigogo will grant all donated funds regardless if I reach my goal, however they will charge a 9% fee if I don't. In the event that I don't make the entire goal, I can still use that money towards the downpayment and insurance.

Why am I doing this NOW instead of waiting until I've saved the money to buy the land myself? A. This land opportunity is perfect, no bank loan, very workable terms, great location, very unique property with tons of potential for what I'd like to create. B. As things change in our society, I feel like growing my own food and inspiring/teaching others to do the same is vital. With the corporate control of our government and food supply, we are losing many freedoms and drowning in unhealthy food and living situations. Help me make a difference by working towards change and inspiring it as well.

What You Get

Every level of donation will recieve a unique gift as specified underneath it. From my home made 'Killa Kale Chips,' a card with original artwork and a copy of my song, to Creativity Consultations, workshop attendance, an autographed copy of my book, a tree planted in your name, (with a plaque and a portion of the fruits shipped to you along with a picture of it), a creative farm structure built in your name with a plaque, a guest starring role in the documentary series of your choice, executive producer credit on the documentary series, a link to preview the first episode, and a DVD copy.

 

The Impact

I believe very strongly that organic sustainable farming and permaculture are the way of the future, as well as the solution to much of what ails society. I also believe that the more people learn to do things for themselves, and in harmony with the earth that feeds them, they will find much joy, health, connection to the environment and entertainment in the process. Help me show the world how fun this can be! Your support will not only help me build this farm, it will help to educate many people into believing in what they can do.

The Documentary

After the first episode is shot and edited, we will pitch it to the networks such as The Discovery Channel, History Channel, Oxygen etc. If we do not get picked up on any TV channel we will release the series on DVD. ES Films is producing the first episode at no cost, which I will direct. See links below to film and video work I have directed in the past.

What I've Already Done

Aside from building an Urban Farm in Los Angeles, volunteering to build gardens in front yards of low income homes in South Central LA, terracing hillsides in the desert, building numerous DIY projects from recycled/found/free materials, writing a regular column in the local paper about sustainability, traveling the world and studying people, their food and agricultural practices, researching extensively, and growing gardens my whole life, I have also produced, directed, written and filmed short films and videos. I have done so for free or very little money by being resourceful and creative (which is a great skill of mine). Feel free to view my IMDB credits and Youtube channels which contain much of my acting, stunt, activist, filmmaking and comedy work. I have also worked as a stunt coordinator and actor/stuntwoman on a Sci-Fi channel film called Red Faction where I was in charge of 19 stuntmen, choreographing 5 fight scenes with multiple people, while also having an acting/action role. This demonstrates my ability to take on large projects and coordinate many things at once.

To view my short film, movie trailer, acting and stunt work as well as some other videos I shot and directed, go to SarahBE1 on youtube http://www.youtube.com/user/sarahbe1.

To view some activist videos I shot, comedy (if you are uptight and conservative the comedy will offend you) and the first 'My Eco Farm Adventure' video diary I shot (not a professional video), go to SARAHBEtv on youtube http://www.youtube.com/user/SarahBEtv.

To view my film credits on IMDB: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1931990/

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to this campaign monetarily, please share it with as many people as you can to get the word out there. That will be an amazing and much appreciated contribution!!!
story_txt:
Who Am I?
World traveled, formerly working as a stunt woman, actor, model, filmmaker and massage therapist, (and still doing some of that) I am a passionate lover of nature, with a deep sensitivity to life, while also having a very strong drive and energy to build, create and get things done. An outta-the-box thinker, health enthusiast and activist, I have been supporting organic farming as long as it existed and have reaped the rewards of robust health because of it. I have designed and built an urban farm in Los Angeles, volunteered for LA Green Grounds to put organic gardens in the front yards of low income families in South Central LA, and grown gardens all my life whenever I had the chance. A recent trip to a village in Bulgaria where people still grow much of their food, as well as my growing awareness of the toxicity and corporate control of much of our food supply, has inspired me to make growing my own food a top priority. I left all my city life and work behind to move to the country and build a dream . . . to live in deep harmony with the land and teach others to do the same. I have the vision, and am very adept at getting support to build and create something out of nothing on a dry desert moutainside, based off of permaculture teachings and other innovative types of land managment.
I have found the perfect land in a small town not far from LA, in which the owner is willing to finance (no banks!) and we have agreed to terms that work for me. I am currently renting a room just down the street from the land which will make it easy to continue building and making the land productive while there is no house on the property (and much less expense). I am also writing a regular column about sustainability in the local paper, to create more awareness and support with the locals.
I believe in my abilities and resourcefulness to create all that is needed to build this farm. From work parties and workshops, to building with recycled materials and using what would normally be thrown away to create beautiful and functional structures and environments.
For more information on me and what I've done (films etc.), follow the links under 'What I've Done' below.
 


What I Need
I need $10,000 to close escrow, pay insurance and pay one year of property taxes. The land owner has agreed to low monthly payments for the first 5 months in order to get the ball rolling and the first episode of the documentary series shot and edited. $5,000 will be the downpayment, roughly $1500 for insurance, and $1,750 for the first years' property taxes (having this paid for up front will give me time to get things going before I take on that extra monthly expense). I'm estimating the escrow fees will make up the remainder of the money, along with Indiegogo's 4% they take out.
Indigogo will grant all donated funds regardless if I reach my goal, however they will charge a 9% fee if I don't. In the event that I don't make the entire goal, I can still use that money towards the downpayment and insurance.

This land opportunity is perfect, no bank loan, very workable terms, great location, very unique property with tons of potential for what I'd like to create. B. As things change in our society, I feel like growing my own food and inspiring/teaching others to do the same is vital. With the corporate control of our government and food supply, we are losing many freedoms and drowning in unhealthy food and living situations. Help me make a difference by working towards change and inspiring it as well.

Every level of donation will recieve a unique gift as specified underneath it. From my home made 'Killa Kale Chips,' a card with original artwork and a copy of my song, to Creativity Consultations, workshop attendance, an autographed copy of my book, a tree planted in your name, (with a plaque and a portion of the fruits shipped to you along with a picture of it), a creative farm structure built in your name with a plaque, a guest starring role in the documentary series of your choice, executive producer credit on the documentary series, a link to preview the first episode, and a DVD copy.

story:
Who is Michelle?

I am a 3rd year environmental science and engineering doctoral candidate at UCLA. My area of focus is in foreign policy and water security. I will be attending and presenting at the international water conference in Thessaloniki Greece in May 2015 (http://www.bywp2015.gr). 

My mission: To develop cross-cutting renewable energy technologies that provide clean water to developing countries. 

The theme of this project is trifold: clean energy, global governance, and women's leadership. This campaign will allow me to present my research on solar water desalination to international water and energy professionals. From this conference, I will network and gain the support of the participating energy leaders in the development of this device. Ultimately, collaborations and networking among scientists and policy makers are key in creating solutions to ameliorate water and sanitation issues.

Topics at the conference include:

  1. Water Management* (Water Loss – Mitigation Methods and Technologies - Drinking Water Treatment Technologies - Quality Monitoring and Identification - Aquifers Rehabilitation Technologies)
  2. Water Distribution, Modelling, Instrumentation & Asset Management
  3. Climate Change and Water Resources
  4. Wastewater Treatment Technologies and Disposal - Sewage Sludge Management - Water Reuse
  5. Sewerage Networks
  6. Industrial Waste Treatment and Disposal
  7. River Basins Management
  8. Legislation in the Water and Wastewater Sector
  9. Case studies are particularly welcome
  10. Remote sensing
The Model Trifecta
  1. Clean Energy: Solar powered water purification research for off-grid communities
  2. Global Governance: Transparent, accountable, and effective 
  3. Women's Leadership: Empowering women to be decision-makers and leaders in their community

What This Means For You

You will be contributing to the success of providing clean water in emerging countries through the use of clean energy. If you are a corporation, I can put you in touch with the key people that I meet at the conference (businesses and government officials).

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share my campaign to corporations and friends!
  • Be amazing.

story: Optimysstique a grass roots festival that creates connections  between wellness,sustainability,yoga,bodywork, agriculture, and food. Education practice and community are the tools. Historically the event has  created long term  benefits  for the community,environment and visitors alike. We've revived farms, discovered affordable health care and created great connections between members of our community and visitors.  Lasting relationships have been created at these events that gather like & conscious  minds. This fundraiser helps us perpetuate our work which is rarely funded by large or corporate donors but fills the voids in wellness,business,education, and arts  that is truly authentic,simple and effective.

story:
At 50 years old, you might say this tree has a "touch of grey." Someone wanted to destroy it...but for two years a married couple fought to save it. The tree survived. Today it's alive and grateful...

For almost two years, Hilary (Cunningham) and Stephen Scharper fought to save this tree. It was a long and expensive court battle, but the Scharpers won their case. It turned out to be a landmark ruling.

Now in cities cross Ontario, it is a criminal offense for one owner of a shared tree to arbitrarily cut it down without the co-owner’s consent. Thousands of trees have been highhandedly cut down in this way. This ruling helps put a stop to this devastating practice. Tens of thousands of trees are breathing easier as a result of this ruling, not only in Ontario but throughout Canada!

A landmark ruling...

With the help of two skilled and distinguished lawyers, Clayton Ruby and Nader Hasan, the Scharpers achieved landmark legal protection for trees.

Now the Ontario Forestry Act applies to municipal trees, carrying with it a potential fine of $20,000 or jail time for those who violate the law. Their case is now being taught in law schools in Canada, listed in the records of Canada's most important court rulings and, best of all, is being used by other property owners to protect their trees from senseless destruction. 

You can read more about their story at: www. boundary trees.com

100,000 donors and $1 campaign

Hilary and Stephen have accumulated tens-of-thousands-of-dollars in legal debts. If there are 100,000 tree-lovers out there who are willing to donate just $1 each, then the majority of their legal debts will be covered.

 100% of all funds received will go toward paying off the Scharpers' legal debts. Any funds accumulated over the amount of the Scharpers' legal debts will be donated to LEAF—Local Enhancement  and Appreciation of Forests. (http://www.yourleaf.org/)

story:
Thank you for taking the time to view my organization campaign. My name is Rev. Verna J. McClain. I am the President of National Soul Outreach For Christ Ministry International. A Non Profit, Non Denominational Missionary Outreach Organization, whom has been a Missionary for over 34 years.  I am now retired, and completing missions on a full time basis.

I  have 34 years of experience, traveling around the world to all Countries, building sustainable fresh water wells, and  growing natural food sources for indigenous people of all cultures, and religions.

This campaign is important to the People of Uganda. Whom are mostly young children, and elderly that have malaria, and no access to clean drinking water, or a sustainable source of food. 

Since 2008, my organization has used 100 % of all proceeds raised to build a well in the Village of Tororo, wherein this well serves 5000 people each day. I have also assisted in providing sustainable food, and other natural resources for many villages in Uganda.


I am now concentrating on overseeing more  fresh water wells being built, and sustainable food sources in  dire Villages of Uganda, and Kenya. The challenges that are currently faced are not being able to access fresh drinking water, and sustainable food due to lack of  available funds.

The challenges that I am facing, are the need to raise capital to meet the desperate needs. Your contribution to this project will save countless lives, and bring an end to unnecessary suffering. All proceeds raised are tax deductible. My organization is 100% accountable for every dollar received.  There are no risks,  I personally oversee the start, to completion of each project, wherein I have photos, videos will be taken of the before, and after work. Therefore you will know how great your contribution made to this desperate country in need is appreciated.

No donation is too small. If you are unable to donate at this time, we understand. If you could kindly, help share this campaign with others on Facebook, it would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance.

story:
Who are you?

I am just a random osu! player called Bass from Poland who is playing this circle-clicking game. I play with mouse and keyboard and I am not going to switch to tablet. http://osu.ppy.sh/u/Bass

Why do you need money for?

Simply - for getting better equipment to play(new PC etc) and being able to stay at lodgings and survive.

Why should I give you money?

You don't have to. I am not forcing anyone. If you feel like throwing me some money just do it. I will be very grateful.

Any benefits from giving you money?

You will help out poor guy. I didn't add any perks but if you will donate any money then be sure I will personally thank you or maybe even mutual or something.

Any risks?

None. I wrote already why do I need money.

story:
Education for a Changing Climate

We are two high school students who created the Cortez Youth for Climate, Blair Rice and Samuel Allsup, and we are dedicated to educating our community on the importance of climate change. We work in coalition with a local elementary school to educate groups of first through sixth graders. Our goal is to assist the children in planning a series of educational and interactive events, where they will share the knowledge they have gained. We then plan to create a presentation to show at the Polar Educators International workshop in Hannover, Germany.

The Presentation

Our presentation will highlight an outreach partnership between two high school students and a local elementary school. Sam and Blair, two high school students, mentored elementary students over a period of time,  engaging the younger children in activities focused around climate change and polar science. After spending time working with the students and engaging them in learning new things about our climate and global warming, we set the kids to the task of creating their own projects, with the aim of educating our small community on climate change and global warming. A few of the students' projects included video creation, hands-on experiments as well as art and writing projects. Their projects will be presented at local events and are intended to spread ideas and help in the fight against climate change and global warming.

What You're Funding
If you kick in to our campaign, you are paving the way for us to go to Germany and present our work. These funds are creating the base for educating the next generation on how our world is changing, and how to save it from self destructing. We are trying to prepare those who will have a different climate on their shoulders for what is to come, and making sure that our children will not be swept away by the sheer size of this problem, and the tides of a changing climate. We are asking for your help to build our curriculum and pay for travel from our rural Colorado home all the way to Germany. 
Why We Need Your Help
We live in a very small, rural community in Southwest Colorado. While the people are genuine and kind, many are less than open minded. The debate on the reality of climate change is a big deal and getting the funding we need from the type of community we live in is not feasible. Being two highschoolers with an unconventional idea and passionate pursuit, our chances become even more slim. We can only ask so many friends and families for a donation, and that won't fly us to Germany to try to change the world. So we are reaching out to try to make our dream a reality. With your help, we can present our idea and try to bring our world back from what seems like an inevitable meltdown.
