story:
Dans le cadre de notre parcours universitaire, un groupe de quinze étudiants en urbanisme de l’Université du Québec à Montréal réalisera, en avril prochain, un stage à l’étranger dans les villes de Copenhague, au Danemark et de Malmö, en Suède. Ce stage offrira la possibilité de participer à la préparation scientifique, à l’organisation logistique ainsi qu’à la réalisation d’un projet de recherche urbain hors Québec. 

Cette courte immersion aidera certainement à alimenter notre parcours universitaire et à diversifier les méthodes d'apprentissage qui permettront d'avoir un regard urbain davantage nuancé.

Les différentes activités préparatoires et le voyage d’études nous donneront l’opportunité d’aiguiser notre sens critique par rapport aux différentes problématiques urbaines, de comparer l’évolution montréalaise à celle d’autres grandes villes, en plus de s'inspirer des pratiques urbanistiques novatrices des villes scandinaves.  

Afin d’assurer le développement et la réalisation de notre projet, nous devrons faire face à des dépenses qui ne pourront être couvertes en totalité par les cotisations des membres, ainsi que par les différentes activités de financement. Toutes contributions seront grandement appréciées et nous aiderons de manière inestimable dans nos démarches. 

En vous remerciant sincèrement de votre geste, 

Les étudiants en urbanisme du cours Les Grandes Villes (EUT 4051 et EUT4052) vous font l’expression de leurs plus respectueuses salutations et vous remercient de votre générosité.
story_txt: Dans le cadre de notre parcours universitaire, un groupe de quinze étudiants en urbanisme de l’Université du Québec à Montréal réalisera, en avril prochain, un stage à l’étranger dans les villes de Copenhague, au Danemark et de Malmö, en Suède. Ce stage offrira la possibilité de participer à la préparation scientifique, à l’organisation logistique ainsi qu’à la réalisation d’un projet de recherche urbain hors Québec. Cette courte immersion aidera certainement à alimenter notre parcours universitaire et à diversifier les méthodes d'apprentissage qui permettront d'avoir un regard urbain davantage nuancé.Les différentes activités préparatoires et le voyage d’études nous donneront l’opportunité d’aiguiser notre sens critique par rapport aux différentes problématiques urbaines, de comparer l’évolution montréalaise à celle d’autres grandes villes, en plus de s'inspirer des pratiques urbanistiques novatrices des villes scandinaves.  Afin d’assurer le développement et la réalisation de notre projet, nous devrons faire face à des dépenses qui ne pourront être couvertes en totalité par les cotisations des membres, ainsi que par les différentes activités de financement. Toutes contributions seront grandement appréciées et nous aiderons de manière inestimable dans nos démarches. En vous remerciant sincèrement de votre geste, Les étudiants en urbanisme du cours Les Grandes Villes (EUT 4051 et EUT4052) vous font l’expression de leurs plus respectueuses salutations et vous remercient de votre générosité.

story:
We need your help to open a cafe and keep fighting against plastic

Who we are and our vision

For those of you who don’t know us yet, we are Mango Tree EcoHostel, located in Negros Island, in the Philippines. The faces behind this project are Julia, Lhouwie, Pilar and Toni.

We are a group of like-minded dedicated young individuals. For us, nature is an essential part of our life and we want to protect it. Most of the people love to travel, to see beautiful places, meet new people, try new food, and experience different cultures that they have not seen yet. That’s why we started Mango Tree EcoHostel: our main aim is to protect our environment and show the world the local Philipino communities around us.

Our vision is to build a place where travellers and locals can meet and learn from each other; a place we can call home, a hostel that is not only a place for sleeping and resting but a centre of cultural exchange that focuses on environmental awareness and protection.

Our trajectory so far

One year ago, all our team met again in the Philippines with the goal of making this vision possible. At that time, we only had this dream in our hearts and each other’s backs. We were innocent and inexperienced in a foreign tropical island, we had nothing - not even a place where we could build our ECOHOSTEL! But during this year, many things happened and we have come so far!

 We can proudly count on these important achievements:

  • We have organized learning sessions in two different local schools on the island, raising awareness about the importance of reducing the consumption of plastic, proper waste management, and recycling.
     
  •  We have shown to more than 1000 people (friends, neighbours, workawayers, school students, etc) how to make eco-bricks for building and upcycling purposes.
     
  • We have recycled by building with eco-bricks for our hostel around 1000 kilograms of soft plastic: it means around 1500 eco-bricks! We built our toilet walls out of eco-bricks and clay. We have loads of upcycled plastic as well to produce pillows, chairs, tables, curtains and more.

  • We have organized and participated in several beach, land and ocean clean-ups with locals and backpackers. In this way, we have been continuing our fight against trash undersea.
     
  • Before the pandemic, we were carrying out a workaway program where volunteers from all over the world could come to help us with our initiatives. We were able to create a cultural exchange between our workawayers and our local friends. It became a little community: we lived, cooked, and celebrated together- and we made our first steps at the construction site – which was really hard work!
     
  • We have already built 80% of the buildings to complete the hostel. We were able to hire an average of 10 local bamboo construction workers for around 8 months. This way, we are preserving the knowledge of traditional construction with bamboo. Knowledge that was being forgotten in the area due to the cement industry becoming the main type of construction in the last decades.
     
  • A German camera team from BluePrintMedia Production visited us in the Philippines to record our exciting journey for a documentary.

The pandemic hasn’t made it easier for us: over a few months, we had to freeze construction, and the feeling of uncertainty around travelling has been like a bad joke for our dreams.

Our plan B: Open a little local cafe

Our initial plan was to open by summer, offering accommodation and breakfast to our first guests, and slowly starting with the next improvements while the hostel was running. But, as you know, the tourism industry – on which countries like the Philippines are heavily dependent – has been one of the most jeopardised by the global pandemic. The world shut down its borders and so sadly we are not able to open our hostel yet.

So now with our accommodation facilities ready to be used, we had to be creative and think about a PLAN B…

While all of you still have to be at home and may not be able to come here and visit the Philippines, we had an idea: we want to open a little Mango Tree EcoCafe.

We want to offer hot and cold drinks, little snacks, smoothie bowls and pastries - all eco-friendly of course!

On our island, local tourism is actually happening, so we can focus on this sector for now. With our café, we are creating a platform where we can still communicate the mission of Mango Tree EcoHostel. The furniture will be all upcycled, and we will have zero-waste workshops, cleanups, and the like. Additional to that, bamboo buildings also need maintaining, we can still provide jobs for locals in need and Mango Tree EcoHostel has a chance to survive. As soon as it’s possible to travel again we want to finally open our hostel so that everyone can visit and experience this beautiful island – and help us save the environment.

Supporting our project at this point will help us to keep on spreading our vision. Like this, you can still be a part of Mango Tree Eco-Hostel and once the borders are open we hope you can visit us and help us in person!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to support us economically, there are many other ways you could help: just living an eco-friendly lifestyle and being able to influence people around you is the best way! You can also follow us in social media, and tell other friends about us so that our vision can be shared as much as possible!

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Link zum deutschen Video:   https://youtu.be/Pj0VTuvMGmQ

 

Wir brauchen deine Hilfe!
Wir wollen ein kleines Cafe eröffnen, um unseren Kampf gegen Single-Used Plastik fortführen zu können.

Wer sind wir uns was ist unsere Vision?

Falls du uns noch nicht kennst, wir sind Mango Tree EcoHostel, zu finden auf der Insel Negros auf den Philippinen. Die Gesichter hinter unserem Projekt sind Julia, Lhouwie, Pilar und Toni.

Wir sind ein bunt zusammen gemixter Haufen und wir alle teilen die Leidenschaft für den Umweltschutz und das Meer.

Reisen, neue Orte entdecken, neue Leute kennen lernen, neue Köstlichkeiten ausprobieren und andere Kulturen erkunden...das ist die Leidenschaft von ganz ganz Vielen! Genau deswegen haben wir Mango Tree EcoHostel gegründet.

Unsere große Leidenschaft ist der Umweltschutz! Gleichzeitig möchten wir der Welt ein bisschen was von der philippinischen Kultur zu zeigen, die wir alle lieben.

Unsere Vision ist es, einen Ort zu erschaffen, wo Reisende und Einheimische zusammentreffen und voneinander lernen können.

Einen Ort, den wir alle „Zuhause“ nennen können. Ein Hostel, das nicht nur ein Ort zum Schlafen ist, sondern vor allem ein Ort für kulturellen Austausch mit dem Fokus auf Umweltschutzprojekte.

Was wir bisher erreicht haben

Vor einem Jahr hat sich das Mango Tree EcoHostel Team auf den Philippinen wiedergetroffen - mit dem Ziel unsere Visionen in die Tat umzusetzen.

Zu diesem Zeitpunkt hatten wir den festen Glauben an unseren Traum und aneinander - sonst aber noch nicht so viel.

Wir waren ziemlich unerfahren, noch dazu in einem anderen Land und hatten eigentlich nichts - nicht einmal ein Land, auf dem wir unser Ecohostel bauen konnten.

Aber seitdem ist viel passiert und wir sind wirklich weit gekommen.

Wir sind echt glücklich und stolz auf das, was wir bisher erreicht haben:

  • Wir haben Programme in zwei verschiedenen Schulen auf unserer Insel ins Leben gerufen. So konnten wir das Bewusstsein der Schüler für die Reduzierung ihres Plastikkonsums, richtige Müllentsorgung und Recycling stärken.
     
  • Wir haben mehr als 1000 Leuten (Freunden, Nachbarn, Workawayers, Schülern, etc.) gezeigt, wie man Ecobricks macht, um später damit zu bauen und Möbel daraus herzustellen.
     
  • Wir haben einige Wände in unserem Hostel aus Ecobricks und Lehm gebaut. Außerdem haben wir das gesammelte Plastik verwendet, um Kissen, Stühle, Tische und Vorhänge herzustellen. So haben wir es geschafft, ungefähr 1000 Kilo Plastik zu recyceln. Das entspricht ungefähr 1500 Ecobricks!

  • Wir haben, gemeinsam mit Einheimische und Backpackern, einige Strand-, Land- und Unterwasser-Aufräumaktionen organisiert oder selbst als Teilnehmer mitgemacht.
     
  • Vor dem Start der weltweiten Pandemie, hatten wir ein Workaway- Programm ins Leben gerufen. Freiwillige aus der ganzen Welt hatten so die Möglichkeit zu uns zu kommen und uns mit unserem Projekt zu helfen. Zusammen mit unseren einheimischen Freunden wurden wir zu einer kleinen Gemeinschaft und es gab einen richtigen kulturellen Austausch.
     
  • Gemeinsam mit unserne einhemischen Arbeitern, haben wir es geschafft, unsere Gebäude zu mehr als 80 % fertig zu bauen. Im Durchschnitt hatten wir 10 einheimische Zimmermänner für über 8 Monate angestellt. So konnten wir auch die Erhaltung der traditionellen Bauweise mit Bambus, hier auf den Philippinen, unterstützen. Denn leider gerät diese traditionelle und nachhaltige Bauweise immer mehr in den Hintergrund, da das Bauen mit Zement immer beliebter wird.
     
  • Ein deutsches Kamerateam von BluePrintMedia Production hat uns auf den Philippinen besucht, um eine Dokumention über unsere spannende Reise zu drehen.

Die Corona Pandemie hat es uns leider nicht wirklich einfach gemacht: Für ein paar Monate mussten wir die Baustelle schließen und die Unsicherheit hinsichtlich der Tourismusbranche war ein echter Rückschlag auf dem Weg, unseren Traum zu erfüllen.

Unser Plan B: Die Eröffnung eines kleinen Cafes

Ursprünglich wollten wir unser Hostel im Sommer 2020 eröffnen und bereits Übernachtungsmöglichkeiten und Frühstück für unsere ersten Gäste anbieten, um das Hostel dann langsam step by step noch weiter zu verbessern.

Aber, wie du weißt, ist die Tourismusbranche eine der Branchen, die sehr stark von der Krise betroffen sind.

Das hat für uns dann einfach bedeutet, wir müssen uns einen PLAN B überlegen...

Während du und alle anderen internationalen Reisenden uns, aufgrund der aktuellen Situation, leider noch nicht auf den Philippinen besuchen können, hatten wir eine Idee: Wir wollen ein kleines MangoTree EcoCafe eröffnen.

Mit dem Cafe wollen wir vor allem die Einheimischen erreichen, denn lokaler Tourismus findet auf unserer Insel mittlerweile wieder statt.

Wir möchten Getränke, kleine Snacks, Smoothie Bowls und andere Leckereien anbieten - natürlich alles so ökologisch wie möglich.

Mit unserem Cafe können wir außerdem eine Plattform erschaffen, wie wir weiterhin unsere Vision verbreiten können. Wir werden Zero-Waste Kurse, Cleanups und Ähnliches über das Cafe organisieren. Außerdem werden wir die Möbel des Cafes aus recycelten Materialien herstellen.

Zusätzlich müssen unsere Gebäude, die zu 90 % aus Bambus bestehen, auch in Stand gehalten werden und wir möchten den Einheimischen weiterhin Jobs zur Verfügung stellen. Durch die Eröffung eines Cafes hat MangoTree EcoHostel eine Chance zu überleben! Und sobald es wieder möglich sein wird zu reisen, möchten wir unser Hostel wirklich komplett eröffnen, damit alle Reisenden unsere schöne Insel hautnah erleben können - und uns bei unseren Umweltschutzprojekten helfen können.

Wenn du unser Projekt zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt unterstützt, hilfst du uns dabei, unsere Vision weiter zu verbreiten! Und sobald die Grenzen wieder offen sind, kannst du uns hoffentlich besuchen!

 

Wie du uns sonst noch helfen kannst.

Falls du es dir nicht leisten kannst, uns auf ökonomischem Weg zu unterstützen, gibt es noch ganz viele andere Wege, wie du uns helfen kannst: bewusst und umweltfreundlich zu leben und andere Leute in deinem Umkreis auch für diese Lebensweise zu begeistern, ist der beste Weg!

Du kannst uns auch auf Social Media verfolgen und deinen Freunden von uns erzählen, sodass unsere Vision so weit wie möglich verbreitet werden kann.

Vielen, Vielen Dank für deine Unterstützung!!!

 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Link al vídeo con subtítulos en Español:  https://youtu.be/iNmt6i9HqBQ

 

Necesitamos tu ayuda para poder abrir una cafetería y así poder continuar con nuestra lucha en contra del plástico en la naturaleza

Quiénes somos y cuál es nuestra visión

Para aquellos que aún no nos conocen: somos Mango Tree EcoHostel, situados en la isla de Negros, en las Filipinas. Nuestro equipo está conformado por Julia, Lhouwie, Pilar y Toni.

Somos un grupo de jóvenes con intereses comunes y una pasión. Para nosotros, la naturaleza es clave en nuestra vida y consideramos muy importante el protegerla. A la mayoría de las personas les encanta viajar, ver lugares bonitos, conocer a gente nueva, probar platos exóticos, y sumergirse en culturas hasta el momento desconocidas para ellos. Esta es una de las razones por las que este proyecto nació: nuestro objetivo principal es proteger el medio ambiente y mostrar al mundo las comunidades filipinas que tenemos a nuestro alrededor.

Nuestro sueño es construir un lugar en donde producir encuentros culturales entre viajeros y locales; un lugar al que llamar hogar, un hostal que no sea sólo para dormir y descansar, sino un centro de intercambio cultural centrado en conciencia medioambiental y protección.

Qué hemos logrado hasta el momento

Hace ya algo más de un año que volvimos a las Filipinas para comenzar nuestro proyecto. Llegamos, y ¡no teníamos nada! Sólo los unos a los otros, y nuestro sueño en nuestros corazones. Durante todo este año, han ido ocurriendo muchas cosas y hemos logrado conseguir muchas metas:

  • Hemos organizado sesiones educativas en dos colegios de educación secundaria en la isla, haciendo hincapié en la importancia de reducir el consumo de plástico, de cómo gestionar estos residuos, y reciclarlos.      
     
  • Hemos logrado que más de 1000 personas (amigos, vecinos, workawayers, alumnos, etc) hagan ecobricks con nosotros, utilizando éstos para construir y para otros proyectos de reciclaje. 
     
  • Hemos reciclado unos 1000 kilos de plástico de un solo uso, convirtiéndolo en 1500 eco-bricks. Con estos eco-bricks hemos construido el primer edificio de baños en nuestro hostal, aún queda otro por construir y tenemos en plan contruir muebles y más con estos eco-ladrillos.

  • Hemos organizado y participado en recogidas de basura en la playa, océano y en la naturaleza. No hemos dejado de luchar en contra del plástico de un solo uso ni por un solo día.
     
  • Antes de que la pandemia se originase, estuvimos llevando a cabo un programa de intercambio cultural donde voluntarios de todo el mundo se vinieron a las Filipinas a ayudarnos a desarrollar nuestras ideas, aportándonos asimismo las suyas. Nuestra casa se convirtió en una pequeña comunidad con sabor internacional donde aprender sobre la cultura filipina.
     
  • Hemos completado a fecha de hoy un 80% de las construcciones previstas para el hostal.  Con estos edificios podríamos empezar con nuestro hostal si hubiese turismo. Podemos estar orgullosas de haber contratado a una media de 10 carpinteros de bambú durante unos 8 meses aproximadamente.  De este modo, hemos colaborado en la transmisión del conocimiento sobre construcción en bambú, actualmente en vía de desuso debido a la globalización de construcciones con cemento.
     
  • Un equipo de producción televisiva ha estado en las Filipinas grabando un pequeño documental sobre nuestro proyecto que saldrá el año que viene.

La pandemia no nos lo ha puesto nada fácil: durante unos meses hemos tenido que cerrar nuestra construcción. El sentimiento de incertidumbre sobre qué va a ocurrir con el turismo está siendo una broma pesada para nuestros sueños.

Nuestro plan B: abrir una pequeña cafetería

Nuestro plan inicial era inaugurar nuestro hostal para el verano con lo básico, y poco a poco ir mejorando nuestro espacio. Pero, como bien sabéis, el sector turístico –en el cual países como las Filipinas dependen en gran medida- ha sido uno de los más afectados por la pandemia global. El mundo entero cierra sus fronteras, y por ello desgraciadamente no podemos abrir nuestro hostal.

Con nuestros edificios prácticamente listos para su funcionamiento, hemos tenido que ser creativas y pensar en un PLAN B…

Mientras la mayoría de vosotros tiene que permanecer en casa y les resulta imposible visitar las Filipinas y nuestro hostal, hemos tenido la idea de abrir una pequeña Mango Tree Eco Cafetería.

Queremos ofrecer bebidas frías y calientes, snacks, smoothie bowls y pasteles – todo ecológico y orgánico, ¡por supuesto!

En la isla en la que nos encontramos, el turismo local está teniendo lugar, lo que nos permite centrarnos en este sector por el momento. Con nuestra cafetería, el plan es poder seguir comunicando la visión de Mango Tree EcoHostel. Los muebles van a ser todos reciclados, y tendremos workshops sobre sostenibilidad en todas sus facetas, además continuaremos limpiando playas, el océano y la naturaleza de plástico. Además, al estar funcionando podremos mantener nuestros edificios de bambú cuidados, lo cual es esencial para que duren, podremos contratar a locales y Mango Tree EcoHostel tiene la oportunidad de continuar operando.

Al apoyar nuestro proyecto nos estarás ayudando a expandir nuestra visión. ¡Así tú también puedes ser parte de Mango Tree EcoHostel y una vez que las fronteras estén abiertas esperamos que puedas venir y cooperar en persona!

Otras formas de ayudarnos

Si no te puedes permitir el apoyarnos económicamente, hay muchas otras formas en las que puedes echarnos una mano: la mejor de las ayudas sería llevar a cabo un estilo de vida sostenible y conseguir influenciar a las personas a tu alrededor. ¡También puedes seguirnos en redes sociales, contarle a tus amigos y allegados sobre nosotros, o compartir esta campaña para que tenga el máximo de difusión posible!

¡MUCHAS GRACIAS POR TU APOYO!

Denn leider gerät diese traditionelle und nachhaltige Bauweise immer mehr in den Hintergrund, da das Bauen mit Zement immer beliebter wird. 
Ein deutsches Kamerateam von BluePrintMedia Production hat uns auf den Philippinen besucht, um eine Dokumention über unsere spannende Reise zu drehen.
Die Corona Pandemie hat es uns leider nicht wirklich einfach gemacht: Für ein paar Monate mussten wir die Baustelle schließen und die Unsicherheit hinsichtlich der Tourismusbranche war ein echter Rückschlag auf dem Weg, unseren Traum zu erfüllen.Unser Plan B: Die Eröffnung eines kleinen CafesUrsprünglich wollten wir unser Hostel im Sommer 2020 eröffnen und bereits Übernachtungsmöglichkeiten und Frühstück für unsere ersten Gäste anbieten, um das Hostel dann langsam step by step noch weiter zu verbessern.Aber, wie du weißt, ist die Tourismusbranche eine der Branchen, die sehr stark von der Krise betroffen sind.Das hat für uns dann einfach bedeutet, wir müssen uns einen PLAN B überlegen...Während du und alle anderen internationalen Reisenden uns, aufgrund der aktuellen Situation, leider noch nicht auf den Philippinen besuchen können, hatten wir eine Idee: Wir wollen ein kleines MangoTree EcoCafe eröffnen.Mit dem Cafe wollen wir vor allem die Einheimischen erreichen, denn lokaler Tourismus findet auf unserer Insel mittlerweile wieder statt.Wir möchten Getränke, kleine Snacks, Smoothie Bowls und andere Leckereien anbieten - natürlich alles so ökologisch wie möglich.Mit unserem Cafe können wir außerdem eine Plattform erschaffen, wie wir weiterhin unsere Vision verbreiten können. Wir werden Zero-Waste Kurse, Cleanups und Ähnliches über das Cafe organisieren. Außerdem werden wir die Möbel des Cafes aus recycelten Materialien herstellen.Zusätzlich müssen unsere Gebäude, die zu 90 % aus Bambus bestehen, auch in Stand gehalten werden und wir möchten den Einheimischen weiterhin Jobs zur Verfügung stellen. Durch die Eröffung eines Cafes hat MangoTree EcoHostel eine Chance zu überleben! Und sobald es wieder möglich sein wird zu reisen, möchten wir unser Hostel wirklich komplett eröffnen, damit alle Reisenden unsere schöne Insel hautnah erleben können - und uns bei unseren Umweltschutzprojekten helfen können.Wenn du unser Projekt zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt unterstützt, hilfst du uns dabei, unsere Vision weiter zu verbreiten! Und sobald die Grenzen wieder offen sind, kannst du uns hoffentlich besuchen! Wie du uns sonst noch helfen kannst.Falls du es dir nicht leisten kannst, uns auf ökonomischem Weg zu unterstützen, gibt es noch ganz viele andere Wege, wie du uns helfen kannst: bewusst und umweltfreundlich zu leben und andere Leute in deinem Umkreis auch für diese Lebensweise zu begeistern, ist der beste Weg!Du kannst uns auch auf Social Media verfolgen und deinen Freunden von uns erzählen, sodass unsere Vision so weit wie möglich verbreitet werden kann.Vielen, Vielen Dank für deine Unterstützung!!! -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Link al vídeo con subtítulos en Español:  https://youtu.be/iNmt6i9HqBQ Necesitamos tu ayuda para poder abrir una cafetería y así poder continuar con nuestra lucha en contra del plástico en la naturalezaQuiénes somos y cuál es nuestra visiónPara aquellos que aún no nos conocen: somos Mango Tree EcoHostel, situados en la isla de Negros, en las Filipinas. Nuestro equipo está conformado por Julia, Lhouwie, Pilar y Toni.Somos un grupo de jóvenes con intereses comunes y una pasión. Para nosotros, la naturaleza es clave en nuestra vida y consideramos muy importante el protegerla. A la mayoría de las personas les encanta viajar, ver lugares bonitos, conocer a gente nueva, probar platos exóticos, y sumergirse en culturas hasta el momento desconocidas para ellos. Esta es una de las razones por las que este proyecto nació: nuestro objetivo principal es proteger el medio ambiente y mostrar al mundo las comunidades filipinas que tenemos a nuestro alrededor.Nuestro sueño es construir un lugar en donde producir encuentros culturales entre viajeros y locales; un lugar al que llamar hogar, un hostal que no sea sólo para dormir y descansar, sino un centro de intercambio cultural centrado en conciencia medioambiental y protección.Qué hemos logrado hasta el momentoHace ya algo más de un año que volvimos a las Filipinas para comenzar nuestro proyecto. Llegamos, y ¡no teníamos nada! Sólo los unos a los otros, y nuestro sueño en nuestros corazones. Durante todo este año, han ido ocurriendo muchas cosas y hemos logrado conseguir muchas metas:
Hemos organizado sesiones educativas en dos colegios de educación secundaria en la isla, haciendo hincapié en la importancia de reducir el consumo de plástico, de cómo gestionar estos residuos, y reciclarlos.       
Hemos logrado que más de 1000 personas (amigos, vecinos, workawayers, alumnos, etc) hagan ecobricks con nosotros, utilizando éstos para construir y para otros proyectos de reciclaje.  
Hemos reciclado unos 1000 kilos de plástico de un solo uso, convirtiéndolo en 1500 eco-bricks. Con estos eco-bricks hemos construido el primer edificio de baños en nuestro hostal, aún queda otro por construir y tenemos en plan contruir muebles y más con estos eco-ladrillos.

Hemos organizado y participado en recogidas de basura en la playa, océano y en la naturaleza. No hemos dejado de luchar en contra del plástico de un solo uso ni por un solo día. 
Antes de que la pandemia se originase, estuvimos llevando a cabo un programa de intercambio cultural donde voluntarios de todo el mundo se vinieron a las Filipinas a ayudarnos a desarrollar nuestras ideas, aportándonos asimismo las suyas. Nuestra casa se convirtió en una pequeña comunidad con sabor internacional donde aprender sobre la cultura filipina. 

Hemos completado a fecha de hoy un 80% de las construcciones previstas para el hostal.  Con estos edificios podríamos empezar con nuestro hostal si hubiese turismo. Podemos estar orgullosas de haber contratado a una media de 10 carpinteros de bambú durante unos 8 meses aproximadamente.  De este modo, hemos colaborado en la transmisión del conocimiento sobre construcción en bambú, actualmente en vía de desuso debido a la globalización de construcciones con cemento. 
Un equipo de producción televisiva ha estado en las Filipinas grabando un pequeño documental sobre nuestro proyecto que saldrá el año que viene.
La pandemia no nos lo ha puesto nada fácil: durante unos meses hemos tenido que cerrar nuestra construcción. El sentimiento de incertidumbre sobre qué va a ocurrir con el turismo está siendo una broma pesada para nuestros sueños.Nuestro plan B: abrir una pequeña cafetería Nuestro plan inicial era inaugurar nuestro hostal para el verano con lo básico, y poco a poco ir mejorando nuestro espacio. Pero, como bien sabéis, el sector turístico –en el cual países como las Filipinas dependen en gran medida- ha sido uno de los más afectados por la pandemia global. El mundo entero cierra sus fronteras, y por ello desgraciadamente no podemos abrir nuestro hostal.Con nuestros edificios prácticamente listos para su funcionamiento, hemos tenido que ser creativas y pensar en un PLAN B…Mientras la mayoría de vosotros tiene que permanecer en casa y les resulta imposible visitar las Filipinas y nuestro hostal, hemos tenido la idea de abrir una pequeña Mango Tree Eco Cafetería.Queremos ofrecer bebidas frías y calientes, snacks, smoothie bowls y pasteles – todo ecológico y orgánico, ¡por supuesto!En la isla en la que nos encontramos, el turismo local está teniendo lugar, lo que nos permite centrarnos en este sector por el momento. Con nuestra cafetería, el plan es poder seguir comunicando la visión de Mango Tree EcoHostel. Los muebles van a ser todos reciclados, y tendremos workshops sobre sostenibilidad en todas sus facetas, además continuaremos limpiando playas, el océano y la naturaleza de plástico. Además, al estar funcionando podremos mantener nuestros edificios de bambú cuidados, lo cual es esencial para que duren, podremos contratar a locales y Mango Tree EcoHostel tiene la oportunidad de continuar operando.Al apoyar nuestro proyecto nos estarás ayudando a expandir nuestra visión. ¡Así tú también puedes ser parte de Mango Tree EcoHostel y una vez que las fronteras estén abiertas esperamos que puedas venir y cooperar en persona!Otras formas de ayudarnosSi no te puedes permitir el apoyarnos económicamente, hay muchas otras formas en las que puedes echarnos una mano: la mejor de las ayudas sería llevar a cabo un estilo de vida sostenible y conseguir influenciar a las personas a tu alrededor. ¡También puedes seguirnos en redes sociales, contarle a tus amigos y allegados sobre nosotros, o compartir esta campaña para que tenga el máximo de difusión posible!¡MUCHAS GRACIAS POR TU APOYO!

story:
A Message from James M. Taylor, Vice President of External Relations

One of the most important battles in the history of the global warming debate will be fought this December at a United Nations climate conference in Paris. The UN is attempting to impose binding carbon dioxide restrictions on the United States and transfer billions of dollars of climate "reparations" from the United States to nations like Iran, North Korea, and Venezuela.

It’s called COP-21 – the twenty-first meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Heartland Institute is working with other leading think tanks and advocacy groups to make sure our voice – the voice of sound science and economics, of energy consumers and taxpayers in America – is heard.

We need your help us stop the UN and the Obama administration from raising your taxes, increasing your energy costs, and destroying jobs – perhaps your job or those of your children. This short proposal describes our project and asks for your financial support.

What’s at Stake in Paris

If the United States agrees to binding restrictions on our carbon dioxide emissions and payment of reparations to corrupt third-world regimes, the economic consequences will be devastating. Your taxes and energy costs will go up dramatically – by thousands of dollars every year. Job losses will be measured in the millions, and many of those are good-paying jobs in manufacturing that the country, still struggling to emerge from the Great Recession, can ill-afford to lose.

President Barack Obama is leading the charge in this assault on the American economy. Obama told the press last month that the key to any Paris agreement is to ensure the United States is "locked in" to binding restrictions. Obama has made it clear that he sees binding, UN-enforced restrictions on U.S. carbon dioxide emissions as a legacy achievement for the conclusion of his presidency.

Obama is tacitly admitting that if he fails to commit the United States to legally binding restrictions in Paris, the global warming movement will have failed once again to achieve its top objective: a globally binding global warming treaty to replace the now-expired Kyoto Protocol. Whoever succeeds Obama is likely to undo much of the policy and regulations he implemented via executive authority. That is why COP-21 is so important, and why we need to be there.

COP-21 will be raucous, even pandemonious. Developing countries are refusing to embrace caps on their exploding greenhouse gas emissions and insisting developed countries give them $100 billion a year with few or no strings attached. International aid groups are fighting to prevent the diversion of aid from more urgent needs to emission reduction schemes that would have little impact on climate. Real science and economics are being kicked to the curb.

What We Plan to Do in Paris

We plan to send a delegation of scientists and policy experts to Paris to hold a "counter-conference" during COP-21 to demonstrate there is strong and informed opposition to Obama’s plans and to expose the agendas and true costs of the agreement being negotiated there.

We have reserved meeting space and rooms at a hotel in Paris where we will hold a series of media events with scientific experts explaining the compelling evidence that humans are not causing a global warming crisis. We will make our space available to allies being sent by other organizations, such as the Cato Institute, Committee for a Constructive Tomorrow, and Competitive Enterprise Institute. We will live-stream presentations from our meeting space so the whole world will know we are there, even if the mainstream media boycott us.

We expect it will cost approximately $60,000 to send a delegation to Paris and extensively promote our presence there. Our expected costs are:

$24,000 Promotion announcing our presence in Paris
$10,000 Hotel rooms
$10,000 Meeting space
$ 9,000 Airfare
$ 4,500 Ground expenses (meals, transportation)
$ 2,000 Printing and shipping media handouts and publications
----------
$ 59,500 Total

We Need Your Support!

Going to Paris and making sure our message is heard by world leaders and the global press is not inexpensive, as the budget on the previous page shows. We need your financial support to make this project possible.

Multiple donors are being asked to fund this project. Your gift for part of the total we need to raise would be greatly appreciated, and we will give you frequent updates and a final "wrap-up memo" on the success (or failure... we admit to failure sometimes) of the project.

Contributions are tax-deductible under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The Heartland Institute has more than 6,000 current donors supporting an annual budget of approximately $6 million. Less than 10% of our budget comes from corporations. For more information, please contact James Taylor, vice president for external relations, at 312/377-4000 or by email at  jtaylor@heartland.org.

story:
As you can see from the picture above, we are already aboard our private space craft. We collected enough Pepsi points in the 90's to get them to give us one, haven't had a use for it till now.

We figure we would travel to the red planet and really understand the local life (which obviously exist now). And to do that we need your support. For every $50 raised, we will take a new picture of us LIVE on the shuttle, and send you a story about the journey to Mars.

*this is fictional and we are not really travelling to Mars, we just would like some booze money.

story:
Being part of this inaugural electric race on US soil is incredibly exciting, and feels like being part of the future while making history at the same time. The technologies are rapidly evolving and being part of the pioneering into electric propulsion territories is nothing short of awesome!

The Mavizen TTX02 is a state of the art machine, built in EEngland based on an RC8 KTM chassis, and it will be the only Mavizen on the grid at the Infineon race on May 14-16, 2010 for the first round of the TTXGP at Infineon Raceway!

The Werkstatt Race Team will put Jennifer Bromme on the grid on this first ever zero-carbon motorcycle race series! The objective is to show that electric motorcycles are viable, fun, and the future!

But we need your help: We need to raise about $10k or more (the batteries alone are $15k) for the season so we can commit to the complete race series, which will take place in 4 venues in North America. If we place in the top 8 we will get to race internationally, battling teams from the UK and Italy in the grand finale in Spain!

Thanks to all that have contributed in our previous fundraiser! The motorcycle is now here and we are prepping it as I write this but this is only the beginning of our historical journey. We continue to ask for your support. Every contribution, no matter how small, will help us reach our goal of competing in the grand finale in Spain later this year. It’s simple to get involved and together we will make history!

For more information and paypal please go http://www.werkstattsf.com/blog-section/index.html.

We will be updating this site regularly to keep you informed!

story:
Help fund and save

One of the most beautiful and precious places on the Planet Earth.

A community-based conservation program to protect critically endangered lemurs in

Kianjavato Classified Forest, Madagascar

The Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership (MBP) is a Malagasy NGO that conducts its conservation efforts in Madagascar to study, research, foster and protect the ecology of the land and its remaining forests.  

More than 90% or Madagascar's forests have been lost in the last century,  which poses a serious threat to the unique biodiversity remaining.  

Lemurs, which can only be found in Madagascar, were recently declared the most threatened mammals in the world. Of the 103 known lemur species, more than 72% are recognized as Critically Endangered or Endangered.

MBP's international team of researchers, educators, engineers and scientists are committed to the challenge of preserving the existing forest and expand them through grassroots tree-planting activities. Critical to MBP's effort is to involve the local community in participating in the restoration and monitoring effort.  Long term protection of Madagascar's forests and wildlife, including endangered lemurs, is only possibile with local participation and commitment.  

http://www.madagascarpartnership.org/home/volunteer_program2

  MBP's project has a goal of planting 1,000,000 trees into the fragmented forest landscape with the assistance of Kianjavato's residents. This effort is part of the "Forest Corridors as Entrepreneurial Opportunities for Madagascar" initiative that combines reforestation with sustainable agroforestry practices. Protecting the local ecosystem requires more than just reforestation, it requires a holistic approach that supports the community and reduces its exploitation of the forest.

  Although the MBP is still a relatively young organization, it has made significant progress towards this end:

  • Promotion of environmental preservation - In the first half of 2012, more than 30,374 trees have been planted into the fragmented landscape. Satellite nurseries throughout the Kianjavato commune, which are managed by area residents that were trained by the MBP, are housing tens of thousands more native tree seedlings in preparation for the next rainy season, a key planting period.
  • Engagement of the local community - Over the recent months, it has become clear that word had gotten out about this reforestation program. Not only is local participation and enthusiasm building, but interest is growing from communities outside Kianjavato. Increasingly these residents make the several kilometer-trek on foot to the research station looking for work as day laborers. Working with MBP is now seen as a more reliable source of income than the job of gold mining, which poses health consequences, is environmentally destructive, and infrequently profitable.
  • Empowerment through education and community development - Reached hundreds of school children, teachers, officials, and residents through a community program between MBP and Conservation Fusion, an international conservation-focused educational organization 

You can help change attitudes and make change happen with just a small donation.  It's easy to affect change - Even a small donation executed thousands of times over by individual compassionate people like you, demonstrates just how.

Hello, My name is Kyle.

  I discovered MBP whilst researching challenging and rewarding employment opportunities and carreer paths for college and university graduates of biology and related disciplines.  My son and daughter namely.   While I was looking for employment/opps abroad for my daughter, I discovered the MBP online.  In addition to hopefully sponsoring my daughter, I wanted to help out with a donation.

  The MBP Volunteer program offers participants an opportunity to budding-scientists to gain knowledge in endangered species protection.  Volunteers and students will be on-the-ground performing real and meaningful field work in-situ in Kianjavato, Madagascar.  Activities involve helping to monitor lemurs in the remaining forest fragments, assisting with the community-wide reforestation effort, working with Malagasy staff to develop research skills, and develop language skills. Participants commit to a 3-6 month minimum stay, during which MBP provides basic accommodations, food, and transportation to/from the MBP research station.   Funding for the filling of these spaces is typically provided by the volunteer themselves, or by a sponsor.  A detailed accounting of the projects work and activity progress can be read/seen a little further below.

  However, the project must also receive funding to carry out its mission of conservation, education and sustainable living for communities and thus, it is the aim of my campaign to generate some of this funding.  Currently this funding is provided via private grants and donations from zoos and individuals.  I decided this could be a way for everyone to help out as much as they can afford to.

  The project acquires tools, resources and labor/manpower as the financial opportunities to do so present themselves. Currently through grants and private donations. Funds are typically spent according to the amounts received but it is nothing short of amazing how much is done with so little money.

http://www.madagascarpartnership.org/home

   

All funding contributions received will go to the MBP whether this campaign goal is reached or not.

 Perks:  As MBP is still a developing organization, we are always in a cycle of updates and advancements, thus are perks may be limited. For those who donate and/or contribute to the general project, we will acknowledge them on our website and email project updates to those who sign up.  We are actively developing a system to tie every donation to a specific tree in the ground. Our future goal is to be able to provide each donor with a GPS location that they can take to Google Earth and see where in the world their sponsored tree was planted. We hope to launch a new page on our website that will have a map where people can zoom in and see the location of their tree, the species, date it was planted, and who planted it. This is still under development, but we believe it will be a fantastic tool once available. (If you love our project and want to volunteer - you could help us get this function up and running!)

  Contributors can request and will recieve via email, a breakdown of how funds are allocated and spent via a pair of reports for this year 2012.  They have been provided by the project.  MBP makes very little money go a very long distance.  My goal is to raise $20,000 to help the project fund its activities, with a special emphasis on expanding the reforestation effort and other critical components of the program with the greatest need for aid.

However small your contribution - It still means a lot.  If you can't contribute, at least take a moment and look at the MBP website to see their project. Like MBP on Facebook; follow MBP on Twitter; help spread the word about the work that they are doing. Work like this is more important to your children and even more important to theirs.  We cannot save the world in one fell swoop.  We have to find our one place and start there.  We have to give back. 

Below are excerpts from reports on the project's activities for the first half of 2012.  The reports serve to explain in detail and inform pertinent agencies about the ongoing work and progress of the Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership:

MBP Project Overview

  With few viable alternatives, Madagascar’s population continues to be reliant upon several environmentally harmful activities such as slash and burn farming, mining and hunting, all of which threaten the island’s extraordinary species diversity. Due to a lack of effective protection of two critically endangered lemur species in the surrounding forests of Kianjavato, in southeast Madagascar, Omaha’s Henry Doorly Zoo and Aquarium (OHDZA) and the Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership (MBP) established an extensive research project in the area in 2007. Operating under the premise of finding a sustainable path forward for the lemurs and the 12,000 residents reliant upon the surrounding forest fragments, OHDZA-MBP developed a community-based conservation effort, the “Education Promoting Reforestation Program” (EPRP).

This grassroots reforestation program deployed MBP personnel to track seed-dispersing lemurs through the forest, in this case the Black and white ruffed lemur (Varecia variegata). While monitoring lemurs, fecal samples were collected opportunistically year-round from which local field assistants extracted and sorted seeds, and planted in nurseries.

The resulting seedlings were transplanted as part of a community supported reforestation and restoration program that utilized these native trees to restore habitat and enable movement of lemur populations. Once mature, the transplanted endemic trees will entice lemurs to forage and continue the process of forest restoration themselves, thus requiring less future human intervention. Additionally, the structure of the reforestation plan also included tree species with commercial value, thus providing area residents with an additional source of income over time.

Community awareness and support has increased due to the employment of large numbers of local community members to monitor lemurs, maintenance and preparation of seedlings in the local nurseries, as well as transplantation of trees. Furthermore, the planned distribution of incentive items as part of the conservation credit program, which is scheduled to occur in July 2012, will further strengthen community ties to forest and lemur protection efforts.

MBP Project Update Since the receipt of the grant award from the XXX Foundation, OHDZA-MBP made great strides in advancing towards the goals of the grant.

Promotion of environmental preservation: The OHDZA-MBP reforestation efforts have enhanced the promotion of habitat protection with more than 30,000 trees being planted into the landscape thus far in 2012, thereby establishing the foundation for vital corridors to connect forest fragments. The eight nurseries strategically located near each participating village housed seedlings prior to transplantation. Community representatives from the immediate area run these nurseries and coordinate future community planting days.

In addition, the program has led to the creation of contracts between OHDZA-MBP and each village. These contracts are designed to identify the specific location for each community-designated nursery plot, define the contributions of each partner, and clearly states that the land remains in the hands of the original owners.As the program expands its efforts into the larger community, there has been a growing interest in the reforestation of neighboring territories. In fact, OHDZA-MBP has increasingly been receiving requests from communities outside the Kianjavato area for guidance in the construction of nurseries near their village. Not wanting the community-based reforestation effort momentum to stop at the border of the Kianjavato commune, OHDZA-MBP has been working with representatives from these other communities to set the groundwork for their reforestation initiative.

Engagement of the local community: To date, there are a number of fantastic community partners routinely contributing to the planting efforts. These comprise groups that we originally anticipated would be involved, such as area residents, school children and their teachers, village elders, and local officials. This is in addition to the OHDZ-MBP Malagasy graduate students, local assistants and guides, and visiting researchers who are regularly involved with the program on a more official capacity. However, there is growing interest in participating from additional groups, including a local single women’s club, members of which are single mothers whose involvement with the project allows them to contribute to the community and earn additional income.

These women currently fill the role of weeding the nurseries and making shade structures for newly transplanted seedlings.Over the recent months it has become clear that word has gotten out about this reforestation program. Increasingly, people from communities outside Kianjavato make the several kilometer-trek on foot to the research station looking for work as day laborers. Working with OHDZA-MBP is now seen as a more reliable source of income than the job of gold mining, which poses health consequences, is environmentally destructive, and infrequently profitable.

Due to the participation of many factions within the Kianjavato community, there is a building of local appreciation for the project as well as its potential for aiding residents and the regional wildlife over the foreseeable future. This acceptance, coupled with a thirst for knowledge, is vital for any conservation effort, and we are very fortunate in this regard and must use it to the advantage of the larger conservation program.

  

Empowerment through education and community development: There are a number of new exciting advances regarding other education and community development opportunities. The project currently supports a postdoctoral researcher, who has a Ph.D. in botany and significant experience working with plants in Madagascar, to oversee the Kianjavato research program. Furthermore, in the first quarter of the year we had two international volunteers, with experience in horticulture and project management, spearhead the reforestation program.

These volunteers worked closely with the nursery managers, day laborers and community participants, teaching them new skills and techniques. The reforestation program made some of its greatest advances while these volunteers were onsite, so in order to continue this momentum, we are bringing two other international volunteers onsite in late June to further manage the reforestation effort and transfer lessons to the local community.

To make the most of the project’s growing awareness and community desire for assistance, our partner, Conservation Fusion, is planning a return visit to the communities of Kianjavato. The international NGO will lead another series of education and community development events to strengthen community interest and ability to participate in making a positive impact. Thus far, the advancements in community-relations have been made with minimal presentation of the conservation incentive items such as the rocket stoves and Tough Stuff Kits. However, in July 2012, the OHDZA-MBP is planning a distribution event, where participants in the reforestation program that have earned sufficient conservation credits will be awarded with a Tough Stuff Kit. \

This allocation will coincide with an education and outreach event which will highlight the advantages and ease of use of the Tough Stuff items. Although there is growing interest regarding our reforestation program, we hope that the educational activities and conservation credit program will assist us in gathering more support from the community to make the one million-tree effort feasible.

Grant-specific Update.  With the grant award from the XXX Foundation for $6,000, we amended the original design and quantity of Tough Stuff Kits that would be made available. The funds enabled us to purchase sufficient components to offer 300 Tough Stuff Kits as incentive items, each with a solar panel and battery power pack (see Table 1). In addition, the grant funds made it possible to purchase 150 LED lamps, a highly sought-after option during the initial pilot kit introduction. The solar panels, battery power packs and LED lamps were purchased in February 2012 and are currently being held at the MBP Headquarters in Antananarivo.

The premier conservation credit program award festivity is currently scheduled in July 2012, when the OHDZA-MBP general director will be onsite to coordinate the event. Through the education and outreach event to be led by Conservation Fusion, we will discuss the advantages associated with additional components for the Tough Stuff Kits. The cell phone and radio connectors will be purchased by OHDZA-MBP in the near future, once participants decide which component they would like to purchase with their conservation credit. 

 Conclusion.  While there is no straight-forward solution to poverty, this innovative forest corridor program can be one facet in a larger overarching vision. OHDZA-MBP’s one-million-tree effort, and its related conservation credit program, is a model for serving the needs of Madagascar’s people and wildlife, like the critically endangered Black and white ruffed and Greater bamboo lemurs. Encouraging communities to sustain themselves by conserving their resources rather than exploiting them will be a long-term process, but is the most effective way of steering Madagascar onto a healthier, more prosperous course.

 

 

 Please help us out.  Together, we have to make a difference ...
story_txt:
Help fund and save
One of the most beautiful and precious places on the Planet Earth.
A community-based conservation program to protect critically endangered lemurs in
Kianjavato Classified Forest, Madagascar
The Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership (MBP) is a Malagasy NGO that conducts its conservation efforts in Madagascar to study, research, foster and protect the ecology of the land and its remaining forests.  
More than 90% or Madagascar's forests have been lost in the last century,  which poses a serious threat to the unique biodiversity remaining.  
Lemurs, which can only be found in Madagascar, were recently declared the most threatened mammals in the world. Of the 103 known lemur species, more than 72% are recognized as Critically Endangered or Endangered.
MBP's international team of researchers, educators, engineers and scientists are committed to the challenge of preserving the existing forest and expand them through grassroots tree-planting activities. Critical to MBP's effort is to involve the local community in participating in the restoration and monitoring effort.  Long term protection of Madagascar's forests and wildlife, including endangered lemurs, is only possibile with local participation and commitment.  

http://www.madagascarpartnership.org/home/volunteer_program2
  MBP's project has a goal of planting 1,000,000 trees into the fragmented forest landscape with the assistance of Kianjavato's residents. This effort is part of the "Forest Corridors as Entrepreneurial Opportunities for Madagascar" initiative that combines reforestation with sustainable agroforestry practices. Protecting the local ecosystem requires more than just reforestation, it requires a holistic approach that supports the community and reduces its exploitation of the forest.
  Although the MBP is still a relatively young organization, it has made significant progress towards this end:


Promotion of environmental preservation - In the first half of 2012, more than 30,374 trees have been planted into the fragmented landscape. Satellite nurseries throughout the Kianjavato commune, which are managed by area residents that were trained by the MBP, are housing tens of thousands more native tree seedlings in preparation for the next rainy season, a key planting period.

Engagement of the local community - Over the recent months, it has become clear that word had gotten out about this reforestation program. Not only is local participation and enthusiasm building, but interest is growing from communities outside Kianjavato. Increasingly these residents make the several kilometer-trek on foot to the research station looking for work as day laborers. Working with MBP is now seen as a more reliable source of income than the job of gold mining, which poses health consequences, is environmentally destructive, and infrequently profitable.

Empowerment through education and community development - Reached hundreds of school children, teachers, officials, and residents through a community program between MBP and Conservation Fusion, an international conservation-focused educational organization 


You can help change attitudes and make change happen with just a small donation.  It's easy to affect change - Even a small donation executed thousands of times over by individual compassionate people like you, demonstrates just how.
Hello, My name is Kyle.
  I discovered MBP whilst researching challenging and rewarding employment opportunities and carreer paths for college and university graduates of biology and related disciplines.  My son and daughter namely.   While I was looking for employment/opps abroad for my daughter, I discovered the MBP online.  In addition to hopefully sponsoring my daughter, I wanted to help out with a donation.
  The MBP Volunteer program offers participants an opportunity to budding-scientists to gain knowledge in endangered species protection.  Volunteers and students will be on-the-ground performing real and meaningful field work in-situ in Kianjavato, Madagascar.  Activities involve helping to monitor lemurs in the remaining forest fragments, assisting with the community-wide reforestation effort, working with Malagasy staff to develop research skills, and develop language skills. Participants commit to a 3-6 month minimum stay, during which MBP provides basic accommodations, food, and transportation to/from the MBP research station.   Funding for the filling of these spaces is typically provided by the volunteer themselves, or by a sponsor.  A detailed accounting of the projects work and activity progress can be read/seen a little further below.
  However, the project must also receive funding to carry out its mission of conservation, education and sustainable living for communities and thus, it is the aim of my campaign to generate some of this funding.  Currently this funding is provided via private grants and donations from zoos and individuals.  I decided this could be a way for everyone to help out as much as they can afford to.
  The project acquires tools, resources and labor/manpower as the financial opportunities to do so present themselves. Currently through grants and private donations. Funds are typically spent according to the amounts received but it is nothing short of amazing how much is done with so little money.
http://www.madagascarpartnership.org/home
   
All funding contributions received will go to the MBP whether this campaign goal is reached or not.
 Perks:  As MBP is still a developing organization, we are always in a cycle of updates and advancements, thus are perks may be limited. For those who donate and/or contribute to the general project, we will acknowledge them on our website and email project updates to those who sign up.  We are actively developing a system to tie every donation to a specific tree in the ground. Our future goal is to be able to provide each donor with a GPS location that they can take to Google Earth and see where in the world their sponsored tree was planted. We hope to launch a new page on our website that will have a map where people can zoom in and see the location of their tree, the species, date it was planted, and who planted it. This is still under development, but we believe it will be a fantastic tool once available. (If you love our project and want to volunteer - you could help us get this function up and running!)
  Contributors can request and will recieve via email, a breakdown of how funds are allocated and spent via a pair of reports for this year 2012.  They have been provided by the project.  MBP makes very little money go a very long distance.  My goal is to raise $20,000 to help the project fund its activities, with a special emphasis on expanding the reforestation effort and other critical components of the program with the greatest need for aid.
However small your contribution - It still means a lot.  If you can't contribute, at least take a moment and look at the MBP website to see their project. Like MBP on Facebook; follow MBP on Twitter; help spread the word about the work that they are doing. Work like this is more important to your children and even more important to theirs.  We cannot save the world in one fell swoop.  We have to find our one place and start there.  We have to give back. 

Below are excerpts from reports on the project's activities for the first half of 2012.  The reports serve to explain in detail and inform pertinent agencies about the ongoing work and progress of the Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership:
MBP Project Overview
  With few viable alternatives, Madagascar’s population continues to be reliant upon several environmentally harmful activities such as slash and burn farming, mining and hunting, all of which threaten the island’s extraordinary species diversity. Due to a lack of effective protection of two critically endangered lemur species in the surrounding forests of Kianjavato, in southeast Madagascar, Omaha’s Henry Doorly Zoo and Aquarium (OHDZA) and the Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership (MBP) established an extensive research project in the area in 2007. Operating under the premise of finding a sustainable path forward for the lemurs and the 12,000 residents reliant upon the surrounding forest fragments, OHDZA-MBP developed a community-based conservation effort, the “Education Promoting Reforestation Program” (EPRP).
This grassroots reforestation program deployed MBP personnel to track seed-dispersing lemurs through the forest, in this case the Black and white ruffed lemur (Varecia variegata). While monitoring lemurs, fecal samples were collected opportunistically year-round from which local field assistants extracted and sorted seeds, and planted in nurseries.
The resulting seedlings were transplanted as part of a community supported reforestation and restoration program that utilized these native trees to restore habitat and enable movement of lemur populations. Once mature, the transplanted endemic trees will entice lemurs to forage and continue the process of forest restoration themselves, thus requiring less future human intervention. Additionally, the structure of the reforestation plan also included tree species with commercial value, thus providing area residents with an additional source of income over time.
Community awareness and support has increased due to the employment of large numbers of local community members to monitor lemurs, maintenance and preparation of seedlings in the local nurseries, as well as transplantation of trees. Furthermore, the planned distribution of incentive items as part of the conservation credit program, which is scheduled to occur in July 2012, will further strengthen community ties to forest and lemur protection efforts.
MBP Project Update Since the receipt of the grant award from the XXX Foundation, OHDZA-MBP made great strides in advancing towards the goals of the grant.
Promotion of environmental preservation: The OHDZA-MBP reforestation efforts have enhanced the promotion of habitat protection with more than 30,000 trees being planted into the landscape thus far in 2012, thereby establishing the foundation for vital corridors to connect forest fragments. The eight nurseries strategically located near each participating village housed seedlings prior to transplantation. Community representatives from the immediate area run these nurseries and coordinate future community planting days.
In addition, the program has led to the creation of contracts between OHDZA-MBP and each village. These contracts are designed to identify the specific location for each community-designated nursery plot, define the contributions of each partner, and clearly states that the land remains in the hands of the original owners.As the program expands its efforts into the larger community, there has been a growing interest in the reforestation of neighboring territories. In fact, OHDZA-MBP has increasingly been receiving requests from communities outside the Kianjavato area for guidance in the construction of nurseries near their village. Not wanting the community-based reforestation effort momentum to stop at the border of the Kianjavato commune, OHDZA-MBP has been working with representatives from these other communities to set the groundwork for their reforestation initiative.

Engagement of the local community: To date, there are a number of fantastic community partners routinely contributing to the planting efforts. These comprise groups that we originally anticipated would be involved, such as area residents, school children and their teachers, village elders, and local officials. This is in addition to the OHDZ-MBP Malagasy graduate students, local assistants and guides, and visiting researchers who are regularly involved with the program on a more official capacity. However, there is growing interest in participating from additional groups, including a local single women’s club, members of which are single mothers whose involvement with the project allows them to contribute to the community and earn additional income.
These women currently fill the role of weeding the nurseries and making shade structures for newly transplanted seedlings.Over the recent months it has become clear that word has gotten out about this reforestation program. Increasingly, people from communities outside Kianjavato make the several kilometer-trek on foot to the research station looking for work as day laborers. Working with OHDZA-MBP is now seen as a more reliable source of income than the job of gold mining, which poses health consequences, is environmentally destructive, and infrequently profitable.
Due to the participation of many factions within the Kianjavato community, there is a building of local appreciation for the project as well as its potential for aiding residents and the regional wildlife over the foreseeable future. This acceptance, coupled with a thirst for knowledge, is vital for any conservation effort, and we are very fortunate in this regard and must use it to the advantage of the larger conservation program.
   
Empowerment through education and community development: There are a number of new exciting advances regarding other education and community development opportunities. The project currently supports a postdoctoral researcher, who has a Ph.D. in botany and significant experience working with plants in Madagascar, to oversee the Kianjavato research program. Furthermore, in the first quarter of the year we had two international volunteers, with experience in horticulture and project management, spearhead the reforestation program.
These volunteers worked closely with the nursery managers, day laborers and community participants, teaching them new skills and techniques. The reforestation program made some of its greatest advances while these volunteers were onsite, so in order to continue this momentum, we are bringing two other international volunteers onsite in late June to further manage the reforestation effort and transfer lessons to the local community.

To make the most of the project’s growing awareness and community desire for assistance, our partner, Conservation Fusion, is planning a return visit to the communities of Kianjavato. The international NGO will lead another series of education and community development events to strengthen community interest and ability to participate in making a positive impact. Thus far, the advancements in community-relations have been made with minimal presentation of the conservation incentive items such as the rocket stoves and Tough Stuff Kits. However, in July 2012, the OHDZA-MBP is planning a distribution event, where participants in the reforestation program that have earned sufficient conservation credits will be awarded with a Tough Stuff Kit. \
This allocation will coincide with an education and outreach event which will highlight the advantages and ease of use of the Tough Stuff items. Although there is growing interest regarding our reforestation program, we hope that the educational activities and conservation credit program will assist us in gathering more support from the community to make the one million-tree effort feasible.
Grant-specific Update.  With the grant award from the XXX Foundation for $6,000, we amended the original design and quantity of Tough Stuff Kits that would be made available. The funds enabled us to purchase sufficient components to offer 300 Tough Stuff Kits as incentive items, each with a solar panel and battery power pack (see Table 1). story:
Who am I and why?

My name is Fatemah. This year my husband(Tahir) and I are planning to climb the CN tower to help raise funds for a good cause. We both love outdoor activities/challenges hence we try to make a point of doing activities together that will not only keep us fit while helping strengthen our bond but also if it happens to make a difference in someone else's life then we woul say all the more reason to do it!

This year's climb is organised by WWF and by participating in the CN Tower Climb for WWF we want to help them continue to preserve our living planet and protect its species today, and for future generations!

We took part in a similar climb last year(pictured above) to raise funds for United Way Toronto which is a non-profit organization that strives to help others in a meaningful way. After viewing the United Way video for 2012 at (http://youtu.be/MpVzfJv5B7o) it gave me satisfaction knowing our donation no matter how small went a long way towards helping United Way make things possible for people. You too can make such a difference by supporting our effort towards WWF. Pledge your amount today to enable us to go for the climb and reach our goal!

Why donate to WWF-Canada? 

WWF-Canada is part of the global conservation network.

  • WWF works to protect the world's biodiversity, conserve critical habitats and address global threats like climate change
  • WWF finds long-term solutions that benefit both people and nature
  • Using the best available scientific knowledge, we work to preserve the diversity and abundance of life in Canada and around the world
  • WWF seeks to reduce the ecological footprint left by humans
  • You'll feel great about what you're doing for the planet and for species at risk
  • Donations of $20 or more are tax receiptable
  • It is a fun-filled event that promotes team/group spirit and camaraderie!

 What amount you need to donate to get a tax receipt? 

All donations of $20 or more will get receipted. Upon special request a tax receipt for a smaller amount can be issued. Please ensure that your complete e-mail address and complete mailing address is included with the donation. Email me at fatemah.wwfclimb@gmail.com with these details

Interesting Fact

Every year, over 15,000 people climb the 1,776 steps of the CN Tower’s main stairwell to raise money for the World Wildlife Fund and the United Way.

story:
Story:

Come with us and touch the earth, capture the scent of her fresh dark soil and the fragrance of her precious life.

She will comfort your spirit with her soft gentle song.

Come with us...Grandma and I will share our story with you..

What The Book is About:

Although the title of this book is a powerful message, it contains a collection of short stories which are softened by morals, ethics and values. A young Indian girl shares her views on the love and concern she has for her homeland an tribal life.

These stories are based on the true Blackfeet culture, creation story, ancient spiritual values and social life. Fracking is only lightly touched on at the end of each story.

Lets face it, fracking is not a pretty subject so I felt it was important to add colorful illistrations to each story. A local Blackfeet artist is working on some beautiful illistrations for each page. These drawings portray an original way of native life and will draw the readers attention to what the story is about.

This book is designed to attact the attention of 6th graders up to adult.

Why is this Important:

The Blackfeet Nation sits on one of the most beautiful places on Mother Earth. From wide open praries, rolling hills and snow capped mountains, our tribe has called this place home for many thousands of years. Our entire being as a tribe is emmersed in the values of the waters, air and soil and all life upon Earth. This story is told by a young girl, there is no one better to get the point across than through the eyes of a child.

The Blackfeet Nation sits at the base of the Rocky Mountain front, which is the headwaters for major waterways that serve several towns, cities, including Canada. Life for thousands of miles around depend on these pure nutrient rich waters for survival.

I feel the stories and illistrations in this book are vital information in making a significant statement to our own Blackfeet people. They will educate our people on the dangers of fracking. Therefore they will be more inclined to inform the tribal council who can determine whether there should be a moritorium or ban put on the hydraulic fracturing (fracking).

Fracking came up on us so fast that no one knew what it was and most people still don't. Through my efforts I am trying to bring awareness and try to ban fracking.

What have I done:

I have sit up meetings and shared brochures and articles on the fracking process. I hung anti-fracking banners all over in our community. In August of this year I created a 80 mile 6 day walk, (Chief Mountain Water Walk) along the mountain front to pray, sing our water song and give offerings of sacred tobacco to each water way we came to. Nearly 14 others joined me.

This walk drew attention from the New York times to the Seattle Post and media around the world, however my focus was to try and bring attention to my own community and tribe. So far I have provided all of the funds to take a stand against fracking and today I cannot move forward without asking for help in financing this book. I continue to search for ways to stop the loss of our beautiful homeland and this book is my next step.

Why Do I Care:

I care about the life of future generations and the drinking water of grandchildren that I may never meet. I care about the this priceless piece of land that is so important to the Creation Story of our people. I care deeply for aspects of a ancient culture that may be lost in the midst of moneary ideas and greed.

I believe this will be a good way to bring attention to the fracking as well as an avenue for spiritual healing. We need it after all of the heartbreak and stress this venture endures.

My Drive

I am excited about this book it has been very healing for me to write and I thank you for being a part of my story.I have decided to publish this book through self-publishing, (Outskirts Press) because time is of the essence.Today the fracking is quickly invading our piece of the Earth.

My plan is that with funding help I can have this book ready to publish by March 1st, 2013. The amount of money I am asking for is $8,000 in order to make it a unique book that will also be an inovative way in bringing awareness to the people who have the power to ban fracking.

If there is any additional funding from the book, it will be used for the 2013 Chief Mountain Water Walk. We are all in this together, so everyone world wide is invited to join us on our spiritual walk to honor, bless and protect all waters.

Financial List for 48 page book:

  • 56 Artist Illistrations 
  • Graphic clean up and layout 
  • Book Publishing 
  • Editing 
  • Gas for travel 
  • Additional books to keep on hand for speaker gifts at antifracking meetings. 
  • Additional 500 books to give to Blackfeet community college, Blackfeet Elementary, Junior High schools and library for free.
